AN ZOOR14805040624
DT Article
TI A preliminary assessment of the Nactus pelagicus species group
   (Squamata: Gekkonidae) in New Guinea and a new species from the
   Admiralty Islands.
AU Zug, George R. (zugg@si.edu) 
   Fisher, Robert N.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3257
PS 22-37
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3257.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03257p037.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Slender-toed Geckos (Nactus) currently have four recognized species
   in New Guinea, and these species divide into two sister clades: a
   pelagicus clade and a vankampeni clade (Heinicke et al. 2010). The
   latter contains three dwarf species. The former consists of five
   bisexual populations, of which numerous New Guinea populations are
   uncharacterized no- menclaturally and lumped under the epithet
   'pelagicus.' This report and description of a new species of the
   pelagicus group from Manus Island in the Admiralty Islands encourages us
   to offer a preliminary assessment of morphology and diversity in New
   Guinea 'pelagicus' populations.
C1 Zug, George R.; Department of Vertebrate Zoology, National Museum of
   Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, District of
   Columbia 20013, USA, USA.
EM zugg@si.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia; Oceanic islands; Pacific
   Ocean islands
DE Nactus kunan [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
   Nactus pelagicus species group [Indonesia / New Guinea / Distribution;
   systematics] [Australia /  / ] [Papua New Guinea /  / ] [Vanuatu /  / ].
   
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Nactus kunan - Fisher & Zug 2012 (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Papua New
   Guinea, P. 26]. 
   Nactus pelagicus species group (Gekkonidae). 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3257.1.2

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of genus Gobio from Turkey (Teleostei:
   Cyprinidae).
AU Turan, Davut (dvtturan@yahoo.com) 
   Ekmerci, F. Guler
   Luskova, Vera
   Mendel, Jan
SO Zootaxa
VL 3257
PS 56-65
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3257.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03257p065.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Gobio sakaryaensis, a new species from the Tozman and the Porsuk streams
   of the Sakarya River drainage (northwestern Anatolia, Black Sea basin),
   is described. The species is distinguished from other gudgeons by a
   combination of the following characters: breast completely scaled,
   scales approximately extending to isthmus; head length 27.2[long
   dash]30.0 % SL; 39[long dash] 42 lateral line scales; 4[long dash]6
   scales between anus and anal-fin origin; 6[long dash]8 scales between
   posterior extremity of pelvic-fin bases and anus. A key is provided for
   Gobio and Romanogobio species recorded from Turkey.
C1 Turan, Davut; Rize University, Faculty of Fisheries and Aquatic
   Sciences, 53100 Rize, Turkey, Turkey.
EM dvtturan@yahoo.com
RI Luskova, Vera/A-2227-2015; Ekmekci, Fitnat Guler/Q-4029-2016; Mendel,
   Jan/F-9728-2014
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Gobio [Turkey /  / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution]. 
   Gobio sakaryaensis [Turkey /  / New species]. 
   Romanogobio [Turkey /  / Key to species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Gobio (Cyprinidae): [Key to species, Turkey, P. 61]. 
   Gobio sakaryaensis (Cyprinidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 57]. 
   Romanogobio (Cyprinidae): [Key to species, Turkey, P. 61]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3257.1.4

PT J
AN ZOOR14805040616
DT Article
TI Revision of Argoravinia Townsend (Diptera: Sarcophagidae) of Brazil with
   the description of two new species.
AU Da Silva Carvalho Filho, Fernando (fernanbio@yahoo.com.br) 
   Esposito, Maria Cristina
SO Zootaxa
VL 3256
PS 1-26
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3256.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03256p026.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Argoravinia Townsend comprises six species restricted to the
   New World, with the exception of two species introduced into the
   Marshall Islands. The nominal genus Raviniopsis Townsend was considered
   a junior synonym of Argoravinia in the last catalogue of Sarcophagidae
   and the results of the present study support this arrangement. However,
   Argoravinia (s.s.) and Raviniopsis are considered as subgenera of
   Argoravinia, since they comprise two distinct species groups that are
   each inferred to be monophyletic based on characters of the male and
   female terminalia. Four species of Argoravinia previously recorded from
   Brazil are redescribed: A. alvarengai Lopes, A. aurea (Townsend), A.
   brasiliana (Lopes), and A. rufiventris (Wiedemann). Two new species of
   the subgenus Argoravinia are described from the Brazilian Amazon: A.
   catiae sp. nov. and A. paraensis sp. nov. Additional information on the
   biology of A. aurea is provided. A key to all six described species of
   Argoravinia is presented.
C1 Da Silva Carvalho Filho, Fernando; Laboratorio de Ecologia de
   Invertebrados, Instituto de Biologia, Universidade Federal do Para, Rua
   Augusto Correa, 01, Guama, Belem, PA, Brazil, Brazil.
EM fernanbio@yahoo.com.br
RI Esposito, Maria/C-3104-2016
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Argoravinia [Brazil /  / Taxonomic revision]. 
   Argoravinia (Argoravinia) catiae; Argoravinia (Argoravinia) paraensis
   [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Sarcophagidae
OR Argoravinia - Townsend 1917 (Sarcophagidae): [Key to species, P. 3]. 
   Argoravinia (Argoravinia) alvarengai - Lopes 1976 (Sarcophagidae):
   [Redescription, P. 4]. 
   Argoravinia (Argoravinia) catiae (Sarcophagidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P.
   9]. 
   Argoravinia (Argoravinia) paraensis (Sarcophagidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P.
   11]. 
   Argoravinia (Argoravinia) rufiventris - (Wiedemann 1830)
   (Sarcophagidae): [Redescription, P. 14]. 
   Argoravinia (Raviniopsis) aurea - (Townsend 1918) (Sarcophagidae):
   [Redescription, P. 16]. 
   Argoravinia (Raviniopsis) brasiliana - (Lopes 1988) (Sarcophagidae):
   [Redescription, P. 19].

DT Article
TI The genus Phygasia Chevrolat (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Galerucinae:
   Alticini) in Taiwan.
AU Lee, Chi-Feng (chifeng@tari.gov.tw) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3256
PS 27-37
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3256.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03256p037.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Taiwanese species of Phygasia are reviewed. Phygasia diluta Chujo,
   1963 is recognized as a valid species and is removed from synonymy with
   P. ornata Baly, 1876. It is a senior subjective synonym of P.
   taiwanensis Ge et al., 2010. The widely distributed P. ornata Baly, 1876
   is not found on the island of Taiwan but occurs on the Kinmen Island. A
   new species, P. chengi, parapatric with P. diluta, is described. A key
   to the Taiwanese species of Phygasia is provided.
C1 Lee, Chi-Feng; Applied Zoologi Division, Taiwan Agricultuural Research
   Institute, Taichung 413, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM chifeng@tari.gov.tw
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Phygasia [Taiwan /  / Key to species] [ /  / Systematics]. 
   Phygasia chengi [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
   Phygasia ornata [Taiwan / Kinmen Island / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae
OR Phygasia - Chevrolat 1836 (Chrysomelidae): [Key to species, Taiwan, P.
   33]. 
   Phygasia chengi - Lee 2012 (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 28]. 
   Phygasia diluta - Chujo 1963 (Chrysomelidae): [Description, P. 30; Syn
   nov, Phygasia taiwanensis Ge et al 2010, p. 30]. 
   Phygasia ornata - Baly 1876 (Chrysomelidae): [Description, P. 32;
   Removal from synonymy, Phygasia taiwanensis Ge et al 2010, p. 30; New
   record]. 
   Phygasia ornata species group (Chrysomelidae): [Diagnosis, P. 28]. 
   Phygasia taiwanensis - Ge et al 2010 (Chrysomelidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Phygasia ornata Baly 1876, p. 30]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3256.1.2

DT Article
TI A review of the genera Prismognathus Motschulsky and Cladophyllus
   Houlbert (Coleoptera: Scarabaeoidea: Lucanidae) from China, with the
   description of two new species.
AU Huang, Hao (cmdhhxx@hotmail.com) 
   Chen, Chang-Chin
SO Zootaxa
VL 3255
PS 1-36
PD 3 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3255.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03255p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A classification scheme is provided for the genera Cladophyllus
   Houlbert, Cyclorasis Thomson, Eligmodontus Houlbert, Gonometopus
   Houlbert, Prismognathus Motschulsky and Tetrarthrius Didier. The Chinese
   species of Prismognathus (in the present sense) and Cladophyllus are
   reviewed, with the male and female genitalia illustrated. New
   distribution data are given for some Chinese species. Two new species of
   Prismognathus are described, P. haojiani new species from Guizhou, and
   P. shani new species from Sichuan. Keys to males and females of the
   Chinese Prismognathus and Cladophyllus are also given.
C1 Huang, Hao; 503 East, No 1 Dong-ting-hu Road, Qingdao, China, China.

   China

   Prismognathus shani [Sichuan /  / New species].

   Female, p. 22]. 
   Cladophyllus nobuhikoi - Ikeda 2000 (Lucanidae): [First time figured,
   Female genitalia, p. 4]. 
   Cladophyllus oberthuri - Houlbert 1912 (Lucanidae): [First time figured,
   Female, p. 22]. 
   Cyclorasis - Thomson 1862 (Lucanidae): [Valid name, P. 2]. 
   Prismognathus - Motschulsky 1860 (Lucanidae): [Key to species, China,
   Males p. 17, females, p. 19; New record].

DT Article
TI The genus Ctenosciara Tuomikoski (Diptera, Sciaridae) in New Caledonia,
   with the description of eight new species.
AU Vilkamaa, Pekka (pekka.vilkamaa@helsinki.fi) 
   Hippa, Heikki
   Mohrig, Werner
SO Zootaxa
VL 3255
PS 37-51
PD 3 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3255.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03255p051.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Ctenosciara Tuomikoski, 1960, includes the following species
   in New Caledonia, all newly described: Cteno- sciara cracens sp. n., C.
   crinita sp. n., C. depilis sp. n., C. depressa sp. n., C. exilis sp. n.,
   C. inflata sp. n., C. lobigera sp. n. and C. obesa sp. n. Some of the
   species show for the genus previously unknown characters. A key to the
   New Caledonian species of Ctenosciara is provided.

PT J
AN ZOOR14805040120
DT Article
TI The discovery of the rare genus Xyeloblacus van Achterberg, 1997
   (Hymenoptera: Braconidae, Blacinae) in China, with description of a new
   species.
AU Huangfu, Wei-Guo (xxchen@zju.edu.cn) 
   Chai, Hong-Fei
   Chen, Xue-Xin
SO Zootaxa
VL 3255
PS 65-67
PD 3 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3255.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03255p067.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Blacinae Foerster, 1862 is a cosmopolitan subfamily of Braconidae
   (Hymenoptera), with five tribes and 14 genera (van Achterberg 1976,
   1988). The genus Xyeloblacus van Achterberg, 1997 is the only member of
   the tribe Xyeloblacini van Achterberg with two known species in the
   world (van Achterberg and Altenhofer, 1997; Yu et al., 2005). van
   Achterberg and Altenhofer (1997) mentioned four important characters for
   Xyeloblacus as follows: the straight ventral margin of the clypeus, the
   crenulate anterior subalar depression, the curved vein 1-1A of fore
   wing, and the presence of vein 2A of hind wing. The members of this
   genus are parasitoids of Xyela spp. (Xyeloidea: Xyelidae) (van
   Achterberg and Altenhofer, 1997). In this paper, the genus Xyeloblacus
   is reported for the first time from China with one new species, X.
   longithecus sp. nov., described. A key to species of this genus is
   updated. The terminology and measurements used in this paper follow van
   Achterberg (1976, 1988, 1990). Additional sources for the description of
   sculpture and setation follow Belokobylskij (1995, 2000). All
   descriptions and measurements were made under Leica MZ 12.5 microscope,
   and all images were made with a digital camera (Q-Imaging,
   Micropublisher, 3.3 RTV) attached to a stereomicroscope (Leica MZ APO,
   Germany) and Auto-Montage Pro version 5.0 software. Type specimens are
   deposited in the Parasitic Hymenoptera Collection of the Zhejiang
   University, Hangzhou, China (ZJUH).
C1 Huangfu, Wei-Guo; State Key Lab of Rice Biology and Ministry of
   Agriculture Key lab of Agricultural Entomology, Institute of Insect
   Sciences, Zhejiang University, 866 Yuhangtang Road, Hangzhou 310058,
   China, China.
EM xxchen@zju.edu.cn
RI Chen, Xue-xin/D-1592-2010
OI Chen, Xue-xin/0000-0002-9109-8853
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Xyeloblacus [China /  / New record] [Henan /  / ] [Zhejiang /  / ]. 
   Xyeloblacus longithecus [Henan /  / New species] [Zhejiang /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Braconidae
OR Xyeloblacus - van Achterberg 1997 (Braconidae): [Key to species, P. 65;
   New record]. 
   Xyeloblacus longithecus (Braconidae): [Sp nov, Henan, P. 65]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14805040120
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Phrixosoma concavifrons - a sexually dimorphic Phrixosomatini
   (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) from the Udzungwa mountains in Tanzania.
AU Jordal, Bjarte H. (bjarte.jordal@um.uib.no) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3255
PS 52-56
PD 3 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3255.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03255p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Phrixosoma from Tanzania is described and illustrated.
   This is a unique species for the genus in having a strongly concave
   female frons. Several characters are described for the first time for
   this genus, including male and female genitalia, mouthparts, thoracic
   sutures, and several overlooked features of the meso- and metatibiae and
   sternal processes.
C1 Jordal, Bjarte H.; Museum of Natural History, University Museum of
   Bergen PB 7800, NO-5020, Bergen, Norway, Norway.

PT J
AN ZOOR14805040021
DT Article
TI Scottoecia - a new genus of halocyprid ostracod, with the description of
   Scottoecia arabica nov. sp. and the redescription of Bathyconchoecia
   darcythompsoni (Scott, 1909).
AU Angel, Martin V. (mvangel37@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3254
PS 32-54
PD 2 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3254.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03254p054.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB On re-describing two species originally attributed to the halocyprid
   genus Bathyconchoecia (B. darcythompsoni Scott, 1909 from the North
   Atlantic and B. lacunosa sensu James 1973 from the Gulf of Oman) they
   were found to show substantive differences from the type species for the
   genus, B. paulula. These differences are: 1. Several carapace
   characteristics including size, the structure of the rostra and
   incisure, and the locations of the openings of the carapace glands. 2.
   Limb structures notably of the mandibles. 3. The exceptionally long
   dorsal terminal seta on the male sixth limb. 4. The structure of the
   copulatory appendage. These two species are placed in a newly defined
   genus Scottoecia, for which S. arabica is designated as the type
   species. The original descriptions of three other Bathyconchoecia
   species, show that they belong to Scottoecia, namely S. crosnieri
   (Poulsen, 1969a), S. subrufa (Angel, 1970a) and S. foveolata (Deevey,
   1968). This has been confirmed for the first two species by the
   examination of the type material. Another species Bathyconchoecia
   baskiae Poulsen, (1969b) has similar mandibles, and is probably closely
   related, but does not share all the characteristics of the new genus.
   The validity of the previous classification in which Bathyconchoecia is
   included in the subfamily, the Euconchoecinae, is questioned.
C1 Angel, Martin V.; National Oceanographic Centre, Waterfront Campus,
   European Way, Southampton SO14 3ZH, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM mvangel37@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Scottoecia arabica [Persian Gulf /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Bathyconchoecia crosnieri - Poulsen 1969 (Ostracoda): [Referred to, New

DT Article
TI The catfish genus Erethistoides (Siluriformes: Sisoridae) in Myanmar,
   with descriptions of three new species.
AU Ng, Heok Hee (heokhee@nus.edu.sg) 
   Ferraris, Carl J., Jr
   Neely, David A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3254
PS 55-68
PD 2 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3254.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03254p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The presence of the sisorid catfish genus Erethistoides in Myanmar,
   represented by three new species, is recorded for the first time. This
   discovery from the Irrawaddy and Sittang river drainages from central
   Myanmar and the Ann Chaung River drainage in western Myanmar extends the
   documented range of the genus beyond the Ganges/Brahmaputra River basin.
   Erethistoides longispinis is distinguished from congeners in having the
   following unique combination of characters: length of the dorsal-fin
   spine 24[long dash]27% SL, length of the pectoral-fin spine 29[long
   dash]35% SL, and absence of proximally-directed serrations on the
   anterior edge of the pectoral spine. Erethistoides luteolus differs from
   congeners in having the following combination of characters: yellow base
   color of the body, body with distinct bands, vertebrae 30, premaxillary
   tooth band partially exposed when the mouth is closed, length of the
   dorsal-fin spine 14[long dash]15% SL, length of the pectoral-fin spine
   21[long dash]24% SL, absence of proximally-directed serrations on the
   anterior edge of the pectoral spine, length of the adipose-fin base
   16[long dash]17% SL, length of the caudal peduncle 22[long dash]25% SL
   and depth of the caudal peduncle 6[long dash] 7% SL. Erethistoides
   vesculus is distinguished from congeners in having the following
   combination of characters: cream base color of the body, body with
   distinct bands, vertebrae 30, premaxillary tooth band partially exposed
   when the mouth is closed, length of the dorsal-fin spine 15% SL, length
   of the pectoral-fin spine 22[long dash]23% SL, absence of proximally-
   directed serrations on the anterior edge of the pectoral spine, length
   of the adipose-fin base 14[long dash]15% SL, length of the caudal
   peduncle 19[long dash]21% SL and depth of the caudal peduncle 4[long
   dash]5% SL.
C1 Ng, Heok Hee; Tropical Marine Science Institute, National University of
   Singapore, 18 Kent Ridge Road, Singapore 119227, Singapore.

AN ZOOR14805040011
DT Article
TI A review of Norwegian streptaster-bearing Astrophorida (Porifera:
   Demospongiae: Tetractinellida), new records and a new species.
AU Cardebas, Paco (cardenas_paco@yahoo.fr) 
   Rapp, Hans Tore
SO Zootaxa
VL 3253
PS 1-53
PD 2 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3253.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03253p053.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We report and describe new material of streptaster-bearing Astrophorida
   sponges collected in Norway: Characella pachastrelloides, Pachastrella
   nodulosa sp. nov., Poecillastra compressa, Vulcanella cf. aberrans,
   Thenea abyssorum, Thenea levis, Thenea muricata and Thenea valdiviae.
   Because many of these species were described in the end of the 19th
   century their original descriptions are often incomplete. The Norwegian
   specimens are the basis for a revision of the morphology, taxonomy and
   distribution of these species. These are the first records of C.
   pachastrelloides and V. cf. aberrans from the Norwegian coast.
   Pachastrella nodulosa sp. nov. differs from Pachastrella monilifera by
   (i) its knobby surface and (ii) the absence of large oxeas, (iii) its
   amphiasters have on average less actines and are less spiny, finally
   (iv) microxeas are rare and with a distinct morphology (although there
   is some doubt concerning their origin). In the present study, Characella
   tuberosa (from South Africa), Pachastrella abyssi (from the North-West
   Atlantic) and Thenea schmidti (from the North-East Atlantic) are
   resurrected. To help their future identifications, all the Norwegian
   species described were associated with DNA barcodes: a cytochrome c
   oxidase subunit I (COI) gene partial fragment and/or a 28S ribosomal
   gene partial fragment (C1[long dash]D2 domains). Furthermore, a key to
   the streptaster-bearing Astrophorida of the North-East Atlantic and the
   Mediterranean Sea is also given (lithistids not included).
C1 Cardebas, Paco; Department of Biology, Univesity of Bergen, PO Box 7803,
   N-5020 Bergen, Norway, Norway.
EM cardenas_paco@yahoo.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Astrophorida [Arctic Ocean / Norway / Distribution; new record;
   systematics; streptaster-bearing taxa] [North Atlantic / Northeast
   Atlantic / Key to species] [ /  / ] [Mediterranean Sea /  / ]. 
   Characella pachastrelloides [North Atlantic / Norway / New record]. 
   Pachastrella nodulosa [Arctic Ocean / Norway / New species] [North
   Atlantic /  / ]. 
   Vulcanella cf. aberrans [Arctic Ocean / Norway / New record]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Astrophorida (Demospongiae): [Key to species, Mediterranean Sea & North
   Atlantic, Northeast Atlantic, Streptaster-bearing taxa, p. 48; New
   record]. 
   Characella pachastrelloides (Demospongiae): [New record]. 
   Pachastrella nodulosa (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, Norway (marine), P. 11]. 
   Vulcanella cf. aberrans (Demospongiae): [New record].

TI A new feather mite species of the genus Proctophyllodes Robin, 1877
   (Astigmata: Proctophyllodidae) from the Long-tailed Tit Aegithalos
   caudatus (Passeriformes: Aegithalidae) - morphological description with
   DNA barcode data.
AU Mironov, Sergey V. (astigmata@zin.ru) 
   Dabert, Jacek
   Dabert, Miroslawa
SO Zootaxa
VL 3253
PS 54-61
PD 2 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3253.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03253p061.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new feather mites species, Proctophyllodes valchukae sp. n., is
   described from the Long-tailed Tit, Aegithalos caudatus (Linnaeus, 1758)
   (Passeriformes: Aegithalidae), captured in the Primoriye (Russian Far
   East). The new species belongs to the tricetratus species group and is
   most closely related to P. stachyris Atyeo et Braasch, 1966. For the
   first time for feather mites the standard morphological description is
   supplemented by sequence data of the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase
   subunit I gene fragment (COI) and nuclear D2 region of 28S rDNA.
C1 Mironov, Sergey V.; Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences,
   Universitetskaya quay 1, 199034, Saint Petersburg, Russia, Russia.

AN ZOOR14805040014
DT Article
TI A new species of frogfish of the genus Histiophryne (Teleostei:
   Lophiiformes: Antennariidae) from Lombok and Komodo, Indonesia.
AU Arnold, Rachel J. (schoenrj@uw.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3253
PS 62-68
PD 2 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3253.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03253p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Histiophryne pogonius, a new species of frogfish of the teleost order
   Lophiiformes, family Antennariidae, is described from a total of five
   specimens: three collected in shallow waters surrounding Lombok,
   Indonesia, one reportedly from the nearshore waters of Cebu,
   Philippines, and a photograph of a specimen from Komodo Island,
   Indonesia. The new taxon differs from its congeners in having an
   extremely small illicium and esca, barely discernible even with aid of a
   dissecting microscope; dark pink pigmentation overlaying a pale pink
   background, including a dark pink basidorsal spot; a small white
   encrusted patch of skin always present posterior to pectoral-fin origin,
   with similar patches sometimes present on cheeks; body everywhere
   covered with small dark reddish to black spots, including lips and outer
   margins of the sclera, spots encircled by a thin white ring; cheeks with
   shallow depressions, giving head a pitted appearance; head lightly
   covered with cutaneous cirri, especially around edges of opercle; upper
   and lower lips with short cutaneous cirri; and genetic divergence in
   mitochondrial gene cytochrome oxidase c subunit I (COI). The new species
   is described and compared with its congeners, and a phylogenetic tree
   based on the nuclear recombination activation gene-2 (RAG2) and
   mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase c subunit I (COI) and 16S genes is
   presented.
C1 Arnold, Rachel J.; School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences, and Burke
   Museum of Natural History and Culture, University of Washington, Campus
   Box 355020, Seattle, Washington 98105-5020, USA, USA.
EM schoenrj@uw.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Histiophryne pogonius [South Indian Ocean / Indonesia / New species]
   [North Pacific / Philippines / ] [South Pacific /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Lophiiformes, Antennariidae
OR Histiophryne pogonius (Antennariidae): [Sp nov, Philippines (marine), P.
   63]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14805040014
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14805040020
DT Article
TI New species of Terebellides (Polychaeta: Trichobranchidae) indicate
   long-distance dispersal between western South Atlantic deep-sea basins.
AU Schueller, Myriam (myriam.schueller@freenet.de) 
   Hutchings, P.A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3254
PS 1-31
PD 2 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3254.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03254p031.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 6
AB During the expedition DIVA 3 in summer 2009, six new species of the
   genus Terebellides (Trichobranchidae) were discovered from the deep
   Argentine and Brazil basins. Five of these (Terebellides gingko sp. n.,
   Terebellides banalis sp. n., Terebellides bulbosa sp. n., Terebellides
   concertina sp. n., Terebellides diva sp. n.) are formally described
   herein; the sixth species is only briefly described as it was
   represented by only a single specimen. While most species were
   represented by a few specimens from a single basin, T. gingko sp. n.,
   was found in relative high abundances in both basins. Molecular analyses
   of 16S rDNA sequences confirmed the long-distance distribution of this
   species. Although branchiae are lost in the majority of specimens found,
   all new species can clearly be separated from each other and
   Terebellides species formerly reported for shallow western South
   Atlantic waters by the relationships between head structures and
   anterior segments, and the shape of thoracic and anterior uncini,
   presenting evidence for a diverse and previously undescribed diversity
   of Trichobranchidae in the world's deep seas.
C1 Schueller, Myriam; Animal Ecology, Evolution & Biodiversity,
   ruhr-University, 44780 Bochum, Germany, Germany.
EM myriam.schueller@freenet.de
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Habitat; Zoogeography;
   Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean

   Deep-sea basins / distribution] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [South
   Atlantic / South America / ]. 
   Terebellides banalis; Terebellides bulbosa; Terebellides diva;
   Terebellides ginkgo [South Atlantic / Brazil / New species]. 
   Terebellides concertina [South Atlantic / Argentina / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates

   Terebellides concertina (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Argentina (marine), P.
   19]. 
   Terebellides diva (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Brazil (marine), P. 23]. 
   Terebellides ginkgo (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Brazil (marine), P. 7].

TI Description of a new sand lance species, Bleekeria murtii (Perciformes:
   Ammodytidae) from India.
AU Joshi, K.K. (joshycmfri@rediffmail.com) 
   Zacharia, P.U.
   Kanthan, P.

VL 59
IS 2
PS 101-107
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new fish species of the genus Bleekeria was collected by trawl nets
   off Tuticorin from a depth of 20-30 m. Bleekeria murtii is characterized
   by 34-39 dorsal rays, 12-16 anal rays, 80-108 lateral line scales, high
   head length (21.1-23.2 in SL), smaller eye diameter (2.45-5.37 mm) and
   high body height (8.7-19.7 mm). The species-specific characters, colour
   pattern and morphometric variations are described in detail.

DT Article
TI Biology and Morphology of Neochlamisus gibbosus (Fabricius, 1777)
   (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Cryptocephalinae: Fulcidacini).
AU Shin, Chulwoo (shinio@ku.edu) 
   Jin, Helen
   Chaboo, Caroline S.
SO Journal of the Kansas Entomological Society
VL 85
IS 2
PS 116-134
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Neochlamisus gibbosus (Fabricius) is a common leaf beetle in eastern and
   central North America (Karren, 1972). We provide detailed illustrated
   descriptions of each life stage based on field studies of a population
   on its host plant, Rubus laudatus Berger (Rosaceae), in Kansas, U.S.A.
   We found some previous diagnostic characters and some new ones can
   diagnose the species. We report two hymenopteran parasitoids, Conura sp.
   (Chalcididae) and Testrastichus sp. (Eulophidae), and one unidentified
   mite species on the juvenile defensive fecal case. Chemical analysis of
   the fecal case and host plant found little overlap in chemicals,
   suggesting that the beetles are manufacturing their own chemicals.
C1 Shin, Chulwoo; Univ Kansas, Museum Nat Hist, 1501 Crestline Dr,Suite
   140, Lawrence, KS, 66049, USA, USA.
EM shinio@ku.edu

   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

   [Kansas /  / biology].

AB A new species of Miocene crane fly, Tipula paleopannonia, new species,
   is described and figured from a well preserved forewing. The specimen
   derives from the Paldau Formation (Early Pannonian, ca. 11.3 Ma) and is
   the first new species of Tipula described from the Miocene of Europe

TI A New Species of Ibaliid Wasp in Baltic Amber (Hymenoptera: Ibaliidae).
AU Engel, Michael S. (msengel@ku.edu) 
   Liu, Zhiwei
SO Journal of the Kansas Entomological Society
VL 85
IS 2
PS 164-168
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 5
AB A second species of ibaliid wasp (Cynipoidea: Ibaliidae) from Baltic
   amber is described and figured and represents the first record of the
   genus Ibalia Latreille from the Eocene. Ibalia (Ibalia) electra Engel
   and Liu, new species is described on the basis of a single individual
   preserved in middle Eocene (Lutetian) Baltic amber and exhibits typical
   features and synapomorphies of the genus Ibalia, subgenus Ibalia. The
   species is distinguished from its congeners.

PT J
AN ZOOR14902007902
DT Article
TI Seasonal study of aquatic invertebrates in five sets of latitudinally
   separated gnammas in southern Western Australia.
AU Timms, B.V. (brian.timms@unsw.edu.au) 
SO Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia
VL 95
IS 1
PS 13-28
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Gnammas (i.e. rock pools) are characteristic habitats on granitic
   inselbergs in southern Western Australia and, though their basic
   limnology is known, much remains to be learnt on the distribution
   patterns and seasonality of their fauna. In this study 10 pools on five
   inselbergs (Mt Madden, Hyden Rock, Yanneymooning Rock, Bullamanya Rock
   and Walga Rock) across a 700 km latitudinal climatic gradient were
   studied during the flooded period from May to October 2010.
   Seventy-three taxa inhabited the five rocks and showed declining species
   richness from south to north promoted by decreasing hydroperiod and
   reliability to the north. Passively dispersing crustaceans dominated
   with 47% of taxa, and almost all of the most abundant species, while 41%
   of taxa were seasonal colonising insects. Many pools had 25-30
   invertebrate species each, far more than rock pools elsewhere in
   Australia and overseas. Most of the dominant species were widespread,
   more localised taxa included cyclopoids and the snail Glyptophysa sp. in
   the south and the notostracan Triops n. sp. in the north. Regional
   endemism and specialisation to live in gnammas was high as a consequence
   of past climatic changes linked with the role of these pools as refuges.
   Most of the dominant species were filter feeders on algae and
   allochthonous and autochthonous organic matter and the dominant
   predators were planarians and beetle larvae. Most species peaked in
   abundance in August and September, with large branchiopods (mainly the
   anostracan Branchinella longirostris) peaking before cladocerans and
   with ostracods last. Active dispersers included hemipterans,
   coleopterans and dipterans; almost all were widespread opportunists, but
   at least one Paroster beetle species was a gnamma specialist.
   Chironomids were dominated by gnamma specialists Paraborniella tonneri
   and Allotrissocladius sp 1 which survive the dry summer in situ as
   cryptobiotic 4th instars and emerge soon after the ponds first fill, and
   by the temporary pond specialist Chironomus tepperi which invaded from
   elsewhere when the ponds fill. Stones in the gnammas were important for
   at least two species: Triops n.sp uses them to hide from predators and
   the snail Glyptophysa aestivates underneath them. Succession in these
   pools was best explained by the tolerance model in which each taxon
   developed at its own pace, largely unaffected by other taxa.
C1 Timms, B.V.; Univ New S Wales, Australian Wetland & Rivers Ctr, Sydney,
   NSW, 2052, Australia, Australia.
EM brian.timms@unsw.edu.au
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0035-922X
BD Ecology; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lentic water; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Invertebrata [Community structure / Community dynamics / ] [Freshwater
   habitat / Gnammas / ] [Temporary water /  / ] [Western Australia / South
   / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia
OR Invertebrata (Animalia). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14902007902
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14902007904
DT Article
TI Three decades of cetacean strandings in Western Australia: 1981 to 2010.
AU Groom, C.J.
   Coughran, D.K. (christine.groom@dec.wa.gov.au) 
SO Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia
VL 95
IS 1
PS 63-76
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Western Australia has an extensive coastline that provides a range of
   marine habitats for cetaceans. This paper constitutes the first
   comprehensive review of cetacean strandings in the region. From 1981 to
   2010, stranding events were reported to the Western Australian
   Department of Environment and Conservation and recorded in the Western
   Australian Cetacean Stranding Database. During this period a total of
   732 cetacean stranding events have been recorded, involving 34 species
   and 1753 individuals. Bottlenose dolphins (Tursiops sp.) were involved
   in the most stranding events (n = 330), while long-finned pilot whales
   (Globicephala melas) accounted for the largest number of individuals (n
   = 446 individuals involved in 22 stranding events). The southwest of the
   State is the region with the greatest number of reported stranding
   events. Sixty percent of stranded individuals were found alive. Over 70%
   of stranded cetaceans found alive were returned to deeper water.
C1 Coughran, D.K.; Dept Environm & Conservat, Nat Protect Branch, Locked
   Bag 104, Bentley Delivery Ctr, WA, 6983, Australia, Australia.
EM christine.groom@dec.wa.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 0035-922X
BD Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Cetacea [South Indian Ocean / Australia, Western Australia / Stranding
   records] [South Pacific /  / ]. 
TN Cetaceans; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia
OR Cetacea (Mammalia). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14902007904
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14901005209
DT Article
TI Endoparasites (helminths and coccidians) in the hedgehogs Atelerix
   algirus and Paraechinus aethiopicus from Algeria.
AU Khaldi, Mourad (mou_khadz@yahoo.fr) 
   Torres, Jordi
   Samso, Berta
   Miquel, Jordi
   Biche, Mohamed
   Benyettou, Meryam
   Barech, Ghania
   Benelkadi, Hadj Aissa
   Ribas, Alexis
SO African Zoology
VL 47
IS 1
PS 48-54
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 30
AB The study of endoparasites (helminths and coccidians) in the Algerian
   (Atelerix algirus) and desert (Paraechinus aethiopicus) hedgehogs was
   performed between July 2008 and October 2009. The helminth species found
   included two cestodes, Mathevotaenia erinacei (Anoplocephalidae) and an
   unidentified cestode larva in the mesentery, eight species of nematodes:
   Aonchotheca erinacei (Trichuridae) in the intestine, spirurids
   (Spiruridae) in the intestine, Crenosoma striatum (Crenosomatidae) in
   the lungs, Gongylonema mucronatum (Gongylonematidae) in the oesophagus,
   Physaloptera clausa (Physalopteridae) in the stomach, Physaloptera sp.
   larvae (Physalopteridae) in the mesentery, Pterygodermatites plagiostoma
   (Rictulariidae) in the stomach, Spirura rytipleurites seurati
   (Spiruridae) in the intestine; and two acanthocephalans, Moniliformis
   moniliformis (Moniliformidae) in the intestine and larvae of an unknown
   acanthocephalan species in the mesentery. The general prevalence was
   high in both hosts, 92% in Atelerix algirus and 94.12% in Paraechinus
   aethiopicus. Physaloptera clausa was the most prevalent species (64.0%
   in Atelerix algirus and 64.7% in Paraechinus aethiopicus).
   Polyparasitism of helminths was 68% in Atelerix algirus and 52.9% in
   Paraechinus aethiopicus. Two coccidian species were detected in both
   hedgehogs, Isospora sp. and Eimeria sp. We provide the first complete
   parasitological data from Africa for these two hedgehogs.
C1 Khaldi, Mourad; Laboratory of Ecology, Department of Biology, Faculty of
   Science, University Pole ofM'sila, 28000, Algeria, Algeria.
EM mou_khadz@yahoo.fr
RI Khaldi, Mourad/AAJ-4155-2020; Miquel, Jordi/J-7186-2017; Ghania,
   Barech/AAJ-8536-2020; ENSA - NHSA, Algiers/AAF-1768-2019; Torres,
   Jordi/AAA-4315-2019; Ribas, Alexis/K-4201-2017
OI Khaldi, Mourad/0000-0002-4914-9143; Miquel, Jordi/0000-0003-1132-3772;
   Ghania, Barech/0000-0002-7179-929X; Ribas, Alexis/0000-0002-1256-3316
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1562-7020
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Africa
DE Acanthocephala; Cestoda; Eimeria; Isospora; Nematoda [Mammalian hosts /
   Atelerix algirus / New record; prevalence] [ / Paraechinus aethiopicus /

   /  / ] [Protozoan parasites / Eimeria / ] [ / Isospora / ] [Algeria /

TI Synetocephalus penrosei Gilbert & Clark (Chrysomelidae: Galerucinae:
   Luperini), a new species from California, USA.
AU Gilbert, Arthur J. (agilbert@cdfa.ca.gov) 
   Clark, Shawn M.
SO Pan-Pacific Entomologist
VL 88
IS 2
PS 122-129
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Synetocephalus penrosei sp. nov. from Monterey County, California,
   U.S.A., is described and illustrated. Comparisons are made with the two
   most similar species, S. bivittatus (LeConte 1859) and S. diegensis
   (Blake 1942). Adults of S. penrosei are associated with Adenostoma
   fasciculatum Hook&Arn. (Rosaceae) during the spring months when plants
   are in bloom.

DT Article
TI Hybopteroides, a new genus in the Cryptobatida group of subtribe Agrina,
   with three new species and notes on their way of life (Insecta:
   Coleoptera, Carabidae, Lebiini).
AU Erwin, Terry L. (erwint@si.edu) 
   Ball, George E.
SO Pan-Pacific Entomologist
VL 88
IS 2
PS 188-201
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB Hybopteroides gen. nov., with three new species in the Cryptobatida
   group of subtribe Agrina, Lebiini, living in the lowland rain forest
   canopy of Ecuador and Peru are diagnosed, described and illustrated. The
   new genus is likely the adelphotaxon of Hyboptera Chaudoir 1872 +
   Thoasia Liebke 1939. Hybopteroides biolat sp. nov., the type species, is
   now known from the Rio Manu watershed in Peru; Hybopteroides karolynae
   sp. nov. is now known from the Rio Tambopata watershed in Peru; and
   Hybopteroides penrosei sp. nov. is now known from the upper and mid Rio
   Napo watershed in Ecuador. The species of this new genus are known from
   insecticidal fogging collections from the rainforest canopy and upper
   understory and from two specimens collected by E. S. Ross at his
   ecotourism lodge at Alinahui, Ecuador, found in his live embiid
   colonies.

TI A new species of sap beetle (Coleoptera: Nitidulidae) from Baja
   California Sur, Mexico, with a review of the genus Lobiopa Erichson.
AU Cline, Andrew R. (andrew.cline@cdfa.ca.gov) 
   Kinnee, Scott A.
SO Pan-Pacific Entomologist
VL 88
IS 2
PS 202-211
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new sap beetle species, Lobiopa penrosei Cline&Kinnee sp. nov., is
   described from Baja California Sur, Mexico. Habitus and genitalia images
   are provided. Major characters distinguishing L. penrosei include:
   dorsal surface setation consisting of all light colored thin and
   spatulate/subclavate setae with no dark to piceous setae present;
   spatulate/subclavate setae straight/erect not curved; and internal sac
   sclerites of male genitalia with a paired basal field of spines as well
   as ejaculatory rods with constricted bases. A review of Lobiopa Erichson
   is given, including biological notes on some of the inclusive members as
   well as a checklist of all described species.

TI Penroseius lienosus, a new monotypic genus of Coraebini from Madagascar

SO Pan-Pacific Entomologist

LA English

AB A new monotypic genus of Madagascan Coraebini, Peuroseius, is proposed
   for a new species. Peuroseius lienosus in memory of Richard L. Penrose.
   The new genus is compared to other putative relatives from the
   Madagascan fauna and illustrated in five figures on one plate.

PT J
AN ZOOR14901000761
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A MOLECULAR STUDY OF THE GENUS AGAMA (SQUAMATA: AGAMIDAE) IN WEST
   AFRICA, WITH DESCRIPTION OF TWO NEW SPECIES AND A REVIEW OF THE
   TAXONOMY, GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION, AND ECOLOGY OF CURRENTLY RECOGNIZED
   SPECIES.
AU Mediannikov, Oleg
   Trape, Sebastien
   Trape, Jean-Francois (jean-francois.trape@ird.fr) 
SO Russian Journal of Herpetology
VL 19
IS 2
PS 115-142
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB We conducted field studies in 15 West African countries and collected
   one thousand specimens of lizards of the genus Agama. Based on these
   collections, literature, molecular analysis of selected specimens, and
   examination of Linnean type-specimens of A. agama, we review the
   phylogeny, taxonomy, geographic distribution and ecology of the West
   African species of the genus Agama. Seventeen different species are
   recognized in the genus Agama in West Africa, northern Cameroon and
   Chad: A. africana, A. agama, A. boensis, A. boueti, A. boulengeri, A.
   castroviejoi, A. cristata, A. doriae benueensis, A. gracilimembris, A.
   insularis, A. lebretoni, A. paragama, A. sankaranica, A. weidholzi, and
   three new species. We design a lectotype for A. agama (Linnaeus, 1758)
   and attribute to A. wagneri, sp. nov., the populations from northern and
   central Cameroon of the A. agama complex. Agama parafricana, sp. nov.,
   is described from wet savanna areas of Togo and Benin. Agama sylvanus
   from southern Ghana is a junior synonym of A. africana. Agama cf.
   impalearis from northern Niger and Mali corresponds to an nondescribed
   species. Agama boensis is resurrected from the synonymy of A.
   sankaranica. According to biogeographic areas, four species are
   Sahelian, seven species are Sudanian, four species are Guinean, and two
   species are ubiquitous.
C1 Trape, Jean-Francois; Inst Rech Dev, UMR URMITE, BP 1386, Dakar,
   Senegal, Senegal.
EM jean-francois.trape@ird.fr
RI Mediannikov, Oleg/H-4018-2015
OI Mediannikov, Oleg/0000-0001-6039-2008

   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1026-2296

   Evolution; Variation; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A NEW SPECIES OF PSEUDOTRAPELUS (AGAMIDAE, SAURIA) FROM AQABA, SOUTHERN
   JORDAN.
AU Melnikov, Daniel (azemiops@zin.ru) 
   Nazarov, Roman
   Ananjeva, Natalia
   Disi, Ahmad
SO Russian Journal of Herpetology
VL 19
IS 2
PS 143-154
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Pseudotrapelus from Aqaba, southern Jordan is
   described. It differs from P. sinaitus in four well developed separated
   preanal pores in males, 3rd toe much longer than 4th and 16% incorrect
   p-distance (COI). Taxonomic relationships between Arabian Peninsula
   Pseudotrapelus need further investigations.

TI MISCELLANEA ACCRODONTIA: NOTES ON NOMENCLATURE, TAXONOMY AND
   DISTRIBUTION.
AU Wagner, Philipp (philipp.wagner.zfmk@uni-bonn.de) 
   Bauer, Aaron M.
   Wilms, Thomas M.
   Barts, Mirko
   Boehme, Wolfgang
SO Russian Journal of Herpetology
VL 19
IS 2
PS 177-189
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This publication includes several contributions usually published as
   short notes. Taxonomic issues of three species-group names of the genus
   Agama Daudin, 1802 are discussed: the proposed name bearing type of
   Agama Aculeata Merrem, 1820 is corrected; Agama namaquensis Werner, 1910
   is identified as synonym of Agama anchietae; and Agama agama mucosoensis
   Hellmich, 1957 is elevated to species rank. Moreover, the first report
   of single introductions of Agama africana and, as additional note, of
   Chamaeleo chamaeleon to Madeira Island (Portugal) is presented.

DT Article
TI Corrections of species of tribe Coenosiini (Diptera: Muscidae).
AU Xue, Wan-qi
   Zhang, Xue-shu
   Du, Jing
SO Shenyang Shifan Daxue Xuebao Ziran Kexue Ban
VL 30
IS 2
SU Sum No 96
PS 293-295
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The tribe Coenosiini has 9 genera in China, among them Coenosia and
   Lispocephala are two bigger ones. The former has 128 species and the
   latter has 48 species. Recently many papers have reported species in
   Coenosiini, even some were embodied by SCI. Because some Chinese
   researchers don't have enough references, specimens or the acquaintance
   of variation between species, it is difficult to avoid the mistakes of
   synonym and homonym in some species of the tribe Coenosiini. During the
   study supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China ( No.
   30870330, 31172139), we find that some species of Coenosia and
   Lispocephala in Leigongshan Landscape ( Diptera) are new synonyms.
   According by external and terminalia features, 20 species have been
   corrected herein, including 8 species of Coenosia and 12 species of
   Lispocephala.
C1 Xue, Wan-qi; Institute of Entomology, Shenyang Normal University,
   Shenyang 110034, China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1673-5862

   Eurasia; Asia

   Muscidae

DT Article
TI Review of Euthera (Diptera: Tachinidae) in North America with the
   description of a new species.
AU O'Hara, James E. (james.ohara@agr.gc.ca) 
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 2
PS 206-215
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Euthera Loew is a small but cosmopolitan genus of Tachinidae with
   distinctive smoky black cross bands on the wings. There are three
   described species in North America, Euthera bicolor Coquillett, Euthera
   setifacies Brooks, and Euthera tentatrix Loew. A new species from
   California and New Mexico is described as Euthera woodi sp. nov. in
   honour of dipterist D. Monty Wood. A key and digital images are provided
   for the identification of the four species, and the three previously
   described species are diagnosed. Oebalus mexicana (Sailer) and Nezara
   viridula (L.) (Heteroptera: Pentatomidae) are new host records for E.
   bicolor and E. tentatrix, respectively.

   960 Carling Ave, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.

DT Article
TI Review of New World Sericomyia (Diptera: Syrphidae), including
   description of a new species.
AU Skevington, Jeffrey H. (jeffrey.skevington@agr.gc.ca) 
   Thompson, F. Christian
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 2
PS 216-247
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB The 19 New World species of Sericomyia Meigen are reviewed, including
   one species new to North America (Sericomyia jakutica (Stackelberg)) and
   one previously undescribed species (Sericomyia vockerothi Skevington sp.
   nov. from Alberta, Minnesota, Northwest Territories, Quebec, and Yukon
   Territory). Mallota powelli Nayar and Cole is recognized as a junior
   synonym of Sericomyia flagrans (Osten Sacken). A description and
   illustrations of S. vockerothi and an illustrated key to New World
   Sericomyia are presented. DNA barcode data are presented for 14 New
   World species and a cytochrome oxidase subunit I gene tree is presented
   and discussed. Genetic evidence supports the contention that the
   subgenera of Sericomyia are not monophyletic. Arctophila Schiner and
   Conosyprhus Frey are thus proposed as junior synonyms of Sericomyia.
C1 Skevington, Jeffrey H.; Agr & Agri Food Canada, Canadian Natl Collect
   Insects Arachnids & Nematod, 960 Carling Ave, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0C6,
   Canada, Canada.
EM jeffrey.skevington@agr.gc.ca

SN 0008-347X

   Key; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America;
   Canada; USA

PT J
AN ZOOR14812076904
DT Article
TI New species of Gymnocarena (Diptera: Tephritidae) from eastern North
   America and Guatemala, and the redescription of G. mississippiensis.
AU Sutton, Bruce D. (suttonb@doacs.state.fl.us) 
   Steck, Gary J.
   Norrbom, Allen L.
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 2
PS 248-265
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB We describe three new species of fruit flies (Tephritidae: Tephritinae)
   (Gymnocarena defoei sp. nov. and Gymnocarena norrbomi sp. nov., from
   eastern North America and Gymnocarena monzoni sp. nov. from Guatemala)
   and redescribe Gymnocarena mississippiensis Norrbom. Gymnocarena monzoni
   is the first Gymnocarena species to be recorded from Guatemala. This
   brings the total number of named species in this genus to 19. New larval
   host plant (Asteraceae) records for Gymnocarena include Verbesina
   helianthoides Michx. for G. mississippiensis and G. norrbomi, Verbesina
   alternifolia (L.) Britton ex Kearney for G. norrbomi, and Viguiera
   cordata (Hook. and Arn.) D'Arcy for G. monzoni. The latter represents
   the first record for Gymnocarena in Viguiera Kunth. Gymnocarena larvae
   were also recorded from Verbesina virginica L. but not identified to
   species. A revised key to the known species of Gymnocarena and
   additional information on larval host plants and biology are provided.
C1 Sutton, Bruce D.; Florida Dept Agr & Consumer Serv, Bur Entomol Nematol
   & Plant Pathol, POB 147100, Gainesville, FL 32614, USA, USA.
EM suttonb@doacs.state.fl.us

SN 0008-347X

   Neotropical region; North America; USA; Central America

TI A new Asio-Nearctic subgenus of Rhamphomyia (Diptera: Empididae:
   Empidinae).
AU Saigusa, Toyohei (toyohei_saigusa@yahoo.co.jp) 
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 2
PS 291-322
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Vockerothempis subgen. nov., a new subgenus of Rhamphomyia, is described
   and includes the following species: Rhamphomyia (Vockerothempis)
   arakawae Matsumura, Rhamphomyia (Vockerothempis) calcarifera Saigusa,
   and Rhamphomyia (Vockerothempis) japonica Frey from Japan, and
   Rhamphomyia (Vockerothempis) umbrosa Loew, Rhamphomyia (Vockerothempis)
   brevisetosa sp. nov., Rhamphomyia (Vockerothempis) chillcottiana sp.
   nov., and Rhamphomyia (Vockerothempis) fortisetosa sp. nov. from North
   America. Zoogeography, phylogenetic relationships within Vockerothempis
   and subgeneric classification of Rhamphomyia are discussed.

DT Article
TI The Nearctic species of Telmaturgus (Diptera: Dolichopodidae).
AU Runyon, Justin B. (jrunyon@montana.edu) 
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 2
PS 337-347
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The sympycnine genus Telmaturgus Mik is reviewed for the Nearctic
   region, and includes three species: Telmaturgus parvus (Van Duzee),
   Telmaturgus robinsoni sp. nov., and Telmaturgus vockerothi sp. nov.
   Species of Telmaturgus can be recognized by the reduced number of
   dorsocentral setae (three pairs in Nearctic species) and the projecting
   lower face of females. Examination of the holotype of T. parvus reveals
   that the widespread species previously thought to be T. parvus is T.
   robinsoni. A key to species and comments on the taxonomic history and
   ecology of the genus are provided.
C1 Runyon, Justin B.; USDA Forest Serv, Rocky Mt Res Stn, 1648 S 7th Ave,
   Bozeman, MT 59717, USA, USA.
EM jrunyon@montana.edu
OI Runyon, Justin B./0000-0002-0271-0511
SC Zoology
SN 0008-347X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Nearctic region; North America; Canada; USA

TI Helina richardi (Diptera: Muscidae), a remarkable new species from the
   Mediterranean subregion.
AU Pont, Adrian C. (pont.muscidae@btinternet.com) 
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 2
PS 348-352
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Helina richardi sp. nov. is described from Morocco and Spain. The
   presence of setulae at the base of vein R4+5 suggests placement in
   Mydaea Robineau-Desvoidy but other characters and the structure of the
   female ovipositor indicate that it is otherwise a typical species of
   Helina Robineau-Desvoidy.

PT J
AN ZOOR14812076026
DT Article
TI THE FIRST SUBTERRANEAN FRESHWATER PLANARIANS FROM NORTH AFRICA, WITH AN
   ANALYSIS OF ADENODACTYL STRUCTURE IN THE GENUS DENDROCOELUM
   (PLATYHELMINTHES, TRICLADIDA, DENDROCOELIDAE).
AU Harrath, Abdul Halim (halim.harrath@laposte.net) 
   Sluys, Ronald
   Ghlala, Adnen
   Alwasel, Saleh
SO Journal of Cave and Karst Studies
VL 74
IS 1
PS 48-57
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The paper describes the first species of freshwater planarians collected
   from subterranean localities in northern Africa, represented by three
   new species of Dendrocoelum Orsted, 1844 from Tunisian springs. Each of
   the new species possesses a well-developed adenodactyl, resembling
   similar structures in other species of Dendrocoelum, notably those from
   southeastern Europe. Comparative studies revealed previously unreported
   details and variability in the anatomy of these structures, particularly
   in the composition of the musculature. An account of this variability is
   provided, and it is argued that the anatomical structure of adenodactyls
   may provide useful taxonomic information.
C1 Harrath, Abdul Halim; King Saud Univ, Coll Sci, POB 2455, Riyadh 11451,
   Saudi Arabia, Saudi Arabia.
EM halim.harrath@laposte.net
RI Harrath, Abdel Halim/K-2166-2014; Alwasel, Saleh/AAD-4023-2019

   Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF NICOLETIIDAE (INSECTA: ZYGENTOMA) FROM KARTCHNER
   CAVERNS STATE PARK, ARIZONA.
AU Espinasa, Luis (luis.espinasa@marist.edu) 
   Pape, Robert B.
   Henneberry, Alanna
   Kinnear, Christopher
SO Journal of Cave and Karst Studies
VL 74
IS 1
PS 82-89
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Spekonycta anachoretes, n. sp., is described and differentiated from S.
   ozarkensis, known from caves in the Ozark Plateau. The new species was
   collected from Kartchner Caverns State Park in Arizona. Morphology and
   preliminary analyses using 16S rRNA corroborate that Speleonycta may be
   related to Texoreddellia, another nicoletiid genus from caves of Texas
   and northern Mexico. General information regarding its conservation
   status within the commercial cave is provided.

   12601, USA, USA.
EM luis.espinasa@marist.edu

   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

   taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogenetic
   relationships / ] [North America /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14812078242
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Survival strategies and cost-benefit-balances of the predatory insect
   larva (Euroleon nostras Fourcroy, Myrmeleontidae).
FT Ueberlebensstrategien and Kosten-Nutzen-Bilanzen einer raeuberischen
   Insektenlarve (Euroleon nostras Fourcroy, Myrmeleontidae).
AU Meissner, Karl (meissner.karl@t-online.de) 
   Feike, Martin
   Pires, Cristiano
   Stetzkowski, Jan
SO Mitteilungen der Deutschen Gesellschaft fuer Allgemeine und Angewandte
   Entomologie
VL 18
PS 591-599
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 15
AB We are investigating the behavior strategies and the evolutionary
   adaptations and we are also determining the quantitative parameters for
   cost-benefit-balance in the antlions Euroleon nostras, Myrmeleon
   formicarius and M. bore. Antlions live in sand mostly in deserts and
   semideserts or in zones of glacial origin and in coastal dunes. The
   probability of prey capture is increased to about 200 species as they
   construct pit. However: larvae that construct traps remain essentially
   	inactive at the ambush-site and wait for active prey. Larvae of E.
   nostras need a very short time (approximately 25 min) for constructing a
   pitfall the	trap in relation to the time at resting metabolic rate.
   Therefore, the costs of the pit construction (volume, mass weight,
   energy) are of minor importance in relation to prey. The linear
   accession of pit traps diameter (benefit of prey catch) exponentially
   corresponds to ascent of costs. 	Although ants live in aggregations and
   use paths, the capture rate of an antlion remains very low, because prey
   is arriving seldom and in unpredictable intervals. In one of the survey
   habitats with 48 pits the antlions captured only 17 prey in 4 days. Each
   pit results in a capture rate of 1 prey/11.3 d. Capturing rates of 1
   prey/3.3 d and 1 prey/24.0 d respectively were reported for 2 other
   areas at the same time. The body masses of the first, second and third
   larval stages varied from 39 to 50 % of the means (2.71[plus or
   minus]1.22 mg, n = 34; 15.20[plus or minus]7.57 mg, n = 34; 57.9[plus or
   minus]22.22 mg, n = 29). For all the larvae instars the mean extraction
   rate of living mass of an ant was 55 to 70% of the live weight. The
   surviving of hunger periods up to more then 4 months of the first and
   second larval instars and up to 8 months in case of the third instar is
   part of evolution-conditioned adjustments. An antlion pit is built
   within 25 min activity time. The function time of the pit was about
   23:35 h within a 24 h-day before beginning of a pit enlargement activity
   phase. The pit construction requires minimum energetic costs, whereas
   the gain obtained by capturing a prey amounts to 20500 mJ per single
   prey. The calculation is based on the energy content of of investigated
   food and the carbon content of the prey Formica spec. Our results
   indicate that an the	antlion with a wet weight (ww) of 22.6 mg releases
   0.62 [mu]g C*h-' (1.3 J*g-' ww *h-') within periods of inactivity and
   5.28 [mu]g C*h-' (11.6 J*g' ww*h-') during construction of a pit (rest :
   1: 8,5). Considering an estimated extraction efficiency of 36.5 % at
   feeding on Formica, one prey of this kind compensates the loss of carbon
   or energy originated by the resting metabolic rate of the larvae for 25
   days.
C1 Meissner, Karl; Institut fuer Biowissenschaften, Albert-Einstein-Str. 3,
   18051 Rostock, Germany, Germany.
EM meissner.karl@t-online.de
SC Entomology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Physiology;
   Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0344-9084
BD Whole animal physiology; Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Feeding behaviour;
   Ecology; Population dynamics; Predators
DE Arthropoda; Formica rufa [Insect predators / Euroleon nostras
   (Neuroptera) / Predator prey relationships; predator trapping strategy].
   
   Euroleon nostras [Metabolic rate /  / arthropod prey; predator prey
   relationships] [Prey / Arthropoda / ] [Insect prey / Formica rufa
   (Hymenoptera) / ] [Energy budget / Pitfall trap construction energetics
   / ] [Foraging / Prey capture / ] [Survival / Survival strategies / ]
   [Animal constructions /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae, Neuroptera
OR Arthropoda (Animalia): [Prey]. 
   Formica rufa (Formicidae): [Prey]. 
   Euroleon nostras (Neuroptera): [Predator].

AB The aim of this work is to restore the Chalcoidea at the level of genus
   from the morphological study of the larvae and imagos of some species

   studies. At this opportunity a new species is described.

DT Article
TI Presence of aphaenopsian troglobitic Trechini in tropical area in the
   Annamitic range at the South of the 18th parallel (Coleoptera,
   Caraboidea, Trechidae).
FT Presence de Trechini cavernicoles aphenopsiens en zone tropicale dans la
   chaine Annamitique, au sud du 18e parallele (Coleoptera, Caraboidea,
   Trechidae)
AU Deuve, Thierry
SO Nouvelle Revue d'Entomologie
VL 28
IS 2
PS 183-190
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Description and illustration of a new genus, Lanxangaphaenops n. gen.,
   for the first 'aphaenopsian' troglobitic trechine (Coleoptera,
   Caraboidea, Trechidae) dwelling in tropical caves at the south of the
   18th parallel of latitude, in the Annamitic range of Laos and Vietnam.
   One new species and two new subspecies (L. louisi n. sp., L. louisi
   leukensis n. subsp., L. louisi annamensis n. subsp.) are described in
   this new genus which is closely allied to the genera Sinaphaenops Ueno
   et Wang, 1991, from southern China, and Laosaphaenops Deuve, 2000, from
   central Laos.

TI A new species of Callistethus from Mexico (Coleoptera, Melolonthidae,
   Rutelinae).
AU Ramirez-Ponce, Andres (miguel.moron@inecol.edu.mx) 
   Moron, Miguel Angel
SO Revista Brasileira de Entomologia
VL 56
IS 2
PS 142-146
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of Callistethus from Mexico (Coleoptera, Melolonthidae,
   Rutclinae). Callistethus tlapanecus, a new species collected in pine
   forest located at 2160 meters of altitude in eastern mountains of the
   state of Guerrero, Mexico is described. The morphological characters
   that distinguish it from other Mexican and Central American species are
   discussed. The diagnostic characters are illustrated, and a key to
   Mexican species of Callistethus is also included.

DT Article
TI Veliidae (Insecta, Heteroptera, Gerromorpha) from southeastern Brazil:
   three new species from Rio de Janeiro State, a new species group for
   Neotropical Rhagovelia Mayr, and notes on distribution and synonymy.
AU Figueiredo Moreira, Felipe Ferraz (felipento@hotmail.com) 
   Barbosa, Julianna Freires
   Inacio Ribeiro, Jose Ricardo
SO Revista Brasileira de Entomologia
VL 56
IS 2
PS 147-158
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Veliidae (Insecta, Heteroptera, Gerromorpha) from southeastern Brazil:
   three new species from Rio de Janeiro State, a new species group for
   Neotropical Rhagovelia Mayr, and notes on distribution and synonymy.
   Microvelia nelsoni sp. nov., M. takiyae sp. nov., and Rhagovelia
   mangaratiba sp. nov. are described. Rhagovelia scitula and R. whitei are
   transferred from the robusta group to the new whitei group. Rhagovelia
   denticulata is synonymized under R. scitula. Microvelia longipes,
   Oiovelia brasiliensis, Rhagovelia sooretama, R. trianguloides, R.
   vaniniae, and Stridulivelia quadrispinosa are recorded for the first
   time from Rio de Janeiro State. Additional new municipality records in
   Rio de Janeiro State are presented for Microvelia braziliensis, M.
   ioana, M. mimula, M. pulchella, Paravelia basalis, P.itatiayana,
   Rhagovelia accedens, R. agra, R. aiuruoca, R. elegans, R. hambletoni, R.
   henryi, R. itatiaiana, R. lucida, R. macta, R. modesta, R. novana, R.
   scitula, R. tenuipes, R. tijuca, R. triangula, and R. zeta. Corrections
   are presented for the previously published distributions of Rhagovelia
   aiuruoca, R. lucida, R. macta, and R. triangula.
C1 Figueiredo Moreira, Felipe Ferraz; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Inst Biol,
   Ave Brigadeiro Trompowski S-N,Bloco A,Sala 107,Ca, Rio De Janeiro, RJ,
   BR-21941-971, Brazil, Brazil.
EM felipento@hotmail.com

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

PT J

DT Article
TI A new species of Sigara Fabricius (Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Corixidae)
   and redescription of the species of the genus in the state of the record
   in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
FT Uma nova especie de Sigara Fabricius (Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Corixidae)
   e redescricao das especies do genero corn registro no Estado do Rio
   Grande do Sul, Brasil.
AU Bernardo, Larissa P.
   Ribeiro, Jose Ricardo I. (joseribeiro@unipampa.edu.br) 
   Stenert, Cristina
   Maltchik, Leonardo
SO Revista Brasileira de Entomologia
VL 56
IS 2
PS 159-182
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of Sigara Fabricius (Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Corixidae)
   and redescription of the species recorded in the State of Rio Grande do
   Sul, Brazil. Water boatmen (Corixidae) constitute the largest group of
   water bugs, with well over 40 species occurring in Brazil. Most of the
   species of Sigara are known from the Neotropics, and II of them have
   been reported in Brazil. Little is known about the distribution and
   taxonomy of Sigara species of Rio Grande do Sul. The following seven
   species are recorded and redescribed: Sigara (Thopocorixa)chrostowskii,
   S. (T)denseconscripta S. (T.) dita, S. (T.) hungerfordi, S. (T.)
   platensis, S. (T) schadei, and S. (T) townsendi. Sigara (T) dita, S. (T)
   hungedbrdi, and S. (T) townsendi are newly recorded from this State,
   while S. (T) schadei is recorded for the first time from Brazil. Sigara
   (T) bachmanni, sp. nov. is described from northeastern Rio Grande do
   Sul. This species resembles S. (T)hungerfotzli in having the synthlipsis
   less than 0.9 times the width of an eye, metaxyphus broader than long,
   and the infraocular portion of genae slender, but can be readily
   recognized by the presence of a short hook at apex of right clasper and
   serrations along the margin of its pre-apical portion. A key to the
   species of Sigara occurring in Rio Grande do Sul is provided. Although
   the general aspect of right clasper and the number of pegs of male pala
   as well as its shape have proven useful for species delimitation, S.
   (T)chrostowskii and S. (T) townsendi have shown considerable variation
   in these features and have been redescribed here.
C1 Ribeiro, Jose Ricardo I.; Univ Fed Pampa, Campus Sao Gabriel,Av Antonio
   Trilha 1847, Sao Gabriel, RS, BR-97300-000, Brazil, Brazil.
EM joseribeiro@unipampa.edu.br
RI Ribeiro, Jose Ricardo Inacio I./A-9276-2012; Stenert,
   Cristina/AAD-6860-2020
OI Ribeiro, Jose Ricardo Inacio I./0000-0001-5035-2766; 
SC Zoology
SN 0085-5626
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America

   Sigara (Tropocorixa) schadei [Brazil /  / New record].

   [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 161].

   [Redescription, P. 165]. 
   Sigara (Tropocorixa) denseconscripta - (Breddin 1897) (Corixidae):
   [Redescription, P. 168].

   P. 169; New record].

   [Redescription, P. 171; New record].

   [Redescription, P. 173].

   [Redescription, P. 175; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14811073927
DT Article
TI The first known fossil record of pygmy pipehorses (Teleostei:
   Syngnathidae: Hippocampinae) from the Miocene Coprolitic Horizon,
   Tunjice Hills, Slovenia.
AU Zalohar, Jure (jure.zalohar@guest.arnes.si) 
   Hitij, Tomaz
SO Annales de Paleontologie
VL 98
IS 2
PS 131-151
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB The first known fossil record of pygmy pipehorses is described. The
   fossils were collected in the Middle Miocene (Sarmatian) beds of the
   Coprolitic Horizon in the Tunjice Hills, Slovenia. They belong to a new
   genus and species Hippotropiscis frenki, which was similar to the extant
   representatives of Acentronura, Amphelikturus, Idiotropiscis, and
   Kyonemichthys genera. Hippotropiscis frenki lived among seagrasses and
   macroalgae and probably also on a mud and silt bottom in the temperate
   shallow coastal waters of the western part of the Central Paratethys
   Sea. The high coronet on the head, the ridge system and the high angle
   at which the head is angled ventrad indicate that Hippotropiscis is most
   related to Idiotropiscis and Hippocampus (seahorses) and probably
   separated from the main seahorse lineage later than Idiot ropiscis. (C)
   2012 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Zalohar, Jure; Univ Ljubljana, Fac Nat Sci & Engn, Askerceva 12,
   Ljubljana, SI-1000, Slovenia, Slovenia.
EM jure.zalohar@guest.arnes.si
RI Hitij, Tomaz/A-6278-2009
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0753-3969; 1778-3666
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Hippotropiscis [Miocene /  / New genus]. 
   Hippotropiscis frenki [Slovenia /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Syngnathiformes, Syngnathidae
OR Hippotropiscis (Syngnathidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Hippocampinae,
   Type species Hippotropiscis frenki, p. 137, Miocene; Fossil]. 
   Hippotropiscis frenki (Syngnathidae): [Sp nov, Slovenia, Miocene, P.
   137; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Palaega pisana n. sp. (Crustacea, Isopoda, Cirolanidae) from the
   Pliocene of Orciano Pisano, Pisa (Toscana, central Italy).
AU Pasini, Giovanni (juanaldopasini@itscali.it) 
   Garassino, Alessandro
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 153
IS 1
PS 3-11
PD Aprile 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report a new form of cirolanid ascribed to Palaega pisana n. sp.
   (Crustacea, Isopoda, Cirolanidae) from the Pliocene of Orciano Pisano,
   Pisa (Toscana, Central Italy). This is the second species of Palaega
   Woodward, 1870, reported from the Pliocene of Tuscany and Italy,
   increasing the very sparce palaeontological data on presence and
   distribution of the genus in the Mediterranean Basin during the Late
   Cenozoic.
C1 Pasini, Giovanni; Via Alessandro Volta 16, I-22070 Appiano Gentile
   (Como), Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI First record of cirolanids (Crustacea, Isopoda, Cirolanidae) from the
   Middle Pliocene of Parma and Reggio Emilia Province (Emilia Romagna, N
   Italy).
AU Pasini, Giovanni (juanaldopasini@itscali.it) 
   Garassino, Alessandro
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 153
IS 1
PS 13-20
PD Aprile 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report two new forms of cirolanid isopods ascribed to Palaega sp. and
   P. steatopigia n. sp. (Cirolanidae) from the Middle Pliocene of Campore
   (Salsomaggiore Terme, Parma) and Monticelli di Quattro Castella (Reggio
   Emilia), Emilia Romagna, N Italy. This is the first record of Palaega
   Woodward, 1870, reported from the Middle Pliocene of Emilia Romagna and
   in the paleo-Adriatic Gulf. Palaega steatopigia n. sp. represents the
   third species described in Italy and in the Mediterranean area.

PS 21-26
PD Aprile 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report a new form of cirolanid ascribed to Palaega picena n. sp.
   (Crustacea, Isopoda, Cirolanidae) from the Miocene of Arcevia, Ancona
   (Marche, Central Italy). This is the second species of Palaega Woodward
   1870, reported from the Miocene of Italy, increasing the sparse
   know-ledge and distribution of this genus in the paleo-Mediterranean
   basin.

DT Article
TI Bathypluma pliocenica n. sp. (Decapoda, Brachyura, Retroplumidae) from
   the Zanclean (Early Pliocene) of Volterra (Pisa, Toscana, Italy).
AU Garassino, Alessandro (alessandro.garassino@comune.milano.it) 
   Pasini, Giovanni
   Marini, Federico
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 153
IS 1
PS 63-69
PD Aprile 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report Bathypluma pliocenica n. sp. (Retroplumidae Gill, 1894),
   discovered from the Zanclean (Early Pliocene) clays near Volterra (Pisa,
   Toscana, Central Italy). This discovery is very important because it is
   the first report of Bathypluma in the worldwide fossil record, enlarging
   the knowledge on its distribution and antedating the presence of the
   genus, known only from the Indo-W Pacific area, to the Early Pliocene of
   the paleo-Mediterranean basin.
C1 Garassino, Alessandro; Museo di Storia Naturale, Corso Venezia 55,
   I-20121 Milano, Italy, Italy.

   Tertiary; Neogene

   Mediterranean region / ] [Pliocene /  / ]. 
   Bathypluma pliocenica [Italy /  / new species] [Pliocene /  / ].

TI Rhamphus monzinii, new species from Piedmont.
FT Rhamphus monzinii, nuova specie del Piemonte (Coleoptera Curculionidae).
AU Pesarini, Carlo (carlo.pesarini@commune.milano.it) 
   Diotti, Luciano
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 153
IS 1
PS 111-117
PD Aprile 2012
PY 2012
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB It is here described from Piedmont the new species Rhamphus monzinii,
   related to R. pulicarius and R. oxracanthae, closer to the latter but
   however distinguished from both through the quite different shape of cr;
   genitalia. The new species seems to be allied, like R. pulicarius, to
   Salicaceae and Betulaceae.

PT J

DT Article
TI A coprological survey of protozoan and nematode parasites of
   free-ranging chacma baboons (Papio ursinus) in the southwestern Cape,
   South Africa.
AU Ravasi, Damiana F. (damianaravasi@gmail.com) 
   O'Riain, M. Justin
   Adams, Vera J.
   Appleton, Christopher C.
SO South African Journal of Wildlife Research
VL 42
IS 1
PS 35-44
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 19
AB This study provides data on gastrointestinal parasite infections in the
   geographically isolated and locally fragmented Cape Peninsula baboon
   population and two troops from neighbouring populations in the Western
   Cape Province, South Africa. We obtained data on parasite diversity and
   prevalence from 616 faecal samples collected from over 350 individuals
   in eight troops between July 2006 and May 2008. We processed faecal
   samples using a modified formalin-ether sedimentation technique and
   identified nematode eggs and protozoan cysts. We recovered seven
   nematode genera (Trichuris sp., Oesophagostomum sp., Trichostrongylus
   sp., Physaloptera sp., Ascaris sp., an unidentified hookworm morphotype,
   and an unidentified spirurid) and eight protozoan species (Balantidium
   coil, Entamoeba coil; E. histolytica/dispar, E. chattoni, E. hartmanni,
   lodamoeba butschlii, Endolimax nana and Chilomastix mesnili). The
   nematode and protozoan fauna of the Cape Peninsula baboon population was
   similar to both neighbouring and geographically distinct chacma baboon
   populations in South Africa. Parasite prevalence was variable across
   study sites and seasonality did not appear to have an effect on patterns
   of infection. The finding of the eggs of an ascarid, possibly Ascaris
   sp., in the Cape Peninsula baboon population represents the first report
   of this nematode genus in wild baboons in South Africa.
C1 Ravasi, Damiana F.; Univ Cape Town, Dept Zool, Private Bag X3,
   Rondebosch, ZA-7701, South Africa, South Africa.
EM damianaravasi@gmail.com
OI O'Riain, M. Justin/0000-0001-5233-8327
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0379-4369
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Ascaridae [Mammalian hosts / Papio ursinus / New record] [South Africa /
    / ]. 
   Nematoda; Protozoa [Mammalian hosts / Papio ursinus / Host parasite
   list; prevalence; gastrointestinal parasites] [South Africa / Cape
   Peninsula & Western Cape / ]. 
   Papio ursinus [Nematode parasites /  / Host parasite list; prevalence;
   gastrointestinal parasites] [ / Ascaridae / New record] [Protozoan
   parasites /  / ] [South Africa /  / ] [ / Cape Peninsula & Western Cape
   / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes; Primates; Protozoans;
   Vertebrates

   Nematoda, Protozoa

   Nematoda (Animalia): [Parasite].

   Ascaridae (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record].
