PT J
AN ZOOR14810068249
DT Article
TI DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF THE PELAGIC PROCESSID, PROCESSA PIPPINAE
   WICKSTEN & MENDEZ, 1985 (DECAPODA, CARIDEA, PROCESSIDAE), COLLECTED
   DURING THE TALUD XIV CRUISE IN THE GULF OF CALIFORNIA, MEXICO, AND
   DESCRIPTION OF A NEW GENUS.
AU Hendrickx, Michel E. (michel@ola.icmyl.unam.mx) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 85
IS 4-5
PS 463-472
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The pelagic processid, Processa pippinae Wicksten&Mendez, 1985, has been
   reported previously as an endemic species in the northern Gulf of
   California, Mexico. Additional material collected accidentally in a
   benthic sledge and with a mid-water micronecton net is reported,
   including a series of small-sized specimens (CL 2.2 mm). The shape of
   the laterally compressed rostrum of this species varies considerably
   with size and among adult specimens. Based on several morphological
   characteristics of P pippinae, a new genus, Maryprocessa, is proposed.
   Several unique characteristics separate Maryprocessa new genus from the
   other five genera of Processidae, including the laterally compressed
   rostrum overreaching the cornea, unique among the Processidae, the
   extraordinary long antennal and antennular flagella, the posterior lobe
   on the dorsal margin of the third abdominal somite, and the long, acute
   pair of spines on the posterior margin of the sixth abdominal somite.
C1 Hendrickx, Michel E.; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Lab Invertebrados
   Benton, POB 811, Mazatlan, Sinaloa, 82000, Mexico, Mexico.
EM michel@ola.icmyl.unam.mx
SC Zoology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Maryprocessa pippinae [North Pacific / Mexico, Gulf of California /
   Distribution; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Natantia
OR Maryprocessa (Natantia): [Gen nov, Of family Processidae, Type species
   Processa pippinae Wicksten & Mendez 1985, p. 465]. 
   Maryprocessa pippinae - (Wicksten & Mendez 1985) (Natantia): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Processa, p. 468]. 
   Processa pippinae - Wicksten & Mendez 1985 (Natantia): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Maryprocessa, p. 465].

   Selvagen Islands in the Mid-Atlantic, and collected during the EMPC

TI REVIEW OF THE SHORE-FLY GENUS LIMNELLIA MALLOCH, 1925 (DIPTERA,
   EPHYDRIDAE) OF RUSSIA.

SO Far Eastern Entomologist
VL 246
PS 1-7
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Materials of the genus Limnellia Malloch, 1925 of Russia are revised.
   Two species of the genus, L. quadrata (Fallen, 1813) and L. stenhammari
   (Zetterstedt, 1846), have been previously registered from Russia. The
   new species Limnellia zlobini sp. n. is described from Primorskii krai.
   The new species differs from the congeners by the position of two small
   black spots in the centre of cell R5 of the wing and by the form of
   surstylus. The key to species of Russia is given.

AB The Palaearctic genus Peodes Loew, 1857 (Dolichopodidae: Hydrophorinae,
   Epithalassiini) is reviewed. Till now the genus includes two European
   species, P. forcipatus Loew, 1857 and P. petsamoensis Frey, 1930. Third
   species, P. yeniseiensis Grichanov, sp. n., is described from Siberia
   (Krasnoyarsk Territory). Diagnosis of Peodes and key to species are
   given.

DT Article
TI Morphology and Phylogeny of Scrippsiella trochoidea (Dinophyceae) a
   potentially harmful bloom forming species isolated from the sediments of
   Iran's south coast.
AU Attaran-Fariman, G. (G.Attaran@cmu.ac.ir) 
   Bolch, C.J.S.
SO Iranian Journal of Fisheries Science
VL 11
IS 2
PS 252-270
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 21
AB Phytoplankton cells and resting cysts of the species Scrippsiella
   trochoidea are regular and dominant components of the dinoflagellate
   flora of coastal marine waters and sediments around the world. This
   species is a common harmful bloom forming species in coastal waters. In
   this study, for the first time cyst of S. trochoidea were isolated from
   the sediments of southeast coast of Iran. Five strains from the
   germination of a single cyst belonged to S. Trochoidea. In order to
   confirm identification of the species an excystment and encystment
   experiment, cyst and germinated cell morphology and plate pattern by
   light and electron microscopy (SEM) have been described. The nucleotide
   sequences of two highly diverse regions, the rDNA-ITS 1,2 and 5.8S-rDNA
   have been sequenced for all strains. Homologous sequences from GenBank
   with five Iranian strains were compared to find their phylogenetic
   relationship. Both NJ and MP phylogenetic and morphological analysis
   showed five strains of S. Trochoidea from Iran were clustered with
   previously described S. Trochoidea and Calciodinellum levantinum
   species, and its closest relationship was with Scrippsiella sp. strain
   with a 1.2-1.4% sequence divergence. Results indicate that molecular
   studies of rDNA if combined with morphological cyst and vegetative cells
   could be a valuable approach to identification and taxonomy of
   calciodinelloideae dinoflagellate.
C1 Attaran-Fariman, G.; Chabahar Maritime Univ, Marine Sci Fac, Chabahar,
   Iran, Iran.
EM G.Attaran@cmu.ac.ir
RI Bolch, Christopher J/J-7619-2014
OI Bolch, Christopher J/0000-0001-9047-2391
SC Cell Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1562-2916
BD Cytology; Genetics; Evolution; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian
   Ocean
DE Scrippsiella trochoidea [General cell ultrastructure / Cyst morphology /
   new record] [Molecular genetics / Nucleotide sequences / ] [Phylogeny /
   Phylogenetic relationships / ] [Persian Gulf / Iran / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea,
   Dinoflagellida
OR Scrippsiella trochoidea (Dinoflagellida): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14810070863
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14810067411

DT Article
TI Trichomycterus anhanga, a new species of miniature catfish related to T.
   hasemani and T. johnsoni (Siluriformes: Trichomycteridae) from the
   Amazon basin, Brazil.
AU Dutra, Guilherme M. (guilhermedutr@yahoo.com.br) 
   Wosiacki, Wolmar B.
   de Pinna, Mario C.C.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 225-231
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Trichomycterus anhanga is described from the Amazon basin, northern
   Brazil. The species is diagnosed by the latero-sensory system which is
   restricted to LL1 and LL2, the pectoral fin with two branched rays, the
   absence of pelvic fins and girdle, the reduced jaws and pharyngeal
   dentition, the presence of six to seven interopercular odontodes, the
   absence of a lateral series of spots, the presence of a small dark spot
   on the ventral surface of the mandibular symphysis, the narrow
   comma-shaped palatine, the absence of procurrent rays anterior to the
   dorsal and anal fins, the position of insertion of the first dorsal-fin
   pterygiophore and the presence of a single pair of pleural ribs.
   Trichomycterus anhanga shares with T. hasemani and T. johnsoni a wide
   cranial fontanel which occupies most of the skull roof. Miniaturization
   as well as synapomorphies for the T. hasemani group are discussed.
C1 Dutra, Guilherme M.; Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, Setor Ictiol, Av
   Magalhaes Barata 376,CP 399, Belem, PA, BR-66040170 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM guilhermedutr@yahoo.com.br
RI de pinna, mario c/L-8043-2017; Wosiacki, Wolmar/I-1724-2012
OI Wosiacki, Wolmar/0000-0002-4013-8501
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1679-6225
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biometrics; Skeletal and supporting
   structures; Skeleton; Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America
DE Trichomycterus anhanga [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Trichomycterus hasemani group [Size / Miniaturization / ] [Skull /

DT Article
TI Crenicichla chicha, a new species of pike cichlid (Teleostei: Cichlidae)
   from the rio Papagaio, upper rio Tapajos basin, Mato Grosso, Brazil.
AU Varella, Henrique R. (hrvarella@hotmail.com) 
   Kullander, Sven O.
   Lima, Flavio C.T.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 233-244
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Crenicichla chicha, new species, occurs in clear, fast-running waters
   with rocky substrates in the rio Papagaio and tributaries. It is
   distinguished from all other Crenicichla species by the combination of
   two character states: infraorbitals 3 and 4 co-ossified (vs. separated)
   and 66-75 scales in the row immediately above to that containing the
   lower lateral line (E1 row scales). Crenicichla chicha shares a smooth
   preopercular margin, co-ossification of infraorbitals 3 and 4, and some
   color features with C. hemera from the adjacent rio Aripuana drainage,
   rio Madeira basin. It differs from Crenicichla hemera in more E1 scales
   (6675 vs. 58-65) and presence of a conspicuous black narrow stripe
   running from infraorbital 3 obliquely caudoventrad toward the
   preopercular margin vs. a rounded and faint suborbital marking present
   on infraorbitals 3-4. Examination of the type series and additional
   material from the rio Aripuana confirms that Crenicichla guentheri
   Ploeg, 1991 is a junior subjective synonym of C. hemera Kullander, 1990.
C1 Varella, Henrique R.; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Caixa Postal 42494,
   Sao Paulo, BR-04218970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM hrvarella@hotmail.com
RI Varella, Henrique/M-6383-2015
OI Varella, Henrique/0000-0002-8935-466X
SC Zoology
SN 1679-6225
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Crenicichla chicha [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae
OR Crenicichla chicha (Cichlidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 234]. 
   Crenicichla guentheri - Ploeg 1991 (Cichlidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Crenicichla hemera Kullander 1990, p. 241]. 
   Crenicichla hemera - Kullander 1990 (Cichlidae): [Senior synonym, Of
   Crenicichla guentheri Ploeg 1991, p. 241]. 
DI 10.1590/S1679-62252012000200002

DT Article
TI A new armored catfish species of the genus Hypostomus Lacepede, 1803
   (Siluriformes: Loricariidae) from the upper rio Xingu basin, Brazil.
AU Zawadzki, Claudio H. (chzawadzki@hotmail.com) 
   Birindelli, Jose L.O.
   Lima, Flavio C.T.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 245-253
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB A new armored catfish species of the genus Hypostomus is described from
   the upper rio Xingu basin, Mato Grosso State, Brazil. The new species is
   diagnosed from congeners by having high number of teeth (58 to 101, mean
   77 on premaxilla, and 58 to 105, mean 80 on dentary), dark spots over
   body and fins, and abdomen mostly naked. The new species is known from
   the rapids of the rio Culuene, where it is sympatric with Hypostomus
   faveolus.

DT Article
TI Hemiodus langeanii (Characiformes: Hemiodontidae), a new species from
   rio Amana, rio Maues-Acu drainage, Amazon basin, Brazil.
AU Beltrao, Helio (helio_anjos@yahoo.com.br) 
   Zuanon, Jansen
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 255-262
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Hemiodus langeanii, new species, is described based on 20 specimens
   collected in the rio Amana, a tributary of rio Maues-Acu, rio Amazonas
   drainage, Brazil. The new taxon can be distinguished from its congeners
   by its high body (27.1-35.3%, average 32.3% SL vs. 18.8-28.5% in
   remaining species). The new species also exhibits a large lateral dark
   spot that is equal to, or greater than, the eye diameter (vs. smaller in
   remaining species except for H. microlepis). The lack of conspicuous
   lateral stripe or transverse bands and the low lateral line scales count
   (68-74) distinguish H. langeanii from some similar species in the genus
   (scale counts: 94-123 in H. argenteus, 124-148 in H. microlepis, 86-99
   in H. orthonops and 77-92 in H. parnaguae). Finally, the new species can
   be differentiated from H. unimaculatus (which overlaps in the number of
   lateral line scales) by the higher number of scales between the lateral
   line and the pelvic fin origin (9-10 vs. 4-7, respectively), which are
   similar sized above and below lateral line (vs. scales larger bellow the
   lateral line in H. unimaculatus).
C1 Beltrao, Helio; UEA, Av Djalma Batista 3578, Flores Manaus, AM, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM helio_anjos@yahoo.com.br
RI Beltrao, Helio/P-4638-2017
OI Beltrao, Helio/0000-0002-5414-5518
SC Zoology
SN 1679-6225
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Hemiodus langeanii [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Characiformes, Hemiodontidae
OR Hemiodus langeanii (Hemiodontidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 256].

DT Article
TI The cascudos of the genus Hypostomus Lacepede (Ostariophysi:
   Loricariidae) from the rio Iguacu basin.
AU Garavello, Julio Cesar (garavelo@ufscar.br) 
   Britski, Heraldo Antonio
   Zawadzki, Claudio Henrique
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 263-283
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 19
AB We reviewed several large collections of the genus Hypostomus from the
   rio Iguacu basin summing up to 793 specimens mainly from the Laboratorio
   de Ictiologia do Departamento de Ecologia e Biologia Evolutiva from
   Universidade Federal de Sao Carlos, from fish collection of Nucleo de
   Pesquisas em Limnologia, Ictiologia e Aquicultura da Universidade
   Estadual de Maringa, and from the Museu de Historia Natural do Capao da
   Imbuia. Hypostomus albopunctatus, H. commersoni, H. derbyi, and H.
   myersi are redescribed and Hypostomus nigropunctatus is described as a
   new species. A practical key for identification of Hypostomus species
   from the rio Iguacu is also provided.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision of the Rineloricaria species (Siluriformes:
   Loricariidae) from the Paraguay River basin.
AU Vera-Alcaraz, Hector S. (hsveraalcaraz@gmail.com) 
   Pavanelli, Carla S.
   Zawadzki, Claudio H.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 285-311
PD April-June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Species of the genus Rineloricaria from the Paraguay River basin were
   revised, the following species and geographic distributional patterns
   were found: R. aurata, Paraguay River basin in Brazil and Paraguay, rio
   Guapore in Brazil; R. cacerensis, Paraguay River near Caceres in Brazil;
   R. lanceolata, Paraguay River basin in Brazil and Paraguay, Guapore,
   Ji-Parana, Purus, Solimoes, and Araguaia rivers in Brazil, Maranon and
   Madre de Dios rivers in Peru; R. parva, Paraguay River basin in Brazil
   and Paraguay, Parana River in Argentina, Uruguay River in Brazil.
   Loricaria hoehnei is proposed as a new junior synonym of R. lanceolata.
   A key to the species of Rineloricaria from the Paraguay River basin is
   provided.
C1 Vera-Alcaraz, Hector S.; Pontificia Univ Catolica Rio Grande Sul PUCRS,

DT Article
TI New species of Alloptox (Lagomorpha, Ochotonidae), first record of the
   genus in Japan, and subgeneric distinction.
AU Tomida, Yukimitsu (y-tomida@kahaku.go.jp) 
SO Paleontological Research
VL 16
IS 1
PS 19-25
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A nearly complete mandible of a large ochotonid lagomorph was recently
   found from upper Lower Miocene deposits in central Japan, and it is
   described as a new species, Alloptox japonicas. The new species can be
   distinguished easily from all known species of the genus by size and
   several distinct characters of the p3 occlusal pattern. Almost all of
   these features show opposite character states in other species of
   Alloptox, suggesting distinction at the subgeneric level, and a new
   subgenus, Mizuhoptox, is created for A. japonicas. All previously known
   species are included in the subgenus Alloptox. Geologic age of the new
   species is about 17.6 (between 18 and 17.5) Ma (late Early Miocene),
   which is almost the same as A. sihongensis, the smallest and probably
   earliest species in continental Asia, suggesting that the distinction
   between those two subgenera was present at an early stage of Alloptar
   evolution.
C1 Tomida, Yukimitsu; Natl Museum Nat & Sci, Dept Geol & Paleontol, Amakubo
   4-1-1, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-0005, Japan, Japan.
EM y-tomida@kahaku.go.jp
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1342-8144
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Alloptox [Japan /  / new record] [Miocene /  / ]. 
   Alloptox (Mizuhoptox) japonicus [Japan /  / new species] [Miocene /  /
   ]. 
TN Chordates; Lagomorphs; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Lagomorpha, Ochotonidae

   New record].

   Fossil].

   (Mizuhoptox) japonicus, p. 20; Fossil].

   P. 20; Fossil].

TI Additional note on earliest Cretaceous entactinarians (Radiolaria) from
   the Mariana Trench.
AU Li, Rui-Qing (liruiqing08307@gmail.com) 
   Sashida, Katsuo
SO Paleontological Research
VL 16
IS 1
PS 26-36
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Extremely well preserved earliest Cretaceous radiolarians were recovered
   from a tuffaceous claystone sample collected from a seamount flank of
   the Mariana Trench's ocean-ward slope by the Japanese submersible
   "Shinkai 6500". Several species and genera belonging to Entactinaria
   have been described previously by the present authors. This study is an
   addition to the continuing investigation of this fauna, and will
   introduce one new family Paracuboctostylidae belonging to Entactinaria.
   Two new genera, Paracuboctostylus and Neoshinkaiera, and four new
   species, P. tetrayurta, N. simplex, Shinkaiera pacifica and S. robusta,
   are described.

DT Article
TI Apsopelix miyazakii, a new species of crossognathid fish (Teleostei)
   from the Upper Cretaceous of Hokkaido, Japan.
AU Yabumoto, Yoshitaka (yabumoto@kmnh.jp) 
   Hikida, Yoshinori
   Nishino, Takanobu
SO Paleontological Research
VL 16
IS 1
PS 37-46
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Apsopelix miyazakii sp. nov. is described on the basis of a single
   specimen from the Upper Cretaceous (Turonian), Nakagawa Town, Hokkaido,
   Japan. This new species differs from the other species of the genus
   Apsopelix by the existence of a median frontal convexity near the
   posterior end of the frontal bones, the articulation of the lower jaw
   behind the middle of the orbit and the antorbital contacting with the
   first infraorbital at the ventral half of its posterior margin. This is
   the first record of the genus Apsopelix and the family Crossognathidae
   from the eastern part of the Tethys.
C1 Yabumoto, Yoshitaka; Kitakyushu Museum Nat Hist & Human Hist,
   Yahatahigashi Ku, 2-4-1 Higashida, Kitakyushu, Fukuoka 805-0071, Japan,
   Japan.

   [Cretaceous / Late Cretaceous / ]. 
   Apsopelix miyazakii [Japan /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   Elopiformes, Crossognathidae

AN ZOOR14809060557
DT Article
TI Ostracoda (Crustacea) association and a new species (Dolerocypris
   anatolia nov sp.) from the Pliocene-Pleistocene Afsin-Elbistan (Kahraman
   Maras) Coal Basin of Turkey.
AU Tunoglu, Cemal (tunay@hacettepe.edu.tr) 
   Besbelli, Berk
   Ertekin, Ibrahim Kadri
SO Geologica Carpathica
VL 63
IS 2
PS 165-174
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The Afsin-Elbistan Coal Basin, which is one of the largest and most
   important Pliocene-Pleistocene lignite basins of Turkey, is located in
   Eastern Anatolia. The basin was formed between two normal faults having
   NE-SW direction and these faults controlled both the sedimentation and
   the subsidence. The coal horizon of over 50 meters in thickness
   indicates the balance between the sedimentation and subsidence rates,
   and was preserved during peat deposition. Coals were generated in this
   extensive and shallow freshwater lake and evolved from the Pliocene to
   Pleistocene. Typical faunal and floral assemblages of this ancient
   Afsin-Elbistan freshwater lake are Ostracoda, Mollusca (Gastropoda and
   Pelecypoda), spore-pollen and Characeae (gyrogonites). Eleven
   Cypridoidea species were identified from the investigation area. Eight
   of them are already known (Candona neglecta Sars, Candona iliensis
   Mandelstam, Candona aff. candida (Muller), Pseudocandona compressa
   (Koch), Cyclocypris ovum (Jurine), Ilyocypris gibba (Ramdohr), Cypris
   pubera Muller, Heterocypris sauna (Brady)), whereas three belong to open
   nomenclature - Candona sp. and Eucypris sp.; Dolerocypris anatolia nov.
   sp. is proposed as a new species. Dolerocypris Kaufmann is one of the
   largest genera among the freshwater Ostracoda. It has a very wide
   geographical distribution. Representatives of this genus are actively
   swimming species found in shallow zones of freshwater lakes and reported
   from small grassy water bodies with megascopic plants. Dolerocypris
   anatolia nov. sp. is recorded from core samples of the
   Pliocene-Pleistocene Afsin-Elbistan Coal Basin for the first time.
C1 Tunoglu, Cemal; Hacettepe Univ, Dept Geol Engn, Beytepe Ankara,
   TR-06800, Turkey, Turkey.
EM tunay@hacettepe.edu.tr
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1335-0552
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary;
   Tertiary; Neogene
DE Dolerocypris anatolia [Turkey /  / new species] [ /  / Pleistocene &amp;
   Pliocene] [Caenozoic /  / ] [Pleistocene /  / ] [Pliocene /  / ]. 
   Ostracoda [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Turkey / Anatolia,
   Afsin-Elbistan Coal Basin / distribution; stratigraphical distribution]
   [Pleistocene /  / ] [Pliocene /  / ].

   Dolerocypris anatolia (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Turkey, Caenozoic, P. 171;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14809060183
DT Article
TI A new species of Cnemidophorus (Squamata, Teiidae) from the South
   American Chaco.
AU Cabrera, Mario R. (mcabrera@efn.uncor.edu) 
SO Herpetological Journal
VL 22
IS 2
PS 123-131
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Comprising one million square kilometres, the Chaco biome is one of the
   largest open formations of South America, and part of a biogeographic
   diagonal in loose continuity with the Cerrado to the north, and the
   Patagonian Monte to the south. Until recently only one species of
   Cnemidophorus was recognized in the ocellifer group (C. ocellifer), but
   in the last decade several new species have been described to Caatingas
   and Cerrado. In this paper a new species of Cnemidophorus, previously
   regarded as the southernmost population of C. ocellifer, is described.
   Analyses of external morphology revealed that a number of traits known
   to be taxonomically informative differ from other species of the genus.
   The new species is bisexual, and distinguished from all other taxa of
   Cnemidophorus by the following character states: 75-98 granular dorsal
   scales across midbody; 184-212 dorsal scales along vertebral line; 15-19
   femoral pores in total; 25-31 lamellae under the fourth toe; two rows of
   enlarged prebrachial plates; two rows of scales along the
   inferoposterior half of the calf of males bearing erected thorn-like
   borders; 23-26 scales around the tail on the fifth complete postcloacal
   ring; 5 superciliaries; frontonasal scale subrhombical, wider than long;
   striped pattern on body and tail with unfading of white stripes in
   adults, and vertebral stripe absent. The range of the new species in
   Paraguay and Argentina strongly suggests it is endemic to the Chaco
   biome. Its presence in the Bolivian Chaco is expected.
C1 Cabrera, Mario R.; Univ Nacl Cordoba, Dept Diversidad Biol & Ecol, Ave
   Velez Sarsfield 299, Cordoba, RA-5000, Argentina, Argentina.
EM mcabrera@efn.uncor.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0268-0130
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Cnemidophorus abalosi [Argentina /  / New species] [Paraguay /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Teiidae
OR Cnemidophorus abalosi (Teiidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 125].

PT J
AN ZOOR14809060936
DT Article
TI Lower Oligocene bivalves of Ramanian Stage from Kachchh, Gujarat, India.
AU Kachhara, R.P. (kachharar@yahoo.com) 
   Jodhawat, R.L.
   Bigyapati Devi, K. Bigyapati
SO Journal of Earth System Science
VL 121
IS 2
PS 405-438
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Marine Oligocene sequences in India outcrop only in western part of
   Kachchh. Earlier researchers have recognized the Oligocene strata under
   the Nari Series (Nagappa 1959; Chatterji and Mathur 1966). The Nari
   Series has a type area in Pakistan. It has two subdivisions - the Lower
   Nari (Lower Oligocene) and the Upper Nari (Upper Oligocene). It seems
   that there is no valid proof about the age of the Lower Nari due to lack
   of proper fauna (Eames 1975), and according to Pascoe (1962), the Upper
   Nari slightly transgress into Aquitanian (Lower Miocene), therefore, one
   has to be very cautious. Biswas and Raju (1971) reclassified the
   Oligocene strata of Kachchh and lithostratigraphically clubbed them as
   the Maniyara Fort Formation with type section along the Bermoti stream.
   This Formation has four members. The lower three members correspond to
   the Ramanian Stage (Lower Oligocene, Biswas 1971, 1973) while the
   uppermost to the Waiorian Stage (Upper Oligocene, Biswas 1965, 1971,
   1973). The Ramanian Stage is characterized by large forams especially
   Nummulites fichteli, Nummulites fichteli intermedius, Lepidocyclina
   (Eulepidina) dialata and Operculina sp. Several ostracods are also known
   to occur. Megafauna include bivalves, gastropods, echinoids, corals,
   mammals and reptiles. Concerning bivalves earlier researchers have
   recorded a few taxa namely Trisidos semitorta (Lamarck), Cubitostrea
   angulata (J de C Sowerby), Pecten (Amussiopecten) labadyei d'Archiac and
   Haime, Periglypta puerpera (Linne') var. aglaurae Brongniart, Ostrea
   fraasi Mayer Eymer and listed Pecten laevicostatus J de C Sowerby,
   Callista pseudoumbonella Vredenburg and Clementia papyracea (Gray) from
   Kachchh as against overall 42 forms from the Nari Series as a whole
   (Vredenburg 1928). This tempted us to make an attempt to collect bivalve
   fauna systematically which are occurring prolifically in the Ramanian
   Stage. In the present work, for this purpose, sections are worked out
   around Lakhpat (23 [degree]50[minute]N; 68 [degree]47[minute]E),
   Maniyara Fort (23 [degree]28[minute]05[second]3N; 68
   [degree]37[minute]E) Rakhdi Dam (23 [degree]27[minute]26[second]3N; 68
   [degree]40[minute]10[second]3E) and Waior (23
   [degree]25[minute]05[second]3N; 68 [degree]41[minute]37[second]3E) with
   a view to highlight the entombed bivalve taxa. Authors have encountered
   53 species of which 23 are restricted to the Ramanian Stage.
C1 Kachhara, R.P.; ML Sukhadia Univ, Dept Geol, Udaipur 313001, India,
   India.
EM kachharar@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0973-774X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Bivalvia [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Gujarat / Kachchh /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Oligocene / Lower Oligocene / ]. 
   Ostrea (Ostrea) lakhpatensis; Ostrea (Ostrea) ramanianense; Plicatula
   (Darteplicatula) bermotiensis; Plicatula (Darteplicatula)
   maniyaragarhensis; Plicatula (Plicatula) kachchhensis [Gujarat /  / new
   species] [Oligocene /  / ].

   Plicatuloidea

   Ostrea (Ostrea) lakhpatensis (Ostreoidea): [Sp nov, Gujarat, Oligocene,
   P. 422; Fossil]. 
   Ostrea (Ostrea) ramanianense (Ostreoidea): [Sp nov, Gujarat, Oligocene,
   P. 423; Fossil]. 
   Plicatula (Darteplicatula) bermotiensis (Plicatuloidea): [Sp nov,
   Gujarat, Oligocene, P. 417; Fossil]. 
   Plicatula (Darteplicatula) maniyaragarhensis (Plicatuloidea): [Sp nov,
   Gujarat, Oligocene, P. 418; Fossil]. 
   Plicatula (Plicatula) kachchhensis (Plicatuloidea): [Sp nov, Gujarat,
   Oligocene, P. 416; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new species of Lophostoma d'Orbigny, 1836 (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae)
   from Panama.
AU Velazco, Paul M. (pvelazco@amnh.org) 
   Gardner, Alfred L.
SO Journal of Mammalogy
VL 93
IS 2
PS 605-614
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 16
AB We report the discovery of a new species of Lophostoma from Panama,
   which we name L. kalkoae. This new species resembles L. carrikeri and L.
   yasuni in possessing a white venter, but is distinguishable from both by
   external and cranial characteristics. The new species is similar in size
   to L. carrikeri and L. schulzi. Lophostoma sp. nov. can be most easily
   recognized by its combination of white venter, postauricular patches
   connected by a thin line of pale hair to the white fur on the chest,
   elongated clitoris and swollen labia, less strongly developed lateral
   projection of mastoid processes, well-marked indentation on the lingual
   cingulum of the upper canine, well-developed P3, well-developed
   posterior lingual cusp on the cingulum of P4, and parastyle absent on M1
   and M2. We present a dichotomous key for the genus Lophostoma and a map
   showing all the localities where white-bellied Lophostoma have been
   recorded.
C1 Velazco, Paul M.; Amer Museum Nat Hist, Dept Mammal, New York, NY,
   10024, USA, USA.
EM pvelazco@amnh.org
RI Velazco, Paul/P-7283-2019
OI Velazco, Paul/0000-0001-7195-7422
SC Zoology
SN 0022-2372

   Neotropical region; Central America
DE Lophostoma kalkoae [Panama /  / New species]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Chiroptera, Phyllostomidae
OR Lophostoma - D'Orbigny 1836 (Phyllostomidae): [Key to species, P. 611]. 
   Lophostoma kalkoae (Phyllostomidae): [Sp nov, Panama, P. 606].

DT Article
TI A new species of extinct little owl from the Pleistocene of Mallorca
   (Balearic Islands).
AU Guerra, Carmen (carmen.guerra@uib.es) 
   Bover, Pere
   Alcover, Josep Antoni
SO Journal of Ornithology
VL 153
IS 2
PS 347-354
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Athene vallgornerensis nov.sp. (Ayes: Strigiformes: Strigidae) from the
   Early Pleistocene of the island of Mallorca (Balearic Islands, Western
   Mediterranean) is described. The material came from a fossil assemblage
   obtained in a collapsed gallery from Cova des Pas de Vallgornera
   (Llucmajor, south of Mallorca), the longest karstic system currently
   known in the Balearics. Associated remains include primitive
   representatives of the insular endemic fauna of Mallorca (Myotragus,
   Hypnomys, Nesiotites), as well as fossils of bats, birds (among them,
   Tyto balearica), lizards and toads. Although only two bones of Athene
   have been obtained, its highly distinctive tarsometatarsus-short, highly
   robust and significantly small-differentiates it from the remaining
   extant and extinct Athene species from the Palaearctic, justifying its
   description as a new species. At least four insular species of Athene
   are now known from the Mediterranean area, and two groups can be
   identified according to the shape of their tarsometatarsi.
C1 Guerra, Carmen; Cr Miguel Marques 21, Mallorca, Balearic Islands, 07190,
   Spain, Spain.
EM carmen.guerra@uib.es
RI Alcover, Josep Antoni/Y-3796-2018

   Pedro/0000-0003-2942-2840

DT Article
TI One new species of the genus Craspedophorus Hope, 1838 (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae: Panagaeini) from Jianfengling Nature Reserve of Hainan
   Province.
AU Pang, Jian-mei
   Tian, Ming-yi (mytian@scau.edu.cn) 
SO Journal of South China Agricultural University
VL 33
IS 2
PS 264-265, 269
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the tribe Panagaeini (Coleoptera : Carabiae)
   Craspedophorus qiongensis sp. nov. was described and illustrated from
   Jianfengling Nature Reserve, Hainan Province. The unique female type
   specimen was deposited in the insect collection of South China
   Agricultural University. Length : 13.5 mm, width : 5.0 mm. This new
   species is similar to C. obscurus Xie et Yu, 1992 of Fujian Province,
   but it can be easily distinguished from the latter by the following
   character states : 1) its pronotum clypeat, wider and broader at apical
   half, side margins not produced in middle as in C. obscurus ; 2) the
   hind angle of pronotum is broader and more obtuse than that of C.
   obscurus ; 3) antennomere 1 is subequal to antennomere 3 (but
   antennomere 1 shorter in C. obscurus) ; 4) labrum and mandibles
   yellowish ( black in C. obscurus) ; and 5) the fore elytral spot
   occupies intervals 6 -10 rather than 6 -9 in C. obscurus. Compared with
   C. philippinus Jedli6ka, 1939, which was also recorded in Hainan
   Province, C. qiongensis sp. nov. is larger in sized (12. 0 [long dash]
   12. 5 mm in C. philippinus), only antennomeres 1 [long dash] 3 dark
   brown ( all antennae dark brown in C. philippinus), mouthparts and palps
   yellow ( but dark brown in C. philippinus), and the fore elytral spot
   occupies intervals of 6 -10 ( but 5 -10 in C. philippinus) . Etymology:
   "Qiong" is the abbreviation for Hainan Province. The new species is
   named after its locality.
C1 Tian, Ming-yi; College of Resources and Environment, South China
   Agricultural University, Guangzhou 510642, China, China.
EM mytian@scau.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1001-411X

   region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Carabidae

   characters, P. 264]. 
   Craspedophorus philippinus - Jedlicka 1939 (Carabidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 264].

DT Article
TI Alloptox katinkae sp nov (Lagomorpha: Ochotonidae), westernmost Eurasian
   record of the genus from the early Middle Miocene vertebrate fauna of
   Litke 2 (N Hungary).
AU Angelone, Chiara (angelone@uniroma3.it) 
   Hir, Janos
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 264
IS 1
PS 1-10
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Alloptox katinkae sp. nov. (Ochotonidae: Lagomorpha) from the late MN5
   of Litke 2 (early middle Miocene, N Hungary) is the northernmost record
   of the genus in Europe, and the westernmost record in Eurasia. The main
   peculiarities of the teeth of A. katinkae reside in their thick enamel
   band, p3 with large triangular, not indented anteroconid without enamel
   hiatuses, very reduced protoconid, large meta+entoconid, and P2 with
   convergent main flexa entering half of the tooth and bilobed meta-cone.
   A. katinkae shares most morphological and dimensional similarities with
   A. anatoliensis that actually is the geographically closest species and
   overlaps its chronologic range. The dental features of A. katinkae and
   analyses of the rest of the faunal assemblage of Litke 2 indicate that
   A. katinkae, contrarily to other congeneric species, lived in a wooded,
   wet environment. This study also evidences the problems related to the
   phylogeny of the genus Alloptox and the related palaeobiogeographical
   questions.
C1 Angelone, Chiara; Univ Roma Tre, Dipartimento Sci Geol, Largo S Leonardo
   Murialdo 1, Roma, I-00146, Italy, Italy.
EM angelone@uniroma3.it
OI ANGELONE, Chiara/0000-0002-7140-9431

   Alloptox katinkae [Hungary /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ].

   Alloptox katinkae (Ochotonidae): [Sp nov, Hungary, Miocene, P. 4;
   Fossil].

AN ZOOR14809059438
DT Article
TI On the early evolution (Late Triassic to Late Jurassic) of the
   Architectibranchia (Gastropoda: Heterobranchia), with a provisional
   classification.
AU Gruendel, Joachim (joachim.gruendel@lingua-pura.de) 
   Nuetzel, Alexander
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 264
IS 1
PS 31-59
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB At least since the Late Triassic, Architectibranchia or "lower
   Heterobranchia" form an important component of marine gastropod faunas.
   Traditionally, such gastropods were also attributed to shelled
   opisthobranchs. In this paper, more than 160 Mesozoic, mostly Jurassic
   architectibranch species are classified in 5 families and 21 genera. The
   position of the problematic genus Acteonina D'ORBIGNY, 1850 based on a
   Palaeozoic type species is discussed and its heterobranch status could
   not be undoubtedly confirmed. For all genera, emended diagnoses are
   given based on re-evaluations of their type species. Moreover, the
   generic assignments of numerous species are changed. However, for many
   species several important shell characters are unknown, e. g.,
   protoconch morphology or apertural features. Therefore, numerous
   previously described species cannot be assigned to genera with certainty
   and as a consequence, the duration of genera and families as well as the
   phylogenetic conclusions provided herein remain tentative.
   Cylindrobullinidae and Tubiferidae originate as early as Triassic. The
   oldest known genus is Sinuarbullina (Tubiferidae, Early Triassic). At
   least 6 genera representing both families cross the Triassic/Jurassic
   boundary. A distinct radiation of cylindrobullinids and tubiferids
   occurs in the Early to Middle Jurassic time interval. Bullinidae
   originate in the Early Jurassic. The bullinid Sulcoactaeon is a long
   ranging genus with a large number of species. Acteonidae and
   Ringiculidae are known since the Middle Jurassic but have their
   radiations in post-Jurassic times. The genera Sinespirites, Domerionina
   and Cossmannina are described as new. The name Cylindrites
   MORRIS&LYCETT, 1851 is replaced by the name Rugalindrites nom. nov.
C1 Gruendel, Joachim; Free Univ Berlin, Inst Geol Wissensch, Malteserstr
   74-100,Haus D, Berlin, D-12249, Germany, Germany.
EM joachim.gruendel@lingua-pura.de
OI Nutzel, Alexander/0000-0002-8852-7688
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 0077-7749

   Combination; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Shell; Evolution; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic

   [Referred to, New genus Domerionina, p. 42; Fossil]. 
   Actaeonina rara - Gruendel & Nuetzel 1998 (Cephalaspidea): [Referred to,
   New genus Domerionina, p. 42; Fossil]. 
   Actaeonina stuorense - Bandel 1994 (Cephalaspidea): [Referred to, New
   genus Domerionina, p. 42; Fossil]. 
   Actaeonina submoorei - Kuhn 1936 (Cephalaspidea): [Referred to, New
   genus Domerionina, p. 42; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14809059439
DT Article
TI Rhyncholites and conchorhynch (calcified nautiloid beaks) from the
   Eocene (Lutetian/Priabonian) Castle Hayne Formation, Southeastern North
   Carolina.
AU Weaver, Patricia G. (trish.weaver@ncdenr.gov) 
   Ciampaglio, Charles N.
   Sadorf, Eric M.
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 264
IS 1
PS 61-75
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four nautiloid upper beaks: two Rhyncolites minimus VAN BINCKHORST, one
   Rhyncolites aturensis PACAUD, one Rhyncolites sp. and one lower beak
   Conchorhynchus furrus WEAVER, CIAM-PAGLIO&SADORF n. sp. are described
   herein for the first time from the Eocene (Lutetian/Priabonian) Castle
   Hayne Formation of southeastern North Carolina. Rhyncolites americanus
   TEICHERT&SPINOSA from the Maastrichtian of Mississippi is reinstated as
   a valid species. The specimens of Rhyncolites minimus are similar in
   size to those found from California and the Netherlands. The specimen of
   Rhyncolites aturensis is similar to, but smaller than those of the same
   species described from France. The specimen of Rhyncolites sp. is so
   well-worn by dissolution, abrasion or other diagenetic factors that no
   species assignment is possible. Though preserved nautiloid upper beaks
   are geographically and stratigraphically wide-spread throughout the
   Mesozoic to Cenozoic, lower beaks are rarely preserved. Conchorhynchus
   furrus n. sp. is the first conchorhynch described from the United
   States. Eocene rhyncholites and the conchorhynch from North Carolina are
   most likely the calcified beaks of Eutrephoceras HYATT.
C1 Weaver, Patricia G.; N Carolina Museum Nat Sci, 11 W Jones St, Raleigh,
   NC, 27601, USA, USA.
EM trish.weaver@ncdenr.gov
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0077-7749
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Digestive system; Buccal
   region; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Conchorhynchus furrus [North Carolina /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Rhyncolites [Buccal jaws / Beak morphology / Taxonomic implications]
   [North Carolina / Castle Hayne Formation / ] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda
OR Conchorhynchus furrus (Cephalopoda): [Sp nov, North Carolina, Eocene, P.
   68; Fossil]. 
   Rhyncolites - Faure-Biguet 1819 (Cephalopoda): [Fossil]. 
   Rhyncolites americanus - Teichert & Spinosa 1971 (Cephalopoda): [Removal
   from synonymy, With Rhyncolites minimus van Binckhorst 1861, p. 66]. 
   Rhyncolites debeyi - (van Binckhorst 1861) (Cephalopoda): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Rhyncolites minimus van Binckhorst 1861, p. 66]. 
   Rhyncolites minimus - van Binckhorst 1861 (Cephalopoda): [Removal from
   synonymy, Rhyncolites americanus Teichert & Spinosa 1971, p. 66; Removal
   from synonymy, Rhyncolites debeyi (van Binckhorst 1861), p. 66]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14809059439
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14809059440
DT Article
TI New data on Astycoryphe, Dohmiella, Longiproetus and Quadratoproetus
   (Trilobita, Proetidae) from the Middle Devonian in the Ardennes,
   Belgium.
AU van Viersen, Allart P. (apvanviersen@gmail.com) 
   van Rossum, Alfer
   Prescher, Harald
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 264
IS 1
PS 77-87
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Proetid trilobites are described from Middle Devonian strata in the
   Dinant Synclinorium, Belgium. Astycoryphe arduinnae sp. nov., Dohmiella
   cf. dohmi (RICHTER&RICHTER), Longiproetus cf. tenuimargo (RICHTER),
   Gerastos sp. C, and Quadratoproetus sp. A are recorded from the Jemelle
   Formation (Eifelian) in Boutonville. These taxa provide the first
   comprehensive data on trilobites from the lower kockelianus conodont
   Zone in the Ardennes. A second Longiproetus species, L. meiopsifius sp.
   nov., is described from the Hanonet Formation (Givetian) in Resteigne.
   This is the first reported occurrence of Longiproetus and
   Quadratoproetus from the Ardennes.
C1 van Viersen, Allart P.; Nat Hist Museum Maastricht, Bosquetpl 6-7,
   Maastricht, NL-6211 KJ, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM apvanviersen@gmail.com
OI van Viersen, Allart/0000-0002-9380-4598
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0077-7749
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Astycoryphe arduinnae; Longiproetus meiopsifius [Belgium /  / new
   species] [Devonian /  / ]. 
   Longiproetus; Quadratoproetus [Europe / Ardennes / new record] [Devonian
   /  / ]. 
   Proetidae [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Belgium / Ardennes / ]
   [Devonian / Middle Devonian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Trilobites
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Trilobitomorpha, Trilobita
OR Astycoryphe arduinnae (Trilobita): [Sp nov, Belgium, Devonian, P. 84;
   Fossil]. 
   Longiproetus (Trilobita): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Longiproetus meiopsifius (Trilobita): [Sp nov, Belgium, Devonian, P. 80;
   Fossil]. 
   Proetidae (Trilobita): [Fossil]. 
   Quadratoproetus (Trilobita): [Fossil; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14809059440
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14809062440
DT Article
TI Intraspecific variation in Triassic Ophthalmidiid Foraminifera from
   Timor.
AU Haig, David W. (david.haig@uwa.edu.au) 
   McCartain, Eujay
SO Revue de Micropaleontologie
VL 55
IS 2
PS 39-52
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four ophthalmidiid species are described as free specimens extracted
   from mudstones and wackestones of Triassic age: Atsabella bandeiraensis
   nov. gen. nov. sp., Karaburunia atsabensis nov. sp., Ophthalmidium sp.
   cf. O. primitivum Ho and Spirophthalmidium grunaui nov. sp. Analysis of
   morphological variation found in large suites of specimens suggests
   that, as in modern miliolids, apertural characteristics, chamber shape
   and adult test size are features that vary within narrow limits and may
   be used to define species. In genera with milioline coiling in the
   post-embryonic stage, chamber arrangement may be highly variable.
   Post-embryonic coiling in K. atsabensis varies from quinqueloculine to
   almost spiroloculine and encompasses morphotypes that, in thin-section
   studies, have been attributed to a number of other genera. In Timor
   Leste, A. bandeiraensis, K. atsabensis and S. grunaui have been found
   with conodonts indicative of the Carnian, but the full local
   stratigraphic range of these species is uncertain. K. atsabensis occurs
   at another locality with conodonts suggestive of the Middle Triassic or
   less likely Carnian. Ophthalmidium sp. cf. O. primitivum has been found
   at one locality associated with A. bandeiraensis and K. atsabensis in a
   stratigraphic succession that suggests a correlation to the Carnian or
   Norian. The ophthalmidiids are found commonly associated with
   organic-cemented agglutinated and hyaline foraminifera and at some
   localities common to abundant ostracods and mollusc debris. They were
   most common in organic-rich carbonate mud of shallow-marine
   environments. (C) 2012 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Haig, David W.; Univ Western Australia, Sch Earth & Environm M004,
   Crawley, 6009, Australia, Australia.
EM david.haig@uwa.edu.au
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0035-1598
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Atsabella [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
   Atsabella bandeiraensis; Karaburunia atsabensis; Spirophthalmidium
   grunaui [East Timor /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
   Ophthalmidiidae [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [East Timor /  / ]
   [Triassic /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Atsabella (Foraminiferida): [Gen nov, Of family Ophthalmidiidae, Type
   species Atsabella bandeiraensis, p. 43, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Atsabella bandeiraensis (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, East Timor, Triassic,
   P. 43; Fossil]. 
   Karaburunia atsabensis (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, East Timor, Triassic,
   P. 43; Fossil]. 
   Ophthalmidiidae - Wiesner 1920 (Foraminiferida): [Fossil]. 
   Spirophthalmidium grunaui (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, East Timor,
   Triassic, P. 47; Fossil].

TI [Contribution on the study of the biodiversity of islands of the Gulf of

PT J
AN ZOOR14809059434
DT Article
TI TABULATE CORALS FROM THE GIVETIAN AND FRASNIAN OF THE SOUTHERN REGION OF
   THE HOLY CROSS MOUNTAINS (POLAND).
AU Zapalski, Mikolaj K. (m.zapalski@uw.edu.pl) 
SO Special Papers in Palaeontology
VL 87
PS 1-100
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Givetian and Frasnian tabulate corals from the southern region of the
   Holy Cross Mountains, Poland, are described. Both Givetian and Frasnian
   tabulate faunas from the study region are dominated by alveolitids and
   comprise 52 species (Favositida: 40 species, Syringoporida: 6 species,
   Auloporida: 6 species). A new genus belonging to Syringoporida is
   proposed [long dash] Sapounofouskilites gen. nov. [long dash] and five
   new species are erected (Favositida: Striatopora sciuricauda sp. nov.,
   Alveolites? obtortiformis sp. nov., Crassialveolites oliveri sp. nov.,
   Roseoporella heuvelmansi sp. nov.; and Auloporida: Aulopora slosarskii
   sp. nov.). Study of the intracolonial variation in tabulates shows that
   minimal and maximal corallite lumen diameters and pore diameters are the
   best taxonomical discriminators for Alveolitidae and Coenitidae, while
   the double wall thickness and tabulae spacing are less useful
   characters. More-over, alveolitids and coenitids show overall greater
   intracolonial variation than, for example, heliolitids. The tabulate
   endobiont Chaetosalpinx? plusquelleci isp. nov. is newly described.
   Study of tabulate endobionts [long dash] that is, Chaetosalpinx?
   plusquelleci, Helicosalpinx cf. asturiana Oekentorp and H. isp. [long
   dash] show that these were parasites of tabulate corals. Givetian and
   Frasnian tabulate faunas from the Kielce (southern) Region of the Holy
   Cross Mountains are dominated by Alveolitidae.
C1 Zapalski, Mikolaj K.; Faculty of Geology, University of Warsaw, Zwirki i
   Wigury 93, 02-089 Warsaw, Poland, Poland.
EM m.zapalski@uw.edu.pl
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology;
   Paleontology
SN 0038-6804
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Evolution; Variation; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Ecology;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
   periods; Palaeozoic
DE Alveolitella fecunda [Parasites / Helicosalpinx cf. asturiana / New
   record] [Poland /  / ] [Devonian /  / ]. 
   Alveolites multispinosus; Aulopora slosarskii; Crassialveolites oliveri;
   Pachyfavosites polonicus; Roseoporella heuvelmansi; Striatopora
   sciuricauda [Poland /  / new species] [Devonian /  / ].

   [Devonian /  / ] [ /  / ].

   host] [Devonian /  / ].

   New record] [Poland /  / ] [Devonian /  / ].

   ] [Fossil assemblages /  / ] [Poland / Holy Cross Mountains /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Devonian / Frasnian &amp; Givetian / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Tabulata

   Parasite of Pachyfavosites polonicus (Cnidaria), p. 83; Fossil]. 
   Helicosalpinx cf. asturiana (Animalia): [Fossil; New record].

   Fossil].

   Steininger 1831, p. 18; Fossil]. 
   Pachyfavosites polonicus (Tabulata): [Fossil].

DT Article
TI Revised generic position of the Palaeosia and Calamidia related species
   in New Guinea (Erebidae, Arctiinae, Lithosiini).
AU de Vos, Rob (rob.devos@ncbnaturalis.nl) 
SO Suara Serangga Papua
VL 6
IS 4
PS 107-128
PD April-Juni 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The generic position of four species which were traditionally placed in
   either Palaeosia Hampson, 1900 or Calamidia Butler, 1877 is revised. It
   turned out that Palaeosia and Calamidia are endemic to Australia and
   that the species in New Guinea belong to three other genera of which two
   are new: Oeonosia Hampson, 1914, Semicalamidia gen. nov. and Neosyntaxis
   gen. nov. Calamidia castanea Rothschild, 1912 syn. nov. is synonymized
   with Ilema owgarra Bethune-Baker, 1908, Calamidia reticulata Rothschild,
   1912 syn. nov. is synonymized with Palaeosia longistriga Bethune-Baker,
   1908, Calamidia warringtonella goliathina Rothschild, 1912 syn. nov. is
   synonymized with Ilema warringtonella Bethune-Baker, 1908 s. str. and
   two new species, Oeonosia cruda spec. nov. and O. abenaho spec. nov.,
   are described. Striosia irrorata (Rothschild, 1912) is compared with the
   treated species.
C1 de Vos, Rob; NCB-Naturalis, dept. Entomology, Darwinweg 2, NL-2333 CR
   Leiden, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM rob.devos@ncbnaturalis.nl
SC Zoology
SN 1978-9807
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Lithosiina [Indonesia / Papua / Distribution; systematics] [Australasia
   /  / ]. 
   Oenosia abenaho; Oenosia cruda [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Arctiidae
OR Calamidia owgarra - (Bethune-Baker 1908) (Arctiidae): [Referred to, New
   genus Semicalamidia, p. 112]. 
   Calamidia warringtonella - (Bethune-Baker 1908) (Arctiidae): [Referred
   to, New genus Neosyntaxis, p. 113]. 
   Ilema owgarra - Bethune-Baker 1908 (Arctiidae): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Semicalamidia, p. 112]. 
   Ilema warringtonella - Bethune-Baker 1908 (Arctiidae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Neosyntaxis, p. 113]. 
   Lithosiina (Arctiidae): [Included taxa, P. 114]. 
   Neosyntaxis (Arctiidae): [Gen nov, Of subtribe Lithosiina, Type species
   Ilema warringtonella Bethune-Baker 1908, p. 113]. 
   Neosyntaxis warringtonella - (Bethune-Baker 1908) (Arctiidae): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Calamidia, p. 113; Syn nov, Calamidia
   warringtonella goliathina Rothschild 1912, p. 113]. 
   Oenosia abenaho (Arctiidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 111]. 
   Oenosia cruda (Arctiidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 109]. 
   Oeonosia longistriga - (Bethune-Baker 1908) (Arctiidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 110; Comb nov, Transferred from Palaeosia, p. 109]. 
   Palaeosia longistriga - Bethune-Baker 1908 (Arctiidae): [Syn nov,
   Calamidia reticulata Rothschild 1912, p. 109; Referred to, Oeonosia, p.
   109]. 
   Semicalamidia (Arctiidae): [Gen nov, Of subtribe Lithosiina, Type
   species Ilema owgarra Bethune-Baker 1908, p. 112]. 
   Semicalamidia owgarra - (Bethune-Baker 1908) (Arctiidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Calamidia, p. 112; Syn nov, Calamidia castanea
   Rothschild 1912, p. 112]. 
   Striosia irrorata - Hampson 1914 (Arctiidae): [Taxonomic position, P.
   114].

DT Article
TI Two new cones from the Philippines (Gastropoda: Conidae).
AU Lorenz, Felix (felix@cowries.info) 
   Barbier, Jean-Pierre
SO Acta Conchyliorum
VL 11
PS 3-10
PD April 2012
PY 2012
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Conus vidua cuyoensis n. ssp. is described from the Cuyo Islands
   (Philippines). It is characterized by orange instead of dark brown
   bands, smaller site and a more sculptured, slightly more ventricose
   shell compared to C. vidua vidua from the direct geographical vicinity.
   Protoconus hanshassi n. sp. is decribed from Siargao (Philippines). It
   closest resembles the Caribbean P. auranhius and differs only in details
   of the colour-pattern and a taller spire.

   Germany.

TI Conasprella lorenzi (Gastropoda, Conidae), a new species from the
   Republic of South Africa.
AU Monnier, Eric (eric.monnier@cnam.fr) 
   Limpalaer, Loic
SO Acta Conchyliorum
VL 11
PS 17-26
PD April 2012
PY 2012
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Conus lorenzi a new species belonging to the genus Conasprella THIELE,
   1929 (Gastropoda, Conidae) is described. This deep water species was
   collected by dredging in the region of Natal (South Africa). The new
   species is compared with congeners Conasprella eugramrnata
   (BARTSCH&RENDER, 1943), C. pepeiu (MOOLENBEEK, ZANDBERGEN&BOUCHET,
   2008), C. wakayamaensis (KURODA, 1956), C. nereis (PETUCH, 1979), C.
   baileyi (ROCKEL&DA MOTTA, 1979). Additionally Yeddoconus memiae
   (HABE&KOSUGE, 1970) and following members of the genus Bathyconus
   TUCKER&TENORIO, 2009 must also had to be compared: B. comatosus
   (PILSBRY, 1904), B. saecularis (MELVILL, 1898) and B. fijiensis
   (MOOLENBEEK, ROCKEL&BOUCHET, 2008).
C1 Monnier, Eric; Conservatoire National des Arts et metiers(CNAM), 292 rue
   Saint-Martin, F-75013 Paris, France, France.

TI Phasmoconus niederhoeferi (Gastropoda, Conidae), a new species from the
   East China Sea and notes on the Ph. moluccensis (Kuester, 1838) and Ph.
   proximus (Sowerby II, 1860) complexes.
AU Monnier, Eric (eric.monnier@cnam.fr) 
   Limpalaer, Loic
   Lorenz, Felix
SO Acta Conchyliorum
VL 11
PS 27-35
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Phasmoconus niederhoeferi (Gastropoda, Conidae) is described. This deep
   water species was collected by dredging in the East China Sea in the
   region of Taizhou, province of Zhejiang, China. The new species is
   compared with the members of the Phasmoconus moluccensis and Ph.
   proxirnus complexes and also Ph. kiicumuhrs (AZUMA, 1982) and Ph.
   ciderryi (DA MOTTA, 1985). The new species is also differentiated from
   Rhizoconus pertusus (HWASS in BRUGUIERE, 1792).

DT Article
TI Largest Toothed Pterosaur Skull from the Early Cretaceous Yixian
   Formation of Western Liaoning, China, with Comments on the Family
   Boreopteridae.
AU Lu Junchang (lujc2008@126.com) 
   Pu Hanyong
   Xu Li
   Wu Yanhua
   Wei Xuefang
SO Acta Geologica Sinica English Edition
VL 86
IS 2
PS 287-293
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new pterosaur Moganopterus zhuiana gen. et sp. nov. is erected based
   on a complete skull with lower jaws and anterior cervical vertebrae. It
   is characterized by much elongated upper and lower jaws with at least 62
   total, long, curved teeth with sharp tips, a well developed parietal
   crest extending posterodorsally, forming an angle of 15 degrees with the
   ventral margin of the skull, the ratio of length to width of cervical
   vertebrae greater than 5:1. The skull length is 750 mm, and it is the
   largest toothed pterosaur found so far in the world. Based on this new
   pterosaur, the Boreopteridae can be divided into two subgroups:
   Boreopterinae sub-fam. nov. and Moganopterinae sub-fam. nov., which is
   also confirmed by the phylogenetic analysis.
C1 Lu Junchang; Chinese Acad Geol Sci, Inst Geol, Beijing, 100037, China,
   China.
EM lujc2008@126.com
SC Zoology
SN 0361-6886
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China;
   Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Boreopterinae; Moganopterinae [Cretaceous /  / New subfamily]. 
   Moganopterus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Moganopterus zhuiana [Liaoning /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Pterosauria,
   Pterodactyloidea
OR Boreopterinae (Pterodactyloidea): [Subfam nov, Of family Boreopteridae,
   Type genus Boreopterus Lu & Ji 2005, p. 292, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Boreopterus - Lu & Ji 2005 (Pterodactyloidea): [Designated type genus
   for new subfamily, Boreopterinae, p. 292; Fossil]. 
   Feilongus - Wang, Kellner, Zhou & de Almeida Campos 2005
   (Pterodactyloidea): [Referred to, New subfamily Moganopterinae, p. 292;
   Fossil]. 
   Moganopterinae (Pterodactyloidea): [Subfam nov, Of family Boreopteridae,
   Type genus Moganopterus, p. 292, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Moganopterus (Pterodactyloidea): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Moganopterinae
   (new), Type species Moganopterus zhuiana, p. 287, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Moganopterus zhuiana (Pterodactyloidea): [Sp nov, Liaoning, Cretaceous,
   P. 287; Fossil]. 
   Zhenyuanopterus - Lu 2010 (Pterodactyloidea): [Referred to, New
   subfamily Boreopterinae, p. 292; Fossil].

AN ZOOR14808053853
DT Article
TI A New Species of Liadotaulius (Insecta: Trichoptera) from the Middle
   Jurassic of Daohugou, Inner Mongolia.
AU Wu Hao
   Huang Diying (huangdiying@sina.com) 
SO Acta Geologica Sinica English Edition
VL 86
IS 2
PS 320-324
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Diverse caddis flies are recently collected from the Middle Jurassic
   Daohugou fauna in Ningcheng County, Inner Mongolia, northern China, and
   different types of caddis cases have been reported in the same locality.
   A new species of caddisfly, Liadotaulius daohugouensis sp. nov. is
   described and illustrated; the establishment is based on a
   well-preserved isolated forewing collected from the Middle Jurassic
   Jiulongshan Formation of Daohugou. The family status of Liadotaulius is
   discussed on the basis of new material and is referred to the family
   Philopotamidae. The Daohugou fauna continues to provide new data for
   studying the early evolution of Trichoptera.

   Jiangsu, 210008, China, China.

DT Article
TI A new species of Cordylus (Squamata: Cordylidae) from the Marungu
   Plateau of south-eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo.
AU Greenbaum, Eli (egreenbaum2@utep.edu) 
   Stanley, Edward L.
   Kusamba, Chifundera
   Moninga, Wandege M.
   Goldberg, Stephen R.
   Bursey, Charles R.
SO African Journal of Herpetology
VL 61
IS 1
PS 14-39
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB Currently there are 20 recognised species of the widespread lizard genus
   Cordylus, which is distributed throughout sub-Saharan Africa's
   non-forested habitats from Ethiopia to South Africa. Most recent
   taxonomic work has focused on forms in southern Africa, where several
   subspecific taxa have been elevated to full species status. Herein, we
   focus on the widespread species Cordylus tropidosternum, which occurs
   from Mozambique (its type locality) to south-eastern Kenya and Tanzania,
   and west to Katanga Province of Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC).
   We sequenced 3 779 bp from two mitochondrial (12S, 16S) and four nuclear
   (MYH, Kif24, PrLR and MC1R) genes from multiple samples of C.
   tropidosternum and several sympatric species; these data were analysed
   with maximum parsimony, maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference
   optimality criteria. One morphologically and genetically distinct clade
   of Cordylus from the Marungu Plateau of Katanga Province, DRC is
   described as a new species. The new species was found under rocks in
   montane grassland, but further study is needed to assess Cordylus
   populations in the lowlands of Katanga. We also provide the first
   detailed morphometric data for the poorly known species C. angolensis,
   which was described from a single specimen that has since been
   destroyed.
C1 Greenbaum, Eli; Univ Texas El Paso, Dept Biol Sci, El Paso, TX, 79968,
   USA, USA.
EM egreenbaum2@utep.edu

   Evolution; Habitat; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Cordylus angolensis [Biometrics / Detailed morphometrics / ] [Angola / 
   / ]. 
   Cordylus marunguensis [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species].

   habitat / Plateau / ] [Africa / Subsaharan Africa / ].

   Sauria, Cordylidae

   Cordylus marunguensis (Cordylidae): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P. 23].

DT Article
TI A new species of Hemidactylus (Squamata: Gekkonidae) from Principe
   Island, Gulf of Guinea, West Africa with comments on the
   African-Atlantic clade of Hemidactylus geckos.
AU Miller, Elizabeth C.
   Sellas, Anna B.
   Drewes, Robert C. (rdrewes@calacademy.org) 
SO African Journal of Herpetology
VL 61
IS 1
PS 40-57
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB The remote oceanic Gulf of Guinea islands of Sao Tome and Principe are
   home to a highly endemic herpetofauna, which has become the focus of
   modern, on-going scientific analysis only during the past decade. Until
   now, the endemic Hemidactylus greeffi Bocage 1886 (Greeff's giant gecko)
   has been considered to occur on both islands. Herein, we employ both new
   and previously published molecular data, along with differences in
   morphological characters, to demonstrate that the Principe populations
   are a full species distinct from H. greeffi. We describe the new species
   and restrict the range of H. greeffi to the island of Sao Tome. The
   original unnumbered holotype of H. greeffii held in the Museu Bocage was
   destroyed in Lisbon and we have been unable to determine the collection
   provenance of unnumbered material treated by subsequent authors. We
   therefore designate a neotype for H. greeffi from California Academy of
   Science collections and provide morphological information on that
   species additional to that of earlier workers, based upon 14 specimens
   collected in various localities on Sao Tome during the past decade.
C1 Drewes, Robert C.; Calif Acad Sci, Dept Herpetol, San Francisco, CA,
   94118, USA, USA.
EM rdrewes@calacademy.org
OI Miller, Elizabeth/0000-0001-6856-3107

   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology

   morphology; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Oceanic islands; Atlantic Ocean islands
DE Hemidactylus [General morphology /  / taxonomic implications] [Nucleic
   acids / Nuclear DNA sequences / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Variation
   / Molecular & morphological character variation / ] [Zoogeography /
   Endemism / ] [Sao Tome and Principe /  / ].

   Sauria, Gekkonidae

   51; Redescription, P. 50]. 
   Hemidactylus principensis (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Sao Tome and Principe,
   P. 44].

DT Article
TI A New Species and a New Record of the Diastylidae (Crustacea: Cumacea)
   from Korea.
AU Lee, Chang-Mok
   Lee, Kyung-Sook (kslee@dankook.ac.kr) 
SO Animal Systematics Evolution and Diversity
VL 28
IS 2
PS 71-83
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study, a new species, Dimorphostylis breviplicata n. sp. is
   described and illustrated on the basis of specimens collected from the
   shallow Korean waters. This new species is similar to Dimorphostylis
   brevicaudata (Zimmer, 1903), Dimorphostylis acroplicata Harada, 1960 and
   Dimorphostylis valida Gamo, 1962 in that the carapace has three pairs of
   oblique ridges on the surface. However, the new species is distinguished
   by the combination of the following features: the middle oblique ridge
   is short and not joined to the other oblique ridges; the transverse
   ridge is absent on the frontal lobe; the dorso-median process on the
   pereonite 5 is only barely visible; the male telson has no short stout
   seta on the both lateral margins; the length ratio of the first to
   remaining articles combined on the male uropod is 1 : 0.7. A key to the
   Korean Dimorphostylis species is provided. Also, Diastylis alaskensis
   Calman, 1912 is redescribed as a new recorded species of the Korean
   fauna.
C1 Lee, Kyung-Sook; Dankook Univ, Dept Life Sci, Cheonan, 330714, China,
   China.
EM kslee@dankook.ac.kr
SC Zoology
SN 2234-6953

   Dimorphostylis [North Pacific / South Korea / Key to species]. 
   Dimorphostylis breviplicata [North Pacific / South Korea / New species].

   Peracarida, Cumacea

   characters, P. 79]. 
   Dimorphostylis breviplicata (Cumacea): [Sp nov, South Korea (marine), P.
   72]. 
   Dimorphostylis valida - Gamo 1962 (Cumacea): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   79].

DT Article
TI First Record of Monstrilloid Copepods in Korea: Description of a New
   Species of the Genus Cymbasoma (Monstrilloida, Monstrillidae).
AU Chang, Cheon Young (cychang@daegu.ac.kr) 
SO Animal Systematics Evolution and Diversity
VL 28
IS 2
PS 126-132
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new monstrilloid species belonging to the genus Cymbasoma is described
   as a preliminary result from nocturnal surveys using a light trap on the
   east and south coasts of South Korea. Monstrilloid copepods are first
   recorded in South Korea. Cymbasoma stritfrons n. sp. resembles C.
   striatum (Isaac, 1974) and C. tumorifrons Isaac, 1975 in sharing the
   character combination of transverse striations on forehead, somewhat
   small body (generally slightly less or longer than 1 mm), single lobed
   leg 5 bearing a short medial seta in female, and smooth lateral margin
   of anal somite without notch and wrinkles. However, C. striifrons n. sp.
   differs from C. striatum by relatively short and swollen cephalothorax,
   and rather strongly wrinkled genital somite. Cymbasoma stritfrons n. sp.
   is also distinguished from C. tumorifrons in lacking a rounded
   protuberance on anterior margin of ventral surface and by relatively
   short cephalothorax and the number of ventral nipple-like processes on
   cephalothorax. Herein the new species is described and illustrated, with
   some comments on the morphological comparison with its allied species.
C1 Chang, Cheon Young; Daegu Univ, Dept Biol Sci, Gyeongsan, 712714, South
   Korea, South Korea.
EM cychang@daegu.ac.kr
SC Zoology
SN 2234-6953
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Cymbasoma; Monstrilloida [North Pacific / South Korea / New record]. 
   Cymbasoma striifrons [North Pacific / South Korea / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Monstrilloida
OR Monstrilloida (Copepoda): [New record]. 
   Cymbasoma (Monstrilloida): [New record]. 
   Cymbasoma striifrons (Monstrilloida): [Sp nov, South Korea (marine), P.
   127].

DT Article
TI SYSTEMATIC REVISION OF THE SPOTTED ANTPITTA (GRALLARIIDAE: HYLOPEZUS
   MACULARIUS), WITH DESCRIPTION OF A CRYPTIC NEW SPECIES FROM BRAZILIAN
   AMAZONIA.
AU Carneiro, Lincoln Silva
   Gonzaga, Luiz Pedreira
   Rego, Pericles S.
   Sampaio, Iracilda
   Schneider, Horacio
   Aleixo, Alexandre (aleixo@museu-goeldi.br) 
SO Auk
VL 129
IS 2
PS 338-351
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 14
AB We present a systematic revision of the polytypic Spotted Antpitta
   (Grallariidae: Hylopezus macularius) based on morphometric, plumage,
   vocal, and molecular characters. Morphological and vocal analyses were
   based, respectively, on 97 specimens and 106 recordings. Molecular
   phylogenies were inferred on the basis of 1,352 base pairs of the
   mitochondrial DNA genes 16S, ND2, and cytochrome b from 30 specimens,
   including several outgroups. Our results revealed the existence of an
   undescribed taxon endemic to the Madeira-Xingu interfluvium, similar in
   morphology to paraensis, but vocally and genetically readily
   distinguished from the latter and any other taxon grouped under H.
   macularius. We also found that populations from the Negro River basin
   (currently treated in paraensis) and those from northern Peru and
   southern Venezuela (placed in diversus) should be treated as a single
   taxon, for which the name dilutus is available. Reconstructed
   phylogenies recovered, with overall strong support, the reciprocal
   monophyly among four main lineages of the Spotted Antpitta, three
   corresponding to already named taxa (dilutus, macularius, and
   paraensis), and one to the unnamed taxon, which we describe. We show
   that those four taxa are also mutually diagnosed by a combination of
   both vocal and morphological features, and we recommend treating them as
   separate species under alternative species concepts. Received 18 July
   2011, accepted 11 February 2012.
C1 Aleixo, Alexandre; Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, Caixa Postal 399,
   Belem, Para, BR-66040170 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM aleixo@museu-goeldi.br

   ANIKUZHIYIL, ANISH/Y-8609-2018; Aleixo, Alexandre/L-3135-2013; Gonzaga,
   Luiz/M-8266-2013; SAMPAIO, IRACILDA/J-6514-2012; Carneiro,
   Lincoln/M-7267-2019; Rego, Pericles S/J-2620-2012
OI Schneider, Horacio/0000-0002-5987-6395; Carneiro,
   Lincoln/0000-0002-7680-2291; ANIKUZHIYIL, ANISH/0000-0001-9686-1283;
   Aleixo, Alexandre/0000-0002-7816-9725; SAMPAIO,
   IRACILDA/0000-0002-2137-4656; Carneiro, Lincoln/0000-0002-7680-2291;
   Rego, Pericles S/0000-0002-4537-946X

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF LEPTOGORGIA (CNIDARIA: ANTHOZOA: OCTOCORALLIA) FROM THE
   MEXICAN PACIFIC COAST.
AU Breedy, Odalisca (odalisca.breedy@ucr.ac.cr) 
   Abeytia, Rosalinda
   Guzman, Hector M.
SO Bulletin of Marine Science
VL 88
IS 2
PS 319-325
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The gorgoniid genus Leptogorgia is found along the Pacific coast of
   Mexico; 10 species have been reported from Baja California and Acapulco.
   Leptogorgia ena sp. nov. is a new shallow-water species found at 5-12 m
   depth at various high energy rocky sites along the coast of San Pedro
   Pochutla District, Oaxaca. Specimens of the new species were collected
   by scuba diving and the morphological characters were analyzed and
   illustrated under light and scanning electron microscopy. The new
   species can be distinguished from the others by the very small colony,
   dominance of wide capstans, barrels and double heads, low occurrence of
   spindles, spindles measuring < 0.10 mm, and presence of tentacular
   sclerites. With this report, the genus Leptogorgia increases to 11
   species for Mexico and 26 for the eastern Pacific.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF ENSAYARA (CRUSTACEA: AMPHIPODA: ENDEVOURIDAE) FROM A
   TROPICAL CORAL REEF SYSTEM, SW GULF OF MEXICO.
AU Winfield, Ignacio (ignacioc@unam.mx) 
   Ortiz, Manuel
SO Bulletin of Marine Science
VL 88
IS 2
PS 327-336
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Here we describe a new species of the genus Ensayara associated with the
   sponge Ircinia felix (Duchassaing and Michelloti, 1864). The specimens
   of Ensayara lozanoi n. sp., were collected from the Veracruz Coral Reef
   System National Park, southwestern Gulf of Mexico, at a depth of 10 m.
   The new species differs from Ensayara entrichoma Gable and Lazo-Wasem,
   1990 and Ensayara jumane Barnard and Thomas, 1990 in several aspects of
   the lateral cephalic lobe, mandibular palp, maxilliped, antenna 1, and
   coxae 3 and 4.

TI Johnius (Johnius) majan sp nov., a sciaenid fish (Pisces: Sciaenidae)
   from Oman, Indian Ocean.
AU Iwatsuki, Yukio (yuk@cc.miyazaki-u.ac.jp) 
   Jawad, Laith A.
   Al-Mamry, Juma M.
SO Ichthyological Research
VL 59
IS 2
PS 151-155
PD Apr 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Johnius (Johnius) majan sp. nov. is described on the basis of 8
   specimens (117-158 mm in standard length) from Oman, Indian Ocean. The
   new species is distinguished from its congeners by the following
   combination of characters: black axillary spot on upper pectoral fin
   base; dorsal soft rays 29-32; anal soft rays 8; scales above lateral
   line 6, below 11; eye diameter 22.9-28.9% HL; interorbital width
   32.0-38.0% HL; gill rakers 5-6 + 15-18 = 21-24; no mental barbel; last
   well developed pleural rib on 7th vertebra; swim bladder appendages 11;
   vertebrae 10 + 14 = 24.

DT Article
TI Derived, still living cockroach genus Cariblattoides (Blattida:
   Blattellidae) from the Eocene sediments of Green River in Colorado, USA.
AU Vrsansky, Peter (geolvrsa@savba.sk) 
   Vidlicka, L'ubomir
   Ciampor, Fedor, Jr
   Marsh, Finnegan
SO Insect Science
VL 19
IS 2
PS 143-152
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Cariblattoides labandeirai sp.n. from the Eocene sediments of Green
   River in Colorado, USA bear only two plesiomorphies, but also several
   significant autapomorphies within the advanced and highly derived living
   cockroach genus. Thus, Cariblattoides with extant occurrence in the
   Caribbean and South America was historically common in the Nearctic, and
   represents important evidence for the occurrence of derived living
   genera of cockroaches [approximately]50 Ma ago. Generally, the vast
   majority of living genera were absent during the Palaeocene, thus the
   diversification of most living cockroach lineages near the
   Palaeocene/Eocene boundary must have been extremely rapid. Females of
   living C. suave, the type species, have identical (sophisticated)
   coloration of pronotum, but the most related living taxa are C.
   piraiensis and C. fontesi from Brazil (supported by phylogenetical
   analysis).
C1 Vrsansky, Peter; Geological Institute, Slovak Academy of Sciences,
   Dubravska cesta 9, P.O. Box 106, 840 05 Bratislava, Slovakia, Slovakia.
EM geolvrsa@savba.sk
RI Ciampor, Fedor/AAR-7555-2020
OI Ciampor, Fedor/0000-0001-6269-3592
SC Zoology
SN 1672-9609
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Cariblattoides labandeirai [Colorado /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Dictyoptera, Blattodea

   P. 145]. 
   Cariblattoides labandeirai (Blattodea): [Sp nov, Colorado, Eocene, P.
   146; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new Upper Carboniferous stem-orthopteran (Insecta) from Ningxia
   (China).
AU Bethoux, Olivier
   Gu, Jun-Jie
   Ren, Dong (rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn) 
SO Insect Science
VL 19
IS 2
PS 153-158
PD April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB During the Upper Carboniferous, orthopteran insects (grasshoppers,
   katydids, and crickets)were represented by numerous species distantly
   related to crown-orthopterans, such as lobeattid and cnemidolestodean
   insects. The panorthopterans, including totalorthopterans and their
   closest relatives, are represented by comparatively rarer species in
   localities of this period. Here we describe Heterologus duyiwuer sp.
   nov., an infrequent panorthopteran from the Late Carboniferous locality
   of Xiaheyan Village (Zhongwei City, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region,
   China). The only available specimen is composed of an isolated forewing
   exhibiting a combination of character states previously unknown, in
   particular the lack of posterior radius (RP) / anterior Media (MA)
   connection, late branchings of the media (M) and anterior cubitus (CuA),
   and a branched posterior branch of the posterior cubitus (CuPb). Based
   on its unusual branching pattern, the composite stem resulting from the
   fusion of CuA and CuPa[alpha] (second anterior branch of CuP) is assumed
   to be composed of a branched CuA and a simple CuPa[alpha].
C1 Ren, Dong; College of Life Sciences, Capital Normal University, Beijing
   100048, China, China.
EM rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn
RI Bethoux, Olivier/C-7308-2009
SC Zoology
SN 1672-9609
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Heterologus duyiwuer [Ningxia Hui /  / new species] [Carboniferous /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Protorthoptera
OR Heterologus duyiwuer (Protorthoptera): [Sp nov, Ningxia Hui,
   Carboniferous, P. 155; Fossil].
