TI A new species of the genus Austinogebia Ngoc-Ho, 2001 (Crustacea,
   Decapoda, Gebiidea, Upogebiidae) from northern China.
AU Liu, Wenliang
   Liu, Ruiyu (jyliu@ms.qdio.ac.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3243
PS 59-64
PD 22 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3243.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03243p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Austinogebia Ngoc-Ho, 2001, A. monospina n.
   sp., collected from the Bohai Sea and the Yellow Sea, is described and
   illustrated. It is closely allied to A. spinifrons (Haswell, 1881) but
   differs markedly in the rostral ornamentation, with one infrarostral
   spine and the unarmed lower margin of antennal peduncle.
C1 Liu, Ruiyu; Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences,

AN ZOOR14806043009
DT Article
TI Preliminary results of anatomical study of molluscs of the genus
   Helicopsis (Hygromiidae) of Crimea and Black Sea Lowland.
AU Gural-Sverlova, N.V. (sverlova@museum.lviv.net) 
SO Ruthenica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 15-34
PD March 22 2012
PY 2012
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The structure of the distal parts of the reproductive system of the
   majority of the species of the genus Helicopsis occuring in Crimea and
   Black Sea Lowland (H. retowskii, H. dejecta, H. striata) were studied.
   The special attention was given to the intraspecific variability of the
   penial papilla shape and some proportions of the genitalia. Basing on
   the anatomical characters, the wide range of the conchological
   variability of H. retowskii has been shown. The area of this species
   extends outside the limits of the Crimea. It is suggested that H.
   paulhessei (=H. gasprensis) and Xerophila elata are the synonyms of H.
   retowskii. The key for the determination of the Crimea molluscs of the
   genus Helicopsis on the anatomical characters is provided.
C1 Gural-Sverlova, N.V.; State Natural History Museum, National Academy of
   Sciences of Ukraine, Teatralna str 18, Lviv 79008, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM sverlova@museum.lviv.net
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology
SN 0136-0027
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Shell; Reproduction; Reproductive system; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Helicopsis [Shell morphology / Conchological variation / ] [Genitalia /
   Genitalia morphological variation / ] [Ukraine / Crimea / ] [ /  / Key
   to species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Helicoidea
OR Helicopsis - Fitzinger 1833 (Helicoidea): [Key to species, Ukraine,
   Crimea, Shell &  genitalia morphology, p. 33]. 
   Helicopsis retowskii - (Clessin 1883) (Helicoidea): [Syn nov, Helicopsis
   paulhessei (Lindholm 1936), p. 30; Syn nov, Xerophila elata Puzanov
   1926, p. 29]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14806043009

PT J
AN ZOOR14806043011
DT Article
TI Pyramidula kuznetsovi sp. nov. - a new species of land molluscs from
   Nepal (Pulmonata, Pyramidulidae).
AU Schileyko, A.A. (asch@gol.ru) 
   Balashov, I.A.
SO Ruthenica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 41-45
PD March 22 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An illustrated description of the shell and reproductive tract of
   Pyramidula kuznetsovi sp. nov. is given. The presence of a distinct
   peripheral angle distinguishes this species from all known species of
   the genus. Both anatomically studied specimens had well-developed
   embryos in the uterus, whereas distal parts of the male section of
   reproductive tract were much reduced. Therefore it is hard to judge
   about anatomical differences of P. kuznetsovi from other species of the
   genus, in particular, the question on the presence of penial caecum
   remains open.
C1 Schileyko, A.A.; A.N. Severtzov Institute of Ecology and Evolution,
   Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky Prospect 33, Moscow 119071,
   Russia, Russia.
EM asch@gol.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0136-0027
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Pyramidula kuznetsovi [Nepal /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Pupilloidea
OR Pyramidula - Fitzinger 1833 (Pupilloidea): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 43]. 
   Pyramidula kuznetsovi (Pupilloidea): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 41]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14806043011
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14806043014
DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Plicifusus Dall, 1902 (Gastropoda: Buccinidae).
AU Kosyan, A.R. (kosalisa@rambler.ru) 
   Kantor, Yu.I.
SO Ruthenica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 55-92
PD March 22 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Plicifusus Dall, 1902 has been revised on the basis of
   available anatomical data. Thirteen valid recent species are recognised,
   for 9 of them detailed descriptions of anatomy are provided. Four names
   were synonymized: Plicifusus obtusatus Golikov, 1985 = Plicifusus
   maehirai Tiba, 1980; Colus okhotskana Tiba, 1973 = Plicifusus elaeodes
   (Dall, 1907); Tritonofusus (Plicifusus) aurantius Dall, 1907 and
   Plicifusus (Aulacofusus) rhyssoides Dall, 1918 = Plicifusus rhyssus
   (Dall, 1907). Plicifusus parvus, Tiba, 1980 and Plicifusus saginatus
   Tiba, 1980 are consid- ered as junior synonyms of Retifusus roseus
   (Dall, 1877). Plicifusus laticordatus (Dall, 1902) is excluded from the
   genus Plicifusus.
C1 Kosyan, A.R.; A.N. Severtsov Institute of Ecology and Evolution, 119071,
   Leninsky prospekt 33, Moscow, Russia, Russia.
EM kosalisa@rambler.ru
RI Kantor, Yuri/D-5259-2014
OI Kantor, Yuri/0000-0002-3209-4940
SC Zoology
SN 0136-0027
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Muricoidea
OR Plicifusus - Dall 1902 (Muricoidea): [Systematics, P. 55]. 
   Plicifusus bambusa - Tiba 1980 (Muricoidea): [Redescription, P. 65]. 
   Plicifusus elaeodes - (Dall 1907) (Muricoidea): [Redescription, P. 72;

   P. 88]. 
   Plicifusus maehirai - Tiba 1980 (Muricoidea): [Redescription, P. 67; Syn
   nov, Plicifusus obtusatus Golikov in Golikov &  Scarlato 1985, p. 66]. 
   Plicifusus oceanodromae - Dall 1919 (Muricoidea): [Redescription, P.
   82]. 
   Plicifusus olivaceus - (Aurivillius 1885) (Muricoidea): [Redescription,
   P. 86]. 
   Plicifusus parvus - Tiba 1980 (Muricoidea): [Junior synonym, Of
   Retifusus roseus (Dall 1877), p. 88]. 
   Plicifusus rhyssus - (Dall 1907) (Muricoidea): [Redescription, P. 78;
   Syn nov, Plicifusus (Aulacofusus) rhyssoides Dall 1918, p. 77; Syn nov,
   Tritonofusus (Plicifusus) aurantius Dall 1907, p. 77]. 
   Plicifusus saginatus - Tiba 1980 (Muricoidea): [Junior synonym, Of
   Retifusus roseus (Dall 1877), p. 88]. 
   Plicifusus scissuratus - Dall 1918 (Muricoidea): [Redescription, P. 67].
   
   Plicifusus torquatus - (Petrov 1982) (Muricoidea): [Redescription, P.
   86]. 
   Retifusus roseus - (Dall 1877) (Muricoidea): [Senior synonym, Of
   Plicifusus parvus Tiba 1980, p. 88; Senior synonym, Of Plicifusus
   saginatus Tiba 1980, p. 88].

PT J

DT Article
TI A revision of Strophurus taenicauda (Squamata; Diplodactylidae) with the
   description of two new subspecies from central Queensland and a
   southerly range extension.
AU Brown, Danny (geckodan@bigpond.com) 
   Worthington Wilmer, Jessica
   MacDonald, Stewart
SO Zootaxa
VL 3243
PS 1-28
PD 22 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3243.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03243p028.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Golden-tailed Gecko, Strophurus taenicauda (De Vis 1886), is
   redescribed and two new subspecies from central Queensland are diagnosed
   on the basis of scalation, colour pattern and genetic differences. The
   distribution of S. t. taenicauda comprises the south-eastern part of the
   Queensland Brigalow Belt bioregion. Strophurus taenicauda albiocularis
   ssp. nov. occupies the northern half of the range whilst S. taenicauda
   triaureus ssp. nov. has a limited range in the central eastern part of
   the Brigalow Belt. The two new subspecies are predominantly inhabitants
   of Eucalyptus woodlands and are not as restricted to Brigalow (Acacia
   harpophylla) woodlands as S. t. taenicauda. A single record of the
   nominate subspecies from northern New South Wales is also reported,
   extending the range of the species by >250km.
C1 Brown, Danny; Sunshine Coast Pet Emergency, 431 Tanawha Tourist Dr,
   Tanawha, Qld 4556, Australia, Australia.
EM geckodan@bigpond.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Strophurus taenicauda [New South Wales /  / Distribution; new record;
   taxonomic revision] [Queensland /  / ]. 
   Strophurus taenicauda albiocularis; Strophurus taenicauda triaureus
   [Queensland /  / New subspecies]. 
   Strophurus taenicauda taenicauda [New South Wales / Pilliga Scrub Region
   / New record]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Strophurus taenicauda - (De Vis 1886) (Gekkonidae): [Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, Subspecies, p. 14; New record]. 
   Strophurus taenicauda albiocularis (Gekkonidae): [Subsp nov, Queensland,
   P. 18]. 
   Strophurus taenicauda taenicauda - (De Vis 1886) (Gekkonidae): [Type
   locality, P. 11; Redescription, P. 14; New record]. 
   Strophurus taenicauda triaureus (Gekkonidae): [Subsp nov, Queensland, P.
   22].

PT J
AN ZOOR14805039517
DT Article
TI Samia beekei sp. nov., a new wild silkmoth from northern Vietnam
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Samia beekei sp. nov., ein neuer wilder Seidenspinner aus dem
   noerdlichen Vietnam (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Paukstadt, Ulrich (ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de) 
   Paukstadt, Laela Hayati
SO Beitraege zur Kenntnis der Wilden Seidenspinner
VL 10
IS 8
PS 295-306
PD 21 Maerz 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Samia HUBNER, 1819 ("1816") (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) of the tribe Attacini BLANCHARD, 1840 is described from
   northern Vietnam, Bac Kan province, Xuat Hoa village, 110 m above sea
   level (GPS Position 22[degree]04[minute]18[second]N,
   105[degree]52[minute]51[second]E), area of karst: Samia beekei sp. nov.
   The new species is named in honor of our long time friend and amateur
   entomologist Martin Beeke (Stemwede, Germany). So far records of S.
   beekei sp. nov. are only known from the lowlands of the Bac Kan
   province, northern Vietnam. The new species is intermediate S. kohlli
   NAUMANN&PEIGLER, 2001 from West Malaysia and S. wangi NAUMANN&PEIGLER,
   2001 from northern Vietnam in the external morphology and in the male
   genitalia structures closer to S. kohlli and S. cynthia (DRURY, 1773)
   (Phalaena Attacus). The differences in the male genitalia structures to
   those of S. canningi (HUTroN, 1859) (Saturnia) are more obvious.
   DNA-barcoding (BOLD) within the context of the global DNA barcoding
   campaign for the family Saturniidae (see http:// www.lepbarcoding.org/
   saturniidae/index.php), an international collaborative effort carried
   out from the Biodiversity Institute of Ontario at the University of
   Guelph revealed in grouping of S. beekei sp. nov. from northern Vietnam,
   S. wangi from northern Vietnam, and S. kohlli from West Malaysia. S.
   beekei sp. nov. likely is a lowland taxon while S. kohlli preferably
   ranges above 1,500 m in the Malay Peninsula (observations by the
   authors). Peigler&Naumann (2003) recorded S. kohlli for West Malaysia,
   Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, and the southern Chinese provinces at
   altitudes from 200-2,500 m. S. beekei sp. nov. was reared indoors by the
   authors from the egg to the moth. Only specimens of this rearing were
   selected for the type series. Larvae surprisingly fed on Salix sp. and
   were found being distinct to those of S. kohlli from the Malay
   Peninsula. A rearing report of S. beekei sp. nov. is published in the
   same edition of this journal. S. beekei sp. nov. is decribed herein and
   mainly compared with S. kohlli (West Malaysia), S. wangi (Vietnam), and
   S. cynthia (China). The male holotype, the female allotype and the male
   genitalia structures of S. beekei sp. nov. are figured. Meister (2011)
   listed the Indonesian Samia kikibudiamini PAUKSTADT,
   PAUKSTADT&SUHARDJONO, 2002 as junior (subjective) synonym of S. yayukae
   NAUMANN&NASSIG, 1995 (error in authorship of S. yayukae PAUKSTADT,
   PEIGLER&PAUKSTADT, 1995). We herewith remove S. kikibudiamini PAUKSTADT,
   PAUKSTADT&SUHARDJONO, 2002 from synonymy with S. yayukae PAUKSTADT,
   PEIGLER&PAUKSTADT, 1995: Samia kikibudiamini PAUKSTADT,
   PAUKSTADT&SUHARDJONO, 2002 stat. rev. True S. kikibudiamini from the
   islands of Alor and Timor and S. yayukae from the island of Flores are
   clearly distinct in the morphology and the male genitalia structures, as
   well as in DNA-barcoding (BOLD). Meister (2011) listed S. borneensis
   (REBEL, 1926) [error in publication year of borneensis (REBEL, 1925)
   (Philosamia)] as a junior (subjective) synonym of S. tetrica (REBEL,
   1923) [error in publication year of tetrica (REBEL, 1924) (Philosamia)].
   S. borneensis from the mountainous region of East Malaysia (Kinabalu)
   was found being distinct from S. tetrica from West Malaysia in the
   morphology and DNA-structures, cf. U. Paukstadt&L.H. Paukstadt (2011).We
   herewith remove again S. borneensis (REBEL, 1925) from synonymy with S.
   tetrica (REBEL, 1924): Samia borneensis (REBEL, 1925) stat. rev.
   Together with S. beekei sp. nov. the number of species in the genus
   Samia increase to twentythree all in species rank.
C1 Paukstadt, Ulrich; Knud-Rasmussen-Strasse 5, 26389 Wilhelmshaven,
   Germany, Germany.
EM ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 1612-2674
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Samia beekei [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Samia beekei (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 299]. 
   Samia borneensis - (Rebel 1925) (Saturniidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Samia tetrica (Rebel 1924), p. 299]. 
   Samia kikibudiamini - Paukstadt, Paukstadt & Suhardjono 2002
   (Saturniidae): [Removal from synonymy, With Samia yayukae Paukstadt,
   Peigler & Paukstadt 1993, p. 299]. 
   Samia tetrica - (Rebel 1924) (Saturniidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Samia borneensis (Rebel 1925), p. 299]. 
   Samia yayukae - Paukstadt, Peigler & Paukstadt 1993 (Saturniidae):
   [Removal from synonymy, Samia kikibudiamini Paukstadt, Paukstadt &
   Suhardjono 2002, p. 299]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14805039517

DT Article
TI A review of the Pachyprotasis pallidistigma species group (Hymenoptera:
   Tenthredinidae) from China, with descriptions of three new species.
AU Zhong, Yihai
   Wei, Meicai (weimc@126.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3242
PS 1-38
PD 21 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3242.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03242p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Chinese species of the Pachyprotasis pallidistigma group are revised
   and a key to the world species of the group is provided. Three new
   species of the group from China are described: P. bilineata sp. nov.
   (Yunnan), P. sichuanensis sp. nov. (Sichuan), P. shennongjiai sp. nov.
   (Hubei). The previously known species of the group are revised.

DT Article
TI Petrodessus conatus sp. n., a new genus and species of Bidessini from
   hygropetric habitats in tropical Australia (Coleoptera: Dytiscidae:
   Hydroporinae).
AU Miller, Kelly B. (kbmiller@unm.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3242
PS 62-67
PD 21 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3242.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03242p067.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Petrodessus conatus sp. n., new genus and species, is described from
   hygropetric habitats in northeastern Australia. The genus is similar to
   Uvarus Guignot, 1939 or Microdessus Young, 1967 in lacking a transverse
   occipital line, a transverse carina on elytral epipleuron at the humeral
   angle and having both basal elytral and pronotal striae. The genus
   differs from these in having the anterior margin of the clypeus
   distinctly modified, flattened and anteriorly produced. This character
   state is somewhat more like that in Clypeodytes Regimbart, 1894,
   Leiodytes Guignot, 1936, Neoclypeodytes Young, 1967, but Petrodessus n.
   gen. differs from these in lacking a transverse occipital line and
   having the basal elytral and pronotal striae distinctly and strongly
   impressed. This is the first hygropetric diving beetle described from
   Australia.
C1 Miller, Kelly B.; Department of Biology and Museum of Southwestern
   Biology, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131-0001, USA, USA.
EM kbmiller@unm.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Petrodessus conatus [Queensland /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Dytiscidae
OR Petrodessus (Dytiscidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Bidessini, Type species
   Petrodessus conatus, p. 63]. 
   Petrodessus conatus (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 65].

DT Article
TI A redescription of Carcharhinus dussumieri and C. sealei, with
   resurrection of C. coatesi and C. tjutjot as valid species
   (Chondrichthyes: Carcharhinidae).
AU White, William T.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3241
PS 1-34
PD 21 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3241.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03241p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A taxonomic re-evaluation of the Carcharhinus sealei-dussumieri group
   using meristic and morphological data revealed that this group consists
   of 5 species. Two species, Carcharhinus coatesi (Whitley, 1939) from
   northern Australia and probably New Guinea and C. tjutjot (Bleeker,
   1852) from Indonesian to Taiwan, are resurrected as valid species and
   together with C. dussumieri and C. sealei are redescribed. Garrick's
   lectotype designation of C. dussumieri and C. tjutjot are retained. A
   neotype for C. sealei, collected from the same locality as the holotype
   which was destroyed during World War II, is designated. A fifth,
   possibly undescribed species (Carcharhinus sp.) is also noted from the
   Western Indian Ocean and its affinities briefly discussed. The four
   redescribed species are very similarly morphologically but can be
   distinguished by a combination of meristic, morphological, dental and
   colour characters. The most important characters for distinguishing
   these species are: vertebral counts, tooth counts, tooth morphology,
   shape of first dorsal and pectoral fins, second dorsal fin colouration,
   and mouth width. Two independent molecular studies have produced results
   which closely correlate with and support the findings of this study.
C1 White, William T.; CSIRO Marine and Atmospheric Research, Wealth from
   Oceans Flagship, GPO Box 1538, Hobart, Tasmania, 7001, Australia,
   Australia.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis;
   Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Biometrics; General morphology;
   Marine zones
DE Carcharhinus sealei-dussumieri group [Meristic morphometrics / Meristic
   characters / systematics] [General morphology / Morphological characters
   / ] [Indian Ocean / Indo-Pacific region / distribution] [Pacific Ocean /
    / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes, Elasmobranchii,
   Carcharhiniformes, Carcharhinidae
OR Carcharhinus coatesi - (Whitley 1939) (Carcharhinidae): [Redescription,
   P. 4; Removal from synonymy, With Carcharhinus dussumieri (Mueller &
   Henle 1839), p. 3]. 
   Carcharhinus dussumieri - (Mueller & Henle 1839) (Carcharhinidae):
   [Redescription, P. 13; Removal from synonymy, Carcharhinus coatesi
   (Whitley 1939), p. 3; Removal from synonymy, Carcharhinus tjutjot
   (Bleeker 1852), p. 23]. 
   Carcharhinus dussumieri subgroup (Carcharhinidae): [New species group,
   P. 30]. 
   Carcharhinus dussumieri-sealei complex (Carcharhinidae): [Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, P. 27; Key to species, P. 32]. 
   Carcharhinus sealei - (Pietschmann 1913) (Carcharhinidae):
   [Redescription, P. 19]. 
   Carcharhinus sealei subgroup (Carcharhinidae): [New species group, P.
   30]. 
   Carcharhinus sealei-dussumieri group (Carcharhinidae): [Revision, P. 3].
   
   Carcharhinus tjutjot - (Bleeker 1852) (Carcharhinidae): [Redescription,
   P. 25; Removal from synonymy, With Carcharhinus dussumieri (Mueller &
   Henle 1839), p. 23]. 
   Carcharias (Prionodon) dussumieri - Mueller & Henle 1839
   (Carcharhinidae): [Lectotype, Designation by Garrick retained, p. 11]. 
   Carcharias (Prionodon) tjutjot - Bleeker 1852 (Carcharhinidae):
   [Lectotype, Designation by Garrick retained, p. 23]. 
   Carcharias sealei - Pietschmann 1913 (Carcharhinidae): [Neotype
   designated, P. 18].

DT Article
TI Records of species of the hippolytid genus Lebbeus White, 1847
   (Crustacea: Decapoda: Caridea) from hydrothermal vents in the Pacific
   Ocean, with descriptions of three new species.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
   Tsuchida, Shinji
   Segonzac, Michel
SO Zootaxa
VL 3241
PS 35-63
PD 21 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3241.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03241p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Five species of the hippolytid shrimp genus Lebbeus White, 1847 are
   reported from various deep-water hydrothermal vent sites in the Pacific
   Ocean: L. laurentae Wicksten, 2010 from the East Pacific Rise
   13[degree]N; L. wera Ahyong, 2009 from the Brothers Seamount, Kermadec
   Ridge, New Zealand; L. pacmanus sp. nov. from the Manus Basin, Bismarck
   Sea; L. shinkaiae sp. nov. from the Okinawa Trough, Japan; and L.
   thermophilus sp. nov. from the Manus and Lau basins, southwestern
   Pacific. Lebbeus laurentae is fully redescribed because the original and
   subsequent descriptions are not totally detailed. Differentiating
   characters among the three new species and close allies are discussed.
   Previous records of Lebbeus species from hydrothermal vents are
   reviewed.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba, 955-2
   Aoba-cho, Chuo-ku, Chiba, 260-8682, Japan, Japan.

   Lebbeus shinkaiae [North Pacific / Japan / New species].

   Distribution; new record; systematics] [South Pacific / New Zealand,
   Kermadec Ridge, Brothers Seamount / ].

   taxa, P. 58].

   Lebbeus thermophilus (Natantia): [Sp nov, South Pacific, P. 51]. 
   Lebbeus wera - Ahyong 2009 (Natantia): [New record].

TI Two new species of the genus Mallinella Strand, 1906 (Araneae:
   Zodariidae) from China.
AU Zhang, Feng (dudu06042001@163.com)

   Jia, Xiao-Mei

AB Two new species of the spider genus Mallinella are reported from China:

DT Article
TI [Myrmica vandeli (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in Central Bohemia.]
FT Myrmica vandeli (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) ve strednich Cechach.
AU Bezdecka, Pavel (bezdecka@muzeum.ji.cz) 
   Bezdeckova, Klara
SO Zapadoceske Entomologicke Listy
VL 3
PS 30-31
PD Mar 21 2012
PY 2012
LA Czech
U1 0
U2 0
AB The first finding of ant Myrmica vandeli Bondroit, 1920 in Central
   Bohemia is presented. A mixed colony of M. vandeli and M. scabrinodis
   Nylander, 1846 was found in a military area Brdy, near the Padrt'ske
   rybniky ponds. The nest was situated in a clump of sedge (Carex sp.),
   with a small solarium. The findings of such mixed colonies are scarce
   and are known mainly from the edges of the known area of M. vandeli
   distribution in Europe.

   58601, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.

   Republic / Central Bohemia / ].

   Republic / Central Bohemia / ].

DT Article
TI A new species of fig-feeding Lonchaeidae (Diptera: Schizophora) from
   India and a checklist for the family in the Indian sub-continent.
AU MacGowan, Iain (iain.macgowan@snh.gov.uk) 
   Razak, Nakeer
   Rotheray, Graham E.
   Ahmad, Irfan
SO Zootaxa
VL 3242
PS 47-52
PD 21 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3242.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03242p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of Lonchaeidae, Silba lashker sp. nov. is described from
   specimens reared from figs in Jammu and Kashmir, India. The adult and
   larvae are described and comparisons are made with other species in the
   genus. A checklist for the Indian sub-continent is provided which lists
   twenty four species in four genera including one new species and a
   further four species recorded from the sub-continent for the first time.
   The family Lonchaeidae is reported for the first time from the
   biodiversity hotspot region of the Kashmir valley.
C1 MacGowan, Iain; Scottish Natural Heritage, Battleby, Redgorton, Perth,
   PH1 3EW, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

   Silba lashker [Jammu and Kashmir /  / New species].

DT Article
TI Nomenclatural changes in Neotropical Tracheini with the description of
   Hylaeogena aeneonitens sp. nov. (Coleoptera: Buprestidae) from the
   Orinoco basin in Venezuela.
AU Hornburg, Michael (mihornburg@t-online.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3242
PS 53-61
PD 21 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3242.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03242p061.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Investigations of specimens belonging to the genus Hylaeogena
   Obenberger, 1923 from South America and especially from Venezuela and
   corresponding types in European institutional collections has led to the
   detection of a number of new synonyms and new combinations. These
   proposed nomenclatural changes are for species in the genera Hylaeogena
   Obenberger, 1923 and Pachyschelus Solier, 1833. The following
   nomenclatural changes are proposed: Hylaeogena atroviridis (Fisher,
   1922) = H. insidiosa Cobos, 1978 syn. nov. = H. venezuela Bellamy, 1996
   syn. nov., Hylaeogena capitata (Kerremans, 1903) comb. nov., Hylaeogena
   cincta (Waterhouse, 1889) = H. circumciliata Cobos, 1967 syn. nov.,
   Hylaeogena circularis (Kerremans, 1899) = H. bruchi (Kerremans, 1903)
   syn. nov. = H. scutellaris Obenberger, 1925 syn. nov., Hylaeogena
   circumdata (Kerremans, 1897) comb. nov. = H. achardi Obenberger, 1925
   syn. nov., Hylaeogena circumscripta (Kerremans, 1903) = H. bryanti
   Thery, 1940 syn. nov., Hylaeogena speculum (Klug, 1827) = H. cordieri
   Obenberger, 1923 syn. nov., and Pachyschelus lunifer Waterhouse, 1889
   comb. nov. Lectotype and paralectotype for H. speculum (Klug) are
   designated. Hylaeogena aeneonitens sp. nov. from the Orinoco basin in
   Venezuela is described and illustrated. Furthermore, new country records
   for the occurrence of the genus Hylaeogena in Venezuela are given.

PT J
AN ZOOR14807047701
PM 22436461
DT Article
TI Myxobolus groenlandicus n. sp (Myxozoa) distorting skeletal structures
   and musculature of Greenland halibut Reinhardtius hippoglossoides
   (Teleostei: Pleuronectidae).
AU Buchmann, Kurt (kub@life.ku.dk) 
   Skovgaard, Alf
   Kania, Per W.
SO Diseases of Aquatic Organisms
VL 98
IS 2
PS 133-141
PD Mar 20 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 16
AB A specimen of Greenland halibut Reinhardtius hippoglossoides (Walbaum,
   1792) caught on the west coast of Greenland (Qasigiannguit) was found to
   possess serious pathological changes in the body musculature. A series
   of cartilaginous cylindrical structures organized symmetrically at the
   position of the proximal pterygiophores had changed the musculature and
   produced irreversible distortions (cavities and holes) in the fillet of
   the processed fish, leaving it with no value for the industry.
   Histopathological investigation showed that these structures consisted
   of hypertrophic cartilage containing numerous myxospore-producing
   plasmodia. Morphometric and molecular analyses of the parasites showed
   that both spore morphology and rDNA sequences complied with
   characteristics of the genus Myxobolus, but no full affiliation with a
   known species could be found. The parasite is a previously undescribed
   species, and the name Myxobolus groenlandicus n. sp. is assigned to this
   new myxobolid.
C1 Buchmann, Kurt; Univ Copenhagen, Fac Life Sci, Copenhagen, DK-1168,
   Denmark, Denmark.
EM kub@life.ku.dk
RI Skovgaard, Alf/B-5684-2009
OI Buchmann, Kurt/0000-0002-2747-237X
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0177-5103
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones
DE Myxobolus groenlandicus [Piscean hosts / Reinhardtius hippoglossoides /
   New parasite species] [Arctic Ocean / Greenland / New species from
   piscean host]. 
   Reinhardtius hippoglossoides [Myxozoan parasites / Myxobolus
   groenlandicus / New parasite species] [Arctic Ocean / Greenland / New
   myxozoan parasite species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Pleuronectiformes, Pleuronectidae, Myxozoa, Myxosporea, Bivalvulida
OR Reinhardtius hippoglossoides (Pleuronectidae): [Host]. 
   Myxobolus groenlandicus (Bivalvulida): [Sp nov, Greenland (marine),
   Parasite of Reinhardtius hippoglossoides (Pisces), p. 136; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807047701
OA Bronze
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14805037358
DT Article
TI Review of the brachypterous, micropterous, and apterous Braconidae of
   the cyclostome lineage (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonoidea) from the Palearctic
   Region.
AU Belokobylskij, Sergey A. (doryctes@yahoo.com) 
   Kula, Robert R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3240
PS 1-62
PD 20 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03240p062.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03240p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The Palearctic species of Braconidae with brachypterous, micropterous,
   or apterous modification are discussed. The following new species are
   described: Chremylus planispinus Belokobylskij (France, Algeria),
   Chremylus algecirasusBelokobylskij (Spain), Pambolus erogolus
   Belokobylskij (Mongolia), Pambolus ovchinnikovi Belokobylskij
   (Kyrgyzstan), Hormius stauropolicus Belokobylskij (Russia (North
   Caucasus)), Bracon (Habrobracon) barbieriBelokobylskij (Algeria), and
   Panerema kamtshatica Belokobylskij (Russia (Kamchatka)). The following
   species are redescribed: Heterospilus hemipterus (Thomson) (male and
   female), Chremylus pomonellae (Atanasov) (male, female and macropterous
   form), Hormius minialatus Tobias (female), and Aleiodes (Chelonorhogas)
   hemipterus Marshall (male and female). Lituania brachyptera
   Jakimavicius, 1968 is a new synonym of Eurybolus hemipterus Thomson,
   1892. Chremylus pomonellae (Atanasov), new combination, is transferred
   from Rhyssalus. Aleiodes hemipterus is placed in the subgenus
   Chelonorhogas Enderlein. Asobara subalata (Zaykov&Fischer) is returned
   from Phaenocarpa Foerster. New distribution records are reported for
   Ecphylus (Sactopus) caudatus Ruschka, H. hemipterus, Rhaconotus
   hispanicus Belokobylskij, Pambolus tricolor (Ruthe), Hormius minialatus
   Tobias, A. (C.) hemipterus, and Pseudopezomachus kasparyaniTobias. A key
   for identifying all Palearctic flightless cyclostome braconid species,
   and the genera in which they are placed, is provided. A discussion about
   the diversity, morphological characters, and natural history of wing
   size reduction, and possible reasons for flightlessness, is provided.
C1 Belokobylskij, Sergey A.; Zoological Institute Russian Academy of
   Sciences, St. Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM doryctes@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology

   Appendages; Evolution; Locomotion; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Africa; Eurasia; Asia; Europe; France

DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision of Australian Pristoderus Hope (Coleoptera,
   Zopheridae).
AU Turco, Federica (federica.turco@qm.qld.gov.au) 
   Slipinski, Adam
   Lambkin, Christine L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3239
PS 1-34
PD 20 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3239.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03239p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Australian species of the genus Pristoderus Hope (Coleoptera,
   Zopheridae) are revised, with the description of nine new species; P.
   bellus sp. n., P. chloreus sp. n., P. cornutus sp. n., P. duvalensis sp.
   n., P. monteithi sp. n., P. occidentalis sp. n., P. occultus sp. n., P.
   spinosus sp. n. and P. tomentosus sp. n., and the re-description of nine
   species transferred herein to Pristoderus: P. elongatus comb. n., P.
   leai comb. n., P. pustulosus comb. n., P. queenslandicus comb. n.
   (Sparactus), P. productus comb. n., P. repandus comb. n. (Illestus), P.
   interruptus comb. n. (Ditoma), P. saccharatus comb. n. (Byrsax), P.
   zigzag comb. n. (Tarphiomimus) and P. phytophorus comb. n. (Dryptops). A
   new synonymy is assessed for Sparactus proximus Blackburn = Pristoderus
   interruptus (Erichson) syn. n. Lectotypes are herein designated for
   Sparactus costatus, S. elongatus, S. proximus, S. pustulosus, Illestus
   grouvellei, I. productus, I. repandus and paralectotypes for Sparactus
   costatus. All Australian species are illustrated with high-resolution
   photographs and a key to Australian and Papuan species is given.
   Detailed locality records are given for each species and distribution
   maps for Australia are provided.
C1 Turco, Federica; Queensland Museum, South Bank, PO Box 3300, South
   Brisbane, Queensland 4101, Australia, Australia.
EM federica.turco@qm.qld.gov.au

   Northern Territory, P. 15].

DT Article
TI New species of Ablabesmyia Johannsen from the Neotropical region: first
   report of a sponge-dwelling Tanypodinae.
AU Fusari, Livia Maria (liviafusari@gmail.com) 
   Oliveira, Caroline S. Neubern
   Hamada, Neusa
   Roque, Fabio O.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3239
PS 43-50
PD 20 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3239.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03239p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The larva, pupa and male of a new Neotropical chironomid species,
   Ablabesmyia tucuxi Neubern et Fusari sp. n., are described and
   illustrated. The larvae were found in freshwater sponge colonies of
   Drulia uruguayensis Bonetto et Ezcurra de Drago, 1968 and Oncosclera
   spinifera (Bonetto et Ezcurra de Drago, 1973) in Brazilian savanna
   streams. The morphological characteristics of the larval head and the
   presence of fine particles in the larval gut contents suggest that the
   larvae probably feed on the sponge tissue or on other animals that live
   inside the sponges.
C1 Fusari, Livia Maria; Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazonia (INPA),
   Coordenacao de Biodiversidade, Manaus, Amazonas, Brazil, Brazil.
EM liviafusari@gmail.com

   Fabio/B-5514-2013

DT Article
TI Notes on the Homoneura subgenera Euhomoneura, Homoneura and Minettioides
   from China (Diptera: Lauxaniidae).
AU Shi, Li (li_shi_lauxaniid@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Gaimari, Stephen D.
   Yang, Ding
SO Zootaxa
VL 3238
PS 1-22
PD 19 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3238.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03238p022.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The proportion of the width of the lower margin of the face and the
   height of the gena is proposed to sort several species of Homoneura Wulp
   in the two subgenera Euhomoneura Malloch and Homoneura where the
   anteriormost dc is located at the transverse suture of the mesonotum.
   One species Homoneura (Homoneura) litorea sp. nov. is described as new
   to science, and two species, Homoneura (Homoneura) stackelbergiana Papp
   and Homoneura (Minettioides) orientis (Hendel) are recorded from China
   for the first time. The former species is elevated out of synonymy from
   Homoneura (Homoneura) stackelbergi Czerny. The species Homoneura alini
   Hering is synonymized under Homoneura (Homoneura) brevicornis Kertesz. A
   key is presented to separate the five subgenera of Homoneura, and
   another key is presented to separate the Chinese species of the
   subgenera Euhomoneura and Minettioides Malloch.
C1 Shi, Li; College of Agronomy, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University,
   Hohot 010019, China, China.
EM li_shi_lauxaniid@yahoo.com.cn

AB A new tachinid species, Kuwanimyia zhanjiangensis sp. nov., is described
   and illustrated based on specimens collected from Zhanjiang in southern
   China. A modified key is provided for the identification of this species
   within the genus Kuwanimyia Townsend, 1916. Figures showing
   characteristics distinguishing K. zhanjiangensis sp. nov. from the
   closely related species K. conspersa Townsend (in particular, features
   of the male terminalia and male abdominal sternum 5) are included.

PT J
AN ZOOR14805037042
DT Article
TI Polymorphism in Languria taedata LeConte, its occurrence in coastal
   Louisiana Spartina marshes, and clarification of some Motschulsky
   languriine types (Coleoptera: Erotylidae: Languriinae).
AU Gimmel, Matthew L. (phalacrid@gmail.com) 
   Carlton, Christopher E.
   White, William H.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3237
PS 24-34
PD 16 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3237.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03237p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We clarify the diagnosis and geographic distribution of the widespread,
   variable eastern coastal species Languria taedata LeConte, 1854, in
   North America. After examining types and the range of variation and
   geographical distribution of the species, we propose synonymy of L.
   erythrocephalus Blatchley, 1924, with L. taedata, new synonymy. We
   report the discovery of an all-piceous form ("Form C"), the first of the
   genus, found primarily along the western Gulf Coast of the United
   States. The recognition of this form requires a modification to the most
   recent key to North American genera of Languriinae. The larvae of L.
   taedata feed within the stems of Spartina alterniflora Loisel (Poaceae).
   We provide additional notes on the occurrence of L. taedata in coastal
   marshes in Louisiana. The types of L. apicalis Motschulsky, L. nigriceps
   Motschulsky, L. obscura Motschulsky, and L. rufiventris are reexamined.
   A revised synonymic checklist is provided for North American Languriini.
C1 Gimmel, Matthew L.; Division of Entomology, Biodiversity Institute &
   Department of Ecology & Evolutionary Biology, University of Kansas, 1501
   Crestline Drive, Suite 140, Lawrence, KS 66045, USA, USA.
EM phalacrid@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Documentation; Publications; General morphology; Nutrition; Diet;
   Evolution; Variation; Morphological variation; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America
DE Languriini [Checklists /  / ] [Canada /  / ] [USA /  / ]. 
   Languriini taedata [General morphology /  / taxonomic implications]
   [Food plants / Spartina alterniflora / ] [Colour variation /  / ] [USA /
    / distribution]. 
   Languriini taedata form. c [USA /  / New form]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cucujoidea,
   Languriidae
OR Acropteroxys gracilis (Languriidae): [Removal from synonymy, Languria
   obscura Motschulsky 1860, p. 32]. 
   Languria apicalis - Motschulsky 1860 (Languriidae): [Status, P. 32]. 
   Languria erythrocephalus - Blatchley 1924 (Languriidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 26]. 
   Languria mozardi - Latreille 1807 (Languriidae): [Syn nov, Languria
   obscura Motschulsky 1860, p. 33]. 
   Languria nigriceps - Motschulsky 1860 (Languriidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 32]. 
   Languria obscura - Motschulsky 1860 (Languriidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Acropteroxys gracilis, p. 32]. 
   Languria taedata - LeConte 1854 (Languriidae): [Syn nov, Languria
   erythrocephalus Blatchley 1924, p. 25]. 
   Languriini (Languriidae). 
   Languriini taedata (Languriidae). 
   Languriini taedata form. c (Languriidae): [New form, P. 30].

TI Phylogeny and description of Eknomia, a morphologically unusual new
   genus of Neotropical Cryptinae (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae), with three
   new species.
AU Santos, Bernardo F.
   Aguiar, Alexandre P. (aguiar.2@osu.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3237
PS 35-52
PD 16 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3237.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03237p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Cryptini Eknomia Santos et Aguiar gen. nov. is proposed, described,
   and cladistically compared with representative species of 40 outgroup
   genera from twelve cryptine subtribes. A total of 98 morphological
   characters were evaluated. All analyses, conducted in TNT under implied
   and equal weighting, clearly suggest that Eknomia is a monophyletic
   group and can be treated as a distinct genus. Its likely sister group,
   however, varied among different analyses and could not be ascertained.
   The relationships of the new genus are therefore unclear, and because of
   this it is not assigned to any of the currently recognized subtribes.
   Eknomia can be diagnosed mainly by the anterior transverse carina of
   propodeum entirely absent; propodeum more or less uniformly strigate;
   clypeus almost entirely flattened; ovipositor stout, with compressed,
   minutely serrate flange at apex of dorsal valve, subapically crossed by
   a subvertical line; first metasomal spiracle placed at tergite midlength
   or nearly so; and hind margin of metanotum with tooth-like projections.
   The species E. nigra Santos et Aguiar, sp. nov., E. rubra Santos et
   Aguiar, sp. nov. and E. propodeator Santos et Aguiar, sp. nov. are
   described and illustrated. The genus is recorded from Colombia to
   southern Brazil.

TI A new species of amphipod, Photis inornatus sp. nov. (Corophiidea,
   Photidae) from a 'Haploops community' in Brittany.
AU Myers, Alan A. (bavayia@gmail.com) 
   Rigolet, Carine
   Thiebaut, Eric
   Dubois, Stanislas F.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3236
PS 55-61
PD 16 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3236.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03236p061.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB A new species of Photis, P. inornatus sp. nov., is described and figured
   from a Haploops community between 20 and 35 m depth in shallow waters
   from South Brittany, in the bay of Concarneau, northernmost part of the
   Bay of Biscay. This species was consistently found in macrobenthic
   samples extracted from the muddy Haploops community but not in
   surrounding muddy environment. An updated identification key is provided
   for European Atlantic and Mediterranean species of Photis.

TI New Australasian Zalmoxidae (Opiliones: Laniatores) and a new case of
   male polymorphism in Opiliones.
AU Sharma, Prashant P. (psharma@fas.harvard.edu.) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3236
PS 1-35
PD 16 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3236.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03236p035.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Six new species of litter-inhabiting harvestmen, four from New Caledonia
   and two from Australia, in the genus Zalmoxis Sorensen, 1886 (Opiliones:
   Laniatores: Zalmoxidae) are described and illustrated using light
   microscropy and SEM. A molecular phylogeny including these and related
   species indicates that the New Caledonian Zalmoxis are monophyletic,
   though the morphology of one species is consistent with the apomorphies
   of Metazalmoxis Roewer, 1912. Accordingly, Zalmoxis Sorensen, 1886 is
   considered the senior synonym of Metazalmoxis Roewer, 1912 new synonymy.
   Zalmoxis therefore remains the sole zalmoxid genus outside of the
   Neotropics. The new species add significantly to the known morphological
   diversity of Zalmoxidae, specifically in the case of one species from
   Queensland, Australia, with polymorphic males[long dash]the first such
   record for the superfamily Zalmoxoidea.

TI Taxonomic notes on some Cheilostomata (Bryozoa) from Madeira.
AU Berning, Bjoern (b.berning@landesmuseum.at) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3236
PS 36-54
PD 16 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3236.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03236p054.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Five species of cheilostome Bryozoa from the Madeiran archipelago, which
   were all introduced during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, are
   figured and redescribed following examination of the type specimens:
   Schizomavella noronhai (Norman), Saevitella peristomata (Waters),
   Phaeostachys schmitzi (Norman), Plesiocleidochasma porcellanum (Busk),
   and Stephanollona contracta (Waters). One species, previously recorded
   as Microporella decorata (Reuss), which is a fossil from the Miocene
   Paratethyan region nowadays placed in the genus Calloporina Neviani, is
   newly described as Calloporina mariae. The genus Schedocleidochasma
   Soule, Soule&Chaney is synonymised with Plesiocleidochasma Soule,
   Soule&Chaney, and the generic diagnoses of Calloporina Neviani,
   Saevitella Bobies and Plesiocleidochasma are amended.

TI Description of Neodolichodorus hainanensis n. sp. (Nematoda:
   Dolichodoridae) from rhizosphere soil of golf turf in China.
AU Xu, Chun-Ling
   Xie, Hui (xiehui@scau.edu.cn) 
   Li, Yu
SO Zootaxa
VL 3236
PS 62-68
PD 16 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3236.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03236p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Neodolichodorus hainanensis n.sp. is described from China, extracted
   from soil around turf in a golf course. N. hainanensisn.sp. is
   characterized by having a conspicuous offset cephalic region with 6[long
   dash]7 striae, divided into 4 lobes; stylet a little shorter (82[long
   dash]100 [mu]m) than most species in this genus; lateral field with four
   incisures, areolated, with outer lateral field regularly crossed by
   every second external stria at most of body length, and inner lateral
   field partly or wholly irregularly crossed by extending external striae;
   subconoid tail with rounded terminus; gubernaculum and spicule slightly
   protruding from cloaca, middle bursa lobe small with a bifid extremity
   in ventral view.

DT Article
TI Peduncular attached secondary tiering acrotretoid brachiopods from the
   Chengjiang fauna: Implications for the ecological expansion of
   brachiopods during the Cambrian explosion.
AU Wang, Haizhou
   Zhang, Zhifei (elizf@nwu.edu.cn) 
   Holmer, Lars E.
   Holmer, E.
   Hu, Shixue
   Wang, Xiangren
   Li, Guoxiang
SO Palaeogeography Palaeoclimatology Palaeoecology
VL 323-325
PS 60-67
PD Mar 15 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB Brachiopods are usually thought to contribute little to the tiering
   complexity from the Paleozoic to the Recent, mainly due to the fact that
   their recent representatives live primarily in lower tiers directly
   above or below the water-sediment interface. Here we present the first
   and oldest record of varied levels of secondary tiering in minute
   brachiopods attached by exceptionally preserved thread-like pedicles
   around the branched fronds of the algae-like Malongitubus kuangshanensis
   Hu, 2005. The specimens illustrated herein were recovered from the
   Chengjiang fauna (Series 2, Stage 3) in the Lower Cambrian Heilinpu
   Formation at the Kuangshan section in Malong County, Yunnan Province,
   southern China. The micro-morphology and oval outline of the attached
   brachiopods demonstrate that they can be assigned to acrotretoid
   brachiopods (Linguliformea, Lingulata, Acrotretoidea), described here as
   Kuangshanotreta malungensis gen. et sp. nov. This is the first report on
   the occurrence of acrotretoid brachiopods in the Lower Cambrian muddy
   deposits from southern China. The posterior margins of the
   Kuangshanotreta shells are invariably either in direct contact with, or
   directed towards, and then in situ attached to the algal frond of M.
   kuangshanensis, indicating a secondary tiering in the ecological
   structure of Early Cambrian brachiopods. The acrotretoid
   Kuangshanotreta/algae malongitubus association represents both the first
   and oldest evidence into the enigmatic paleoecology of the diverse
   acrotretoid linguliformean stock that comprises an important component
   of the Cambrian evolutionary fauna, and sheds light on medium-high
   levels of secondary tiering (+5 to +10 cm) Cambrian soft substrate
   suspension-feeding communities. When compared to other Chengjiang
   brachiopods, the miniature morphology and concomitant weight reduction
   of the shell of K. malungensis may be a good adaption to a suspended
   epifaunal tiering life style. We infer that the diversification of
   micromorphic and miniaturized acrotretoids that occurred from the Middle
   Cambrian to Early Ordovician may be the result of the increased
   availability of habitable surfaces provided by high levels of tiering in
   new types of ecological spaces. [copyright] 2012 Elsevier B.V. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Zhang, Zhifei; NW Univ Xian, Early Life Inst, 229 Taibaibei Rd, Xian,
   710069, China, China.
EM elizf@nwu.edu.cn
RI Holmer, Lars/I-9162-2012; Holmer, Lars/N-7736-2019
OI Holmer, Lars/0000-0003-3629-0049; Holmer, Lars/0000-0003-3629-0049
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine
   &Freshwater Biology
SN 0031-0182
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Associations;
   Ecology; Habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China;
   Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Acrotretoidea [Pedicle / Thread-like peduncle attachment / Algal
   commensals; new record; systematics] [Commensalism / Malongitubus
   kuangshanensis (alga) / ] [Distribution within habitat / Secondary
   tiering / ] [Marine habitat /  / ] [Yunnan / Malong County / ] [Cambrian
   / Lower Cambrian / ]. 
   Kuangshanotreta [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
   Kuangshanotreta malungensis [Commensalism / Malongitubus kuangshanensis
   (Alga) / New commensal species] [Yunnan /  / new species; algal

TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates

   Kuangshanotreta - Zhang, Holmer & Hu 2012 (Brachiopoda): [Gen nov, Of

   Cambrian; Fossil]. 
   Kuangshanotreta malungensis - Zhang, Holmer & Hu 2012 (Brachiopoda): [Sp

   (Alga), p. 66; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new vole from Xizang, China and the molecular phylogeny of the genus
   Neodon (Cricetidae: Arvicolinae).
AU Liu, Shao Ying (Shaoyliu@163.com) 
   Sun, Zhi Yu
   Liu, Yang
   Wang, Hao
   Guo, Peng
   Murphy, Robert W.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3235
PS 1-22
PD 15 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3235.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03235p022.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During a faunal survey in southern Xizang, we collected 27 specimens of
   voles that could not be identified as any known species in the
   Arvicolinae. These specimens shared the following morphological
   characteristics, not corresponding with any other arvicoline species:
   the first lower molar possessed five closed triangles, the third upper
   molar exhibited either four or three inner angles, and the tails of all
   specimens measured 30% of the body length. Their proximal baculum of the
   glans was very sturdy and trumpet-shaped, the distal baculum was
   tongue-like and sturdy, and the lateral bacula were very short.
   Molecular phylogenetic analyses based on nucleotide sequences of the
   mitochondrial cytochrome b (cyt b) gene clustered these specimens as a
   distinct lineage within the genus Neodon. According to the morphological
   and molecular data, we described them as a new species, Neodon
   linzhiensis. Our phylogenetic analysis strongly supported that Lasio-
   podomys fuscus, Phaiomys leucurus, Neodon sikimensis, N. irene and the
   new species formed a monophyletic group, not including N. juldaschi. We
   suggested that L. fuscus and P. leucurus should be transferred to Neodon
   and that N. juldaschi should be removed from this genus. Following our
   new delineation of Neodon, we proposed a redefinition of the morpho-
   logical diagnostic characters of the genus.
C1 Liu, Shao Ying; Sichuan Academy of Forestry, 44# Xia Sha he Pu Street,
   Chengdu 610066, Sichuan, China, China.
EM Shaoyliu@163.com
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology

   Taxonomic position; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China

   /  / ]. 
   Neodon linzhiensis [Xizang /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae
OR Blanfordimys (Muridae): [Status, P. 15]. 
   Blanfordimys juldaschi - (Severtzov 1879) (Muridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Neodon, p. 10]. 
   Lasiopodomys fuscus - (Buchner 1889) (Muridae): [Referred to, Neodon, p.
   10]. 
   Neodon - Horsfield 1841 (Muridae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 16]. 
   Neodon fuscus - (Buchner 1889) (Muridae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Lasiopodomys, p. 10]. 
   Neodon juldaschi - (Severtzov 1879) (Muridae): [Referred to,

   Neodon leucurus - (Blyth 1863) (Muridae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Phaiomys, p. 10].

   Phaiomys leucurus - (Blyth 1863) (Muridae): [Referred to, Neodon, p.

AN ZOOR14805036652
DT Article
TI Algerophilus, a neglected lineage of Western Mediterranean centipedes
   (Chilopoda: Geophilidae).
AU Bonato, Lucio (lucio.bonato@unipd.it) 
   Voigtlaender, Karin
   Minelli, Alessandro
SO Zootaxa
VL 3235
PS 23-34
PD 15 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3235.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03235p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Among the diverse geophilomorph centipedes inhabiting the Mediterranean
   region, we recognise and describe a morphologically distinct lineage
   that has long been misunderstood and neglected. This lineage, which
   deserves to be treated as a distinct genus (Algerophilus Brolemann,
   1925), is broadly similar to Geophilus Leach, 1814 and Tuoba Chamberlin,
   1920, but differs from them mainly in the more elongate head and
   forcipular segment and the coxal pores clustered into elonga- ted
   pouches. All published and new records are from Western Mediterranean
   regions including the Baetic Mountains, Ibiza, the Atlantic Moroccan
   coastal plain, and the Tell Atlas. A single species A. hispanicus
   (Meinert, 1870) (= Nesogeophilus mateui Machado, 1953, syn. n.) is
   recognised on morphological characters, but some geographical varia-
   tion has been detected in the relative elongation of antennae and
   forcipules and in the number of trunk segments. The evolutionary
   distinctness and geographical distribution highlighted here for
   Algerophilus mirror those of other divergent lineages of soil arthropods
   that are endemic to the Western Mediterranean region.
C1 Bonato, Lucio; Universita di Padova, Dipartimento di Biologia, via U.
   Bassi 58 B, I-35131 Padova, Italy, Italy.
EM lucio.bonato@unipd.it
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Palaearctic region
DE Algerophilus [Africa / Western Mediterranean region / Distribution; new
   record; systematics] [Eurasia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Myriapods
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Myriapoda, Chilopoda
OR Algerophilus - Brolemann 1925 (Chilopoda): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14805036654
DT Article
TI The taxonomic status of Melanophryniscus orejasmirandai Prigioni &
   Langone, 1987 "1986" (Anura: Bufonidae).
AU Baldo, Diego (diegobaldo@gmail.com) 
   Borteiro, Claudio
   Kolenc, Francisco
   Rosset, Sergio
   Prigioni, Carlos
   Martinez Debat, Claudio
SO Zootaxa
VL 3235
PS 45-61
PD 15 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3235.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03235p061.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Melanophryniscus orejasmirandai is a species of toad known only from two
   localities in southern Uruguay. This toad is the southernmost suggested
   taxon of the M. tumifrons group, whose species are characterized by a
   glandular frontal swelling on the snout. The study of the type series of
   M. orejasmirandai and of M. pachyrhynus, along with observations made on
   many specimens of both species suggested a close relationship between
   them. The analysis of the variation of snout-vent length, coloration
   pattern, relative size of the frontal swelling, and presence/absence of
   the metatarsal gland showed that characters previously used to separate
   both species resulted of no diagnostic value. Further comparison of the
   external morphology, osteological characters, and partial sequences of
   the cytochrome b gene indicated that M. orejasmirandai is a junior
   synonym of M. pachyrhynus. Melanophryniscus pachyrhynus is characterized
   by a reticulated orange ventral pattern which is shared only with M.
   peritus, from which it differs by its smaller size. The ornamentation of
   the nasal bones underlying the frontal swelling in M. pachyrhynus seems
   to be characteristic of the M. tumifrons group. An updated distribution
   map of M. pachyrhynus and some new localities are also provided.
C1 Baldo, Diego; Instituto de Herpetologia, Fundaciion Miguel Lillo, Miguel
   Lillo 251, 4000 San Miguel de Tucuman, Argentina, Argentina.
EM diegobaldo@gmail.com
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; General morphology; Genetics; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Melanophryniscus pachyrhynus [General morphology / External morphology /
   systematics] [Molecular genetics / Cytochrome b gene sequence / ]
   [Brazil /  / distribution] [Uruguay /  / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Bufonidae
OR Melanophryniscus pachyrhynus - (Miranda-Ribeiro 1920) (Bufonidae): [Syn
   nov, Melanophryniscus orejasmirandai Prigioni & Langone 1986, p. 54]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14805036654
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14805036281
DT Article
TI Siphonoecetini Just, 1983 (Crustacea, Amphipoda, Ischyroceridae) 9: New
   species in Rhinoecetes Just, 1983, Cephaloecetes gen. nov. and Neoecetes
   gen. nov. from the south-eastern Australian shelf.
AU Just, Jean (jean-just@mail.dk) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3234
PS 1-42
PD 14 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3234.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03234p042.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Six new species of Rhinoecetes Just, 1983, R. rhinoceros, R. dinoceros,
   R. brevirostris, R. coclearis, R. albomaculosus and R. meridianus, are
   described together with Cephaloecetes enigmaticus gen. nov., sp. nov.
   and Neoecetes conipes gen. nov., sp. nov. from eastern Australia from
   Moreton Bay in Queensland to Bass Strait and Tasmania. Cephaloecetes
   gen. nov. differs from Rhinoecetes by having the head front margin
   entire and a pseudorostrum arising underneath from the frons. Neoecetes
   gen. nov. differs from Rhinoecetes in having two robust setae instead of
   one on the posterior projection of gnathopod 2 carpus, a row of small
   accessory robust setae on pereopods 5 and 6 carpus instead of a single
   one, and uropod 3 ramus being conical instead of round. Keys to genera
   and species are given. A novel character, a pair of sternal papillae, is
   documented in Rhinoecetes and Cephaloecetes on the ventral surface of
   pereonite 7 in adult females. The distribution of the species is
   commented upon. The most diverse fauna of Siphonoecetini was found in
   Jervis Bay, New South Wales.
C1 Just, Jean; Museum of Tropical Queensland, 70-102 Flinders Street,
   Townsville QLD 4810, Australia, Australia.

DT Article
TI Gnathia masca sp. nov. (Crustacea, Isopoda, Gnathiidae) from Lizard
   Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia.
AU Farquharson, Charon
   Smit, Nico J. (nico.smit@nwu.ac.za) 
   Grutter, Alexandra S.
   Davies, Angela J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3233
PS 22-36
PD 14 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3233.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03233p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Gnathia masca sp. nov. is described from material collected off Coconut
   Beach, Lizard Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia. Males are
   characterised by a cephalosome with a shallow dorsal sulcus that
   stretches half its length, a slightly produced frontal border with two
   conical superior fronto-lateral processes and a conical inferior
   medio-frontal process. Male mandibles have 6 processes on the dentate
   blade and a distinct internal lobe with 6 or 7 crenulations and a single
   large distal process. Live males, females and larvae are characterized
   by brown pigmentation especially in the male where it forms a dark band
   that stretches between the eyes, giving it the appearance of a mask.
C1 Smit, Nico J.; Schol of Environmental Sciences and Development, Private
   Bag X6001, North-West University, Potchefstroom, 2520, South Africa,
   South Africa.
EM nico.smit@nwu.ac.za
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Peracarida, Isopoda

   Queensland (marine), Host not given, p. 23].

DT Article
TI Phylogeography of Dasia Gray, 1830 (Reptilia: Scincidae), with the
   description of a new species from southern India.
AU Harikrishnan, S.
   Vasudevan, Karthikeyan
   de Silva, Anslem
   Deepak, V.
   Kar, Niladri Bhusan
   Naniwadekar, Rohit
   Lalremruata, Albert
   Prasoona, K. Rebekah
   Aggarwal, Ramesh K. (rameshka@ccmb.res.in) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3233
PS 37-51
PD 14 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3233.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03233p051.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new tree skink species of the genus Dasia Gray, 1830, closely allied
   to Dasia haliana, is described from southern Western Ghats of India. The
   new species named, Dasia johnsinghi sp. nov. can be distinguished from
   all other congeners by morphological and molecular data. A related
   species, Dasia subcaeruleum, is re-described based on new material from
   a new locality in the Western Ghats. Mitochondrial rDNA-based
   phylogenetic analysis of the genus Dasia reveals the affinities of the
   south Indian and the Sri Lankan species with Southeast Asian ones. The
   biogeographic processes that might have led to the disjunct distribution
   of the entities in the genus are discussed. An updated key to the
   identification of spe- cies of the genus Dasia is provided.
C1 Aggarwal, Ramesh K.; Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology
   (CSIR-CCMB), Tarnaka, Hyderabad, India, India.
EM rameshka@ccmb.res.in
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Genetics; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Dasia [Molecular genetics / Mitochondrial rDNA sequence analysis /
   systematics] [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Asia
   /  / distribution]. 
   Dasia johnsinghi [Tamil Nadu /  / New species]. 
   Dasia subcaeruleum [Karnataka /  / New record].

AN ZOOR14805036272
DT Article
TI Three new species of Neoplecostomus (Teleostei: Siluriformes:
   Loricariidae) from the Upper Rio Parana basin of southeastern Brazil.
AU Roxo, Fabio F.
   Oliveira, Claudio
   Zawadzki, Claudio H.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3233
PS 1-21
PD 14 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3233.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03233p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB In this study, we describe three new species of the genus
   Neoplecostomus: N. bandeirante, from Salesopolis in the state of Sao
   Paulo, N. langeanii from Muzambinho, in the state of Minas Gerais, and
   N. botucatu from Botucatu, in the state of Sao Paulo. All of the
   described species are found in the Upper Rio Parana basin. The new
   species are different from each other and from their nominal congeners
   in their mitochondrial DNA sequences (COI), morphology and meristic
   traits, in addition to their color patterns. Morphologically, N.
   bandeirante can be distinguished from all congeners by the presence of
   moderate keels throughout the lateral series of plates and by a naked
   area between each mid-ventral and ventral plate that is greater in size
   than the length of these plates. Neoplecostomus botucatu is
   morphologically distinguished by a reduction of the adipose fin and the
   presence of dark spots that are distributed along the body.
   Neoplecostomus langeanii can be morphologically distinguished by the
   absence of hypertrophied odontodes and a swollen integument on the head,
   as well as by morphometric characteristics.
C1 Roxo, Fabio F.; Universidade Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Departamento de
   Morfolia, Laboratorio de Biologia e Genetica de Peixes, 18618-000
   Botucatu, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.
RI Oliveira, Claudio/D-7713-2012
OI Oliveira, Claudio/0000-0002-7010-8880

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   South America

   langeanii [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Neoplecostomus botucatu (Loricariidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 9]. 
   Neoplecostomus langeanii (Loricariidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 12].

DT Article
TI Description of a cave-dwelling species Duvalius karaormanicus sp. n.
   (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Trechinae) from the south-western part of the
   Republic of Macedonia.
AU Hristovski, Savco (slavco_h@pmf.ukim.mk) 
SO Entomologica Fennica
VL 22
IS 4
PS 262-267
PD Mar 13 2011(2012)
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species, Duvalius karaormanicus sp. n., in the subgenus
   Euduvalius, is described from the type locality: Mlecnik cave in the
   Karaorman Mountain in the south-western part of the Republic of
   Macedonia. This is the second cave-dwelling Duvalius and the sixth
   representative of the genus so far recorded from the Republic of
   Macedonia. Based on its diagnostic characters, the new species is found
   to be related to the species in the "gogalai" and "petrochilosi" groups.
   D. karaormanicus sp. n. occupies an intermediate position between the
   species from these two groups and is therefore placed in a separate
   "karaormanicus" species group.
C1 Hristovski, Savco; Fac Nat Sci & Math, Inst Biol, Arhimedova St 5,
   Skopje, 1000, Macedonia, Macedonia.
EM slavco_h@pmf.ukim.mk

AU Li, Yun

PS 44-61
PD 13 Mar 2012

LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Eight new Macrolycus are described: M. luteus sp. nov., M. mucronatus
   sp. nov., M. muyuensis sp. nov., M. quadrifidus sp. nov., M. rubineus
   sp. nov., M. venustus sp. nov. from China and M. extrusus sp. nov., M.

DT Article
TI Checklist of Dryinidae (Hymenoptera) from Guangdong Province, China,
   with descriptions of two new species.
AU Xu, Zaifu
   Olmi, Massimo (olmi@unitus.it) 
   Guglielmino, Adalgisa
   Chen, Huayan
SO Zootaxa
VL 3231
PS 1-28
PD 13 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3231.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03231p028.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Five subfamilies, 11 genera and 77 species of Dryinidae are listed from
   Guangdong Province. Two new species, Anteon pteromaculatum Xu, Olmi,
   Guglielmino&Chen, sp. nov. and Dryinus nanlingensis Xu, Olmi,
   Guglielmino&Chen, sp. nov. are described from Nanling National Nature
   Reserve. New synonymies are proposed for Dryinus indicus (Kieffer, 1914)
   (=Chlorodryinus koreanus Moczar, 1983, syn. nov.; Dryinus masneri Olmi,
   2009, syn. nov.), Gonatopus nearcticus (Fenton, 1927) (=Acrodontochelys
   sinensis Olmi, 1984, syn. nov.). Ten species, Anteon atrum Olmi, 1998,
   A. silvicolum Olmi, 1984, A. viraktamathi Olmi, 1987, Deinodryinus
   asiaticus Olmi, 1984, Dryinus krombeini Ponomarenko, 1981, Neodryinus
   sumatranus Enderlein, 1907, Gonatopus malesiae (Olmi, 1984), Gonatopus
   validus (Olmi, 1984), G. plebeius (Perkins, 1912), and G. asiaticus
   (Olmi, 1984) are newly recorded from China. Anteon nanlingense Xu,
   Olmi&He, 2011 is newly recorded from Indonesia. Twenty-seven species are
   newly recorded from Guangdong Province. Ten species, including new ones,
   are known from Guangdong Province only.

DT Article
TI Catalogue and bibliography of Afrotropical Psychodidae: Bruchomyiinae,
   Psychodinae, Sycoracinae and Trichomyiinae.
AU Kvifte, Gunnar Mikalsen (Gunnar.Kvifte@student.uib.no) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3231
PS 29-52
PD 13 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3231.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03231p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Afrotropical fauna of Psychodidae, subfamilies Bruchomyiinae,
   Psychodinae, Sycoracinae and Trichomyiinae is catalogued. A total of 174
   species in 27 genera are listed with full bibliographic citations and
   distributional data. Cryptotelmatoscopus Vaillant, 1982 is placed as a
   subgenus of Clogmia Enderlein, 1935, stat.nov.; Karakovounimerus Jezek,
   1990 is placed as a subgenus of Panimerus Eaton, 1904, stat.nov.;
   Orgaoclogmia Jezek&van Harten, 1996 is synonymised with
   Cryptotelmatoscopus Vaillant, 1982, syn.nov.; and Rhipidopsychoda
   Vaillant, 1991 is synonymised with Threticus Eaton, 1904 syn.nov.
   Telmatoscopus flagellifer Freeman, 1949, Mormia soelii Wagner&Andersen,
   2007 and Rhadinoscopus triangulatus Wagner, 1979 are transferred to
   Hemimormia Krek, 1971, comb.nov.; Telmatoscopus fuscipennis Tonnoir,
   1920 and Orgaoclogmia caboverdeana Jezek&van Harten, 1996 are
   transferred to Clogmia Enderlein, 1937, comb.nov.; Telmatoscopus
   pilosternatus Satchell, 1955 is transferred to Mormopericomiella
   Jezek&van Harten, 2002, comb.nov.; Copropsychoda bulbosa Jezek&van
   Harten, 2005, Falsologima verrucosa Jezek&van Harten, 2005, Psychana
   rujumensis Jezek&van Harten, 2005 and Psychodocha khoralkhwairensis
   Jezek&van Harten, 2009 are transferred to Psychoda Latreille, 1796
   comb.nov.; and Psychoda boettgeri Wagner, 1979 is transferred to
   Threticus Eaton, 1904 comb.nov. All nomenclatural changes are discussed.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Stenatkina Young, 1986 from China with comparative
   notes on the female genitalia (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Cicadellini).
AU Meng, Ze-Hong
   Yang, Mao-Fa (yangmaofa@sohu.com) 
   Li, Zi-Zhong
SO Zootaxa
VL 3231
PS 53-67
PD 13 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3231.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03231p067.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Stenatkina Young, 1986 is a sharpshooter genus that includes six
   species, three of them recorded from China. In this paper, two new
   species, S. moliensis sp. nov. and S. luteimacula sp. nov. are added. A
   key is given to distinguish all species of the genus. Descriptions and
   illustrations of the male and female genitalia of the new species and of
   other Chinese species are provided. S. heveli Young is newly recorded
   from China. Comparative notes on the female genitalia within Stenatkina
   are provided. The preliminary results show that the female genitalia
   provide useful features for distinguishing Stenatkina species.
C1 Yang, Mao-Fa; Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University, the
   Provincial Key Laboratory for Agricultural Pest Management of
   Mountainous Region, Guiyang, Guizhou, China, China.
EM yangmaofa@sohu.com

DT Article
TI A new species of Tephritis Latreille (Diptera: Tephritidae) from Iran.
AU Mohamadzade Namin, Saeed (mohamadzade@iauvaramin.ac.ir) 
SO Entomologica Fennica
VL 22
IS 4
PS 284-288
PD Mar 13 2011(2012)
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Tephritis nozarii sp. n. from East Azerbaijan Province (North West of
   Iran) is described and illustrated. It is similar to T. hendeliana
   Hering, T. hyosciami Linnaeus and T. multiguttata Becker in its pale
   brownish grey wing pattern, differing by the number of hyaline spots in
   marginal part of r1 cell and some other details of pattern. Cell r1 in
   T. nozarii sp. n. contains 3 subequally large spots (resembling some
   Campiglossa species), a character rarely encountered in Tephritis.
C1 Mohamadzade Namin, Saeed; Islamic Azad Univ, Varamin Pishva Branch,
   Varamin, Iran, Iran.
EM mohamadzade@iauvaramin.ac.ir
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0785-8760
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Tephritis nozarii [Plant hosts / Cirsium / New parasite species] [Iran /
    / New species from plant host]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Tephritidae
OR Tephritis hendeliana - Hering 1944 (Tephritidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 288]. 
   Tephritis hyosciami - (Linnaeus 1758) (Tephritidae): [Diagnostic

   P. 284].

DT Article
TI Taxonomy of the ant genus Pheidole Westwood (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in
   the Afrotropical zoogeographic region: definition of species groups and
   systematic revision of the Pheidole pulchella group.
AU Fischer, Georg (georg.fischer@gmx.de) 
   Garcia, Francisco Hita
   Peters, Marcell K.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3232
PS 1-43
PD 13 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3232.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03232p043.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB This paper is a starting point towards a much needed comprehensive
   taxonomic treatment of the genus Pheidole in the Afrotropical region.
   Despite its hyperdiversity, the taxonomy of this globally distributed
   ant genus is limited to important revisions for the New World and
   several Asian faunas. However, Pheidole of the Afrotropical
   zoogeographic region has never been revised. The most recent
   Afrotropical Pheidole species descriptions are fifty years old and many
   are considerably older. Identification keys are not available and many
   species descriptions are of limited diagnostic value. This calls for a
   series of taxonomic revisions in order to resolve the complicated
   taxonomic situation for the complete Afrotropical Pheidole fauna. In
   this paper the following preliminary morphological species groups for
   the Afrotropical region are defined: P. aurivillii group, P. excellens
   group, P. megacephala group, P. nigeriensis group, and P. speculifera
   group. We also establish and revise the P. pulchella group, which
   currently contains eleven species, of which seven are new. The four
   species described prior to this study are: P. pulchella Santschi, P. dea
   Santschi, P. nimba Bernard, and P. batrachorum Wheeler stat. rev., which
   is removed from synonymy under P. d e a and regains species status. The
   following new synonymy is proposed (senior synonym listed first): P.
   pulchella Santschi = P. pulchella achantella Santschi. The following
   seven species are described as new: P. christinae sp. n., P. darwini,
   sp. n., P. glabrella sp. n., P. heliosa sp. n., P. rebeccae sp. n., P.
   semide a sp. n. and P. setosa, sp. n. An illustrated key combining the
   minor and major worker subcastes is presented.
C1 Fischer, Georg; Systematic Zoology, Zoological Research Museum A Koenig,
   Adenaueralle 160, D-53113 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM georg.fischer@gmx.de
RI Fischer, Georg/G-2484-2015; Fischer, Georg/Y-3059-2019; Garcia,
   Francisco Hita/C-9636-2015
OI Fischer, Georg/0000-0002-0637-6485; Fischer, Georg/0000-0002-4033-2005;
   Garcia, Francisco Hita/0000-0003-4709-3083; Peters,
   Marcell/0000-0002-1262-0827
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   Pheidole christinae [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species] [Gabon /  / ]
   [Uganda /  / ]. 
   Pheidole darwini [Cameroon /  / New species] [Central African Republic /
    / ] [Gabon /  / ]. 
   Pheidole glabrella [Cameroon /  / New species] [Central African Republic
   /  / ] [Congo-Kinshasa /  / ] [Gabon /  / ]. 
   Pheidole heliosa [Cameroon /  / New species] [Ivory Coast /  / ]. 
   Pheidole rebeccae [Ghana /  / New species] [Ivory Coast /  / ]. 
   Pheidole semidea [Nigeria /  / New species]. 
   Pheidole setosa [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Formicoidea, Formicidae
OR Pheidole - Westwood 1841 (Formicidae). 
   Pheidole aurivillii group (Formicidae): [Diagnosis, P. 6]. 
   Pheidole batrachorum - Wheeler 1922 (Formicidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 14; Description, P. 15; Removal from synonymy, With Pheidole dea
   Santschi 1921, p. 14]. 
   Pheidole christinae (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Uganda, P. 17]. 
   Pheidole darwini (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Gabon, P. 19]. 
   Pheidole dea - Santschi 1921 (Formicidae): [Lectotype designated, P. 22;
   Description, P. 22; Removal from synonymy, Pheidole batrachorum Wheeler
   1922, p. 14]. 
   Pheidole excellens group (Formicidae): [Diagnosis, P. 6]. 
   Pheidole glabrella (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 26]. 
   Pheidole heliosa (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Ivory Coast, P. 29]. 
   Pheidole megacephala group (Formicidae): [Diagnosis, P. 6]. 
   Pheidole nigeriensis group (Formicidae): [Diagnosis, P. 7]. 
   Pheidole nimba - Bernard 1953 (Formicidae): [Description, P. 31]. 
   Pheidole pulchella - Santschi 1910 (Formicidae): [Description, P. 33;
   Syn nov, Pheidole pulchella var. achantella Santschi 1939, p. 33]. 
   Pheidole pulchella group (Formicidae): [Diagnosis, P. 7; Key to species,
   P. 9]. 
   Pheidole rebeccae (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Ivory Coast, P. 35].

PT J

DT Article
TI A new species of Bezzia Kieffer from Argentina (Diptera:
   Ceratopogonidae).
AU Spinelli, Gustavo R. (spinelli@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Ronderos, Maria M.
   Cazorla, Carla G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3232
PS 62-68
PD 13 Mar 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3232.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03232p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Bezzia ventanensis Spinelli, a new Neotropical species, is described and
   illustrated based on pupae and adults. Pupae were collected from muddy
   water from the edge of a stream margin in Sierra de la Ventana, Buenos
   Aires province, Argentina. Specimens were carried back to the laboratory
   and conditioned in vials until adult emergence. This new species is
   similar to Bezzia brevicornis (Kieffer), from which it can be mainly
   distinguished by the female adult bearing two well developed
   spermathecae, and by the pupal respiratory organ with 13[long dash]15
   spiracles.
C1 Spinelli, Gustavo R.; Division Entomologya, Museo de La Plata, CCT La
   Plata CONICET, Paseo del Bosque s/n, 1900 La Plata, Argentina,
   Argentina.
EM spinelli@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Bezzia ventanensis [Argentina /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

OR Bezzia ventanensis - Spinelli 2010 (Ceratopogonidae): [Sp nov,
   Argentina, P. 62].
