UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14812075999
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14805032321
PM 26467949
DT Article
TI Reticulitermes nelsonae, a New Species of Subterranean Termite
   (Rhinotermitidae) from the Southeastern United States.
AU Lim, Su Yee (bfor@uga.edu) 
   Forschler, Brian T.
SO Insects
VL 3
IS 1
PS 62-90
PD March 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mdpi.com/2075-4450/3/1/
AW http://www.mdpi.com/2075-4450/3/1/
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Reticulitermes nelsonae, a new species of Rhinotermitidae (Isoptera) is
   described based on specimens from Sapelo Island, GA, Thomasville, GA,
   Havelock, NC, and Branford, FL. Adult (alate) and soldier forms are
   described. Diagnostic characters are provided and incorporated into a
   supplemental couplet of a dichotomous key to the known species of
   Reticulitermes found in Georgia, USA.
C1 Lim, Su Yee; Household and Structural Entomology Laboratory, Department
   of Entomology, 413 Biosciences Building, 120 Cedar St., University of
   Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, USA, USA.
EM bfor@uga.edu
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 2075-4450
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Genetics; Evolution;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Reticulitermes [Molecular genetics / mtDNA COI & COII gene sequences / ]

PT J
AN ZOOR14805037446
DT Article
TI Spatial and temporal variability of fish community abundance and
   diversity off the coast of Campeche, Mexico.
FT Variabilidad espacial y temporal de la abundancia y diversidad de la
   comunidad de peces en la costa de Campeche, Mexico.
AU Ayala-Perez, Luis Amado (luayala@correo.xoc.uam.mx) 
   Teran-Gonzalez, Greicy Janet
   Flores-Hernandez, Domingo
   Ramos-Miranda, Julia
   Sosa-Lopez, Atahualpa
SO Latin American Journal of Aquatic Research
VL 40
IS 1
PS 63-78
PD March 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.lajar.cl/det_en.php?id=53
AW http://www.lajar.cl/pdf/imar/v40n1/Articulo_40_7.pdf
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 14
AB The fish community of the southern Gulf of Mexico is abundant and
   diverse, and its components are affected by the bycatch of the seabob
   shrimp fishery. The spatial and temporal abundance and diversity
   patterns of the fish community are described and analyzed in this paper,
   and the ecologically dominant species are identified. Monthly sampling
   was carried out from February 2006 to January 2007, at 37 sites located
   between the mouth of the Grijalva-Usumacinta system to the mouth of the
   Chumpan-Balchacah system inside the Terminos Lagoon, in the state of
   Campeche, southern Gulf of Mexico. Using an experimental trawl net, 444
   experimental hauls were done, and 26,386 individuals were caught with a
   joint weight of 407.1 kg. In total, 94 species were identified, grouped
   in 65 genera and 38 families. The abundance and diversity of the fish
   community was analyzed on spatial and temporal scales in terms of
   density (ind m-2), biomass (g m-2 ), average weight (g ind-1), diversity
   index (H'n), species richness (Dmg), and evenness (J'). The abundance
   was high in August and September at sites near the mouths of the
   Grijalva-Usumacinta and Palizada-Del Este systems. The most important
   species in terms of abundance was the catfish, Cathorops melanopus. The
   intervals of variation of the diversity range on a spatial scale were
   H'n = 0.5 to 2.8 bits; Dmg = 2.6 to 5.3 sp ind-1, and J' = 0.1 to 0.8
   bits. On a temporal scale, the intervals were: H'n = 1.8 to 2.6 bits;
   Dmg = 5.1 to 6.7 sp ind-1, and J' = 0.4 to 0.6 bits. Nine dominant
   species were identified, with 16,840 individuals and a joint weight of
   278.5 kg, equivalent to 63.8% of the total capture.
C1 Ayala-Perez, Luis Amado; Laboratorio de Ecologia Aplicada, Departamento
   EL Hombre y su Ambiente, Universidad Autonoma Metropolitana Xochimilco,
   Calz, Del Hueso 1100, Col Villaquietud Coyoacan 04960, Mexico, Mexico.
EM luayala@correo.xoc.uam.mx
RI Sosa-Lopez, Atahualpa/AAC-2541-2020
OI Sosa-Lopez, Atahualpa/0000-0002-0725-5028; Ayala Perez, Luis
   Amado/0000-0002-7876-9544
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0718-560X
BD Biometrics; Ecology; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Pisces [Weight /  / ] [Biomass /  / ] [Community structure /  / ] [Gulf
   of Mexico / Mexico, Campeche, Laguna de Terminos / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Pisces (Vertebrata).

TI Cobitis keyvani sp. nova - a New Species of Spined-loach from South of
   the Caspian Sea Basin (Teleostei: Cobitidae).
AU Mousavi-Sabet, Hamed (Mousavi-Sabet@guilan.ac.ir) 
   Yerli, Sedat V.
   Vatandoust, Saber
   Ozeren, Cevher
   Moradkhani, Zeynab
SO Turkish Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
VL 12
IS 1
PS 7-13
PD March 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.trjfas.org/issue_past.php?issue_id=39
AW http://www.trjfas.org/pdf/issue_12_01/0102.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Cobitis keyvani is a new species of spined-loach which is described from
   Talar River, south of the Caspian Sea basin, north of Iran. This new
   species is distinguished from Cobitis linea by one lamina circularis at
   the base of second ray of the male pectoral fins and from Cobitis taenia
   and Cobitis faridpaki by combination of the following characters: dorsal
   fin with 2- 3 unbranched and 6-7 branched soft rays; anal fin with 2-3
   unbranched 5-7 branched soft rays; caudal fin with 13-16 branched rays;
   one brownish streak across eye from the tip of nose, no streak on cheek;
   a big black spot smaller than eye diameter near the dorsal corner of the
   caudal fin base; pigmentation of longitudinal zones; third zone is
   reduced, and the fourth zone composed of 14-20 roundish to oval blotches
C1 Mousavi-Sabet, Hamed; Fisheries Department, Faculty of Natural
   Resources, University of Guilan, Sowmeh Sara, Iran, Iran.

DT Article
TI First record of the genus Strongyloides (Nematoda : Rhabditoidea)
   obtained from a fairy pitta, Pitta brachyura nympha.
AU Yoshino, Tomoo
   Hayakawa, Daisuke
   Yoshizawa, Miku
   Osa, Yuichi
   Asakawa, Mitsuhiko
SO Bulletin of the Tokushima Prefectural Museum
VL 22
PS 1-6
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two young individuals of fairy pitta, Pitta brachyura nympha, were
   rescued somewhere within Kochi Prefecture, Shikoku, Japan, and housed at
   the Wanpark Kochi Animal Land, Kochi city. Each died suddenly, on May
   31, 2008 and January 23, 2011, respectively. In the postmortem and
   helminthological examinations, four female parasitic nematode specimens
   were obtained from the small intestine of one of the birds. They were
   identified as Strongyloides sp. based on morphological characters.
   Several species of the genus Strongyloides have been recorded from wild
   birds and domestic poultry worldwide, including in Japan, but this is
   the first record of the nematode genus Strongyloides from P. b. nympha.
   We could not definitively identify the present specimens to species
   because they had not formed matured eggs.
C1 Yoshino, Tomoo; Department of Pathobiology, School of Veterinary
   Medicine, Rakuno Gakuen University, Ebetsu-shi, Hokkaido 069-8501,
   Japan, Japan.

DT Article
TI Catalogue of the tribe Picrotini (Coleoptera: Cryptophagidae:
   Cryptophaginae).
AU Leschen, R.A.B. (leschenr@landcareresearch.co.nz) 
   Gimmel, M.L.
SO New Zealand Entomologist
VL 35
IS 1
PS 14-28
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A survey of the literature and examination of type specimens of the
   tribe Picrotini Crowson, 1980 resulted in a catalogue of 38 valid
   species and 11 valid genera. We were unable to locate the types of
   Chiliotis germaini Grouvelle, Alicrambina amitta Reitter, and Micrambina
   analis (Grouvelle). Six species originally described in Ctyptophagus
   Herbst (Cryptophagus attstralis Redtenbacher, Cryptophagus amoenus
   Broun, Ctyptophagus gibbipennis Blackburn, Ctyptophagus lindensis
   Blackburn, Cryptophagus nigroapicalis Blackburn, and Oyptophagus
   tasmanicus Blackburn) remain unplaced to genus. Deposition and exact
   label data of all primary type material is presented. Lectotypes are
   designated for 15 species. Ctyptothelypterus selkirki (Bruce, 1940) is a
   junior synonym of Ctyptothelypterus atomarioides (Grouvelle, 1919), syn.
   nov. Ctyptophagus rufescens Blanchard is transferred from Cryptophagidae
   to Tenebrionidae.
C1 Leschen, R.A.B.; Landcare Res, New Zealand Arthropod Collect, Private
   Bag 92170, Auckland, New Zealand, New Zealand.

DT Article
TI Review of New Zealand Cryptamorpha (Coleoptera: Silvanidae), with a
   description of a new species from the Three Kings Islands.
AU Brown, S.D.J. (Sam.Brown@lincoln.ac.nz) 
   Marris, J.W.M.
   Leschen, R.A.B.
SO New Zealand Entomologist
VL 35
IS 1
PS 29-38
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of silvanid beetle, Cryptamorpha triregia sp. n. is
   described from the Three Kings Islands, New Zealand. A key to the New
   Zealand Ctyptamorpha species and diagnoses to the previously described
   Cryptamorpha brevicornis (White) and Cryptamorpha desjardinsi
   (Guerin-Meneville) are provided. Examination of the type series of
   Cryptamorpha curvipes Broun and Dendrophagus suturalis White show that
   C. curvipes is a synonym of C. brevicornis and confirms that D.
   suturalis is a junior synonym of C. desjardinsi, despite formerly being
   considered to be a synonym of C. brevicornis. Lectotypes are designated
   for C. brevicornis and D. suturalis.

TI A new species of Mecodema (Carabidae: Broscini) from Northland, New
   Zealand, with notes on a newly observed structure within the female
   genitalia.
AU Seldon, D.S. (d.seldon@auckland.ac.nz) 
   Leschen, R.A.B.
   Liebherr, J.K.
SO New Zealand Entomologist
VL 35
IS 1
PS 39-50
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Mecodema kokoromatua sp.n. (Carabidae: Broscini) is described from
   specimens collected from a small stretch of coastal forest adjacent to
   the Ahipara escarpment, Northland. We include a revised key and
   phylogeny for the 'curvidens group', and raise the number of endemic
   broscine species in Northland to eight. The ventral bursal keel is a
   newly identified structure from the female reproductive tract, which is
   attached ventrally to the helminthoid sclerite. The ventral bursal keel
   is Y-shaped in the 'curvidens group'.

DT Article
TI A new species of Hierodoris Meyrick (Lepidoptera: Oecophoridae) with a
   telescopic ovipositor, from granite sand plains in Fiordland.
AU Hoare, R.J.B. (hoarer@landcareresearch.co.nz) 
SO New Zealand Entomologist
VL 35
IS 1
PS 51-57
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species, Hierodoris extensilis Hoare (Lepidoptera: Oecophoridae),
   is described from Fiordland, New Zealand. Adults fly by day in February
   and appear to be restricted to granite sand and gravel fields from 1,150
   to 1,500 m above sea level on Mts Titiroa and Burns. The female has an
   exceptionally long telescopic ovipositor, which suggests that eggs may
   be laid beneath the surface of the sand in proximity to plant stems or
   roots. The species is assigned to the H. iophanes Meyrick group of Hoare
   (2005), and brings the total number of species in this endemic New
   Zealand genus to 19. New information on the life history of H. iophanes,
   a miner in cicada-damaged twigs of miro (Prumnopitys ferruginea), is
   given.
C1 Hoare, R.J.B.; Landcare Res, Private Bag 92170, Auckland, New Zealand,
   New Zealand.

AN ZOOR14811073857
DT Article
TI Ecological studies of Scaptomyza flava (Fallen, 1823) (Diptera:
   Drosophilidae) and its parasitoids.
AU Martin, N.A. (nicholas.martin@plantandfood.co.nz) 
SO New Zealand Entomologist
VL 35
IS 1
PS 58-67
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 9
AB Populations of the leafminer, Scaptomyza flava, were monitored
   fortnightly in turnip plantings at Pukekohe, south Auckland, for more
   than 2 years. The fly, and its main parasitoid, Asobara sp. (nr.
   persimilis) (Hymenoptera: Braconidae), were present throughout the year,
   with populations peaking in midsummer on spring plantings. A replicated
   field trial, comparing four planting dates, suggests that new leaves on
   young plants and on flowering stems were favoured for oviposition by the
   leafminer. In another experiment, young leaves of flowering Gypsophila
   sp. were more suitable for oviposition and larval survival than leaves
   of younger non-flowering plants. Measurements of the mandible and
   associated skeleton confirmed the existence of three leafininer larval
   instars. The parasitoid has a partial winter diapause. In midsummer, it
   achieved over 80% parasitism. A survey found Asobara parasitism of
   S.flava was restricted to a small area of south Auckland. These data,
   together with its monophagy in New Zealand and molecular analysis,
   indicate that it is either a species close to A. persimilis or a
   distinct population of that species.
C1 Martin, N.A.; New Zealand Inst Plant & Food Res Ltd, Mt Albert Res Ctr,
   Private Bag 92169, Auckland, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM nicholas.martin@plantandfood.co.nz
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Developmental
   Biology
SN 0077-9962

   Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Ecology; Population dynamics;
   Habitat; Man made habitat; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia
DE Asobara nr. persimilis [Dipteran hosts / Scaptomyza flava / Prevalence;
   host life history] [Cultivated land habitat / Turnip crop / ] [New
   Zealand / North Island, Auckland / ]. 
   Scaptomyza flava [Life cycle / Life history / prevalence; pest]
   [Hymenopteran parasites / Asobara nr. persimilis / ] [Population density
   /  / ] [Cultivated land habitat / Turnip crop / ] [New Zealand / North
   Island, Auckland / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14811075832
PM 22309510
DT Article
TI Bartonella species in bat flies (Diptera: Nycteribiidae) from western
   Africa.
AU Billeter, S.A.
   Hayman, D.T.S.
   Peel, A.J.
   Baker, K.
   Wood, J.L.N.
   Cunningham, A.
   Suu-Ire, R.
   Dittmar, K.
   Kosoy, M.Y. (mck3@cdc.gov) 
SO Parasitology
VL 139
IS 3
PS 324-329
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB Bat flies are obligate ectoparasites of bats and it has been
   hypothesized that they may be involved in the transmission of Bartonella
   species between bats. A survey was conducted to identify whether
   Cyclopodia greefi greefi (Diptera: Nycteribiidae) collected from Ghana
   and 2 islands in the Gulf of Guinea harbour Bartonella. In total, 137
   adult flies removed from Eidolon helvum, the straw-coloured fruit bat,
   were screened for the presence of Bartonella by culture and PCR
   analysis. Bartonella DNA was detected in 91 (66[center dot]4%) of the
   specimens examined and 1 strain of a Bartonella sp., initially
   identified in E. helvum blood from Kenya, was obtained from a bat fly
   collected in Ghana. This is the first study, to our knowledge, to report
   the identification and isolation of Bartonella in bat flies from western
   Africa.
C1 Kosoy, M.Y.; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Department of
   Vector Borne Diseases, 3150 Rampart Road, Fort Collins, CO 80521, USA,
   USA.
EM mck3@cdc.gov
RI Wood, James/A-1626-2008; Baker, Kate/P-2087-2016; Peel, Alison
   J/I-3202-2012; Cunningham, Andrew A/E-7536-2010
OI Wood, James/0000-0002-0258-3188; Baker, Kate/0000-0001-5850-1949; Peel,
   Alison J/0000-0003-3538-3550; Hayman, David/0000-0003-0087-3015
SC Infectious Diseases; Zoology
SN 0031-1820
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Diseases and disorders; Microbial
   diseases; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa; Oceanic islands

DT Article
TI Gastrointestinal helminths of pipistrelle bats (Pipistrellus
   pipistrellus/Pipistrellus pygmaeus) (Chiroptera: Vespertilionidae) of
   England.
AU Lord, Jennifer S.
   Parker, Steve
   Parker, Fiona
   Brooks, Darren R. (d.r.brooks@salford.ac.uk) 
SO Parasitology
VL 139
IS 3
PS 366-374
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 39
AB Although bats are one of the most successful and diverse of mammalian
   orders, studies that focus upon bat endoparasites are limited. To
   further knowledge of bat parasitology, pipistrelle bats (Pipistrellus
   pipistrellus and P. pygmaeus) were acquired from across the Greater
   Manchester and Lancashire region of England and examined for
   gastrointestinal helminths using morphological and molecular analyses.
   Sixty-eight of 90 adult/juvenile bats (76% prevalence) were infected
   with at least 1 species of helminth and mean helminth abundance was
   48[center dot]2 ([plus or minus]7[center dot]0). All helminths were
   digenean trematodes and the following species were identified in 51 P.
   pipistrellus specimens (prevalence in parentheses): Lecithodendrium
   linstowi (80[center dot]4%), L. spathulatum (19[center dot]6%),
   Prosthodendrium sp. (35[center dot]3%), Plagiorchis koreanus (29[center
   dot]4%) and Pycnoporus heteroporus (9[center dot]8%). Statistical
   analyses, incorporating multifactorial models, showed that male bats
   exhibited a significantly more aggregated helminth distribution and
   lower abundance than females. Positive associations were observed
   between L. linstowi and L. spathulatum, Prosthodendrium sp. and P.
   heteroporus and between L. spathulatum and P. koreanus. A revised
   phylogeny of bat-associated Lecithodendriidae, incorporating novel L.
   spathulatum and Prosthodendrium sp. 28S rRNA sequences, separated the
   controversial clade formed by L. linstowi and P. hurkovaae. Further
   studies are likely to assist the understanding of bat-parasite/pathogen
   relationships, helminth infracommunity structures and phylogenetics.
C1 Brooks, Darren R.; Centre for Parasitology and Disease, School of
   Environment and Life Sciences, University of Salford, Salford, Greater
   Manchester M5 4WT, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM d.r.brooks@salford.ac.uk
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Parasitology
SN 0031-1820
BD Evolution; Associations; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe; United Kingdom
DE Lecithodendrium linstowi; Lecithodendrium spathulatum [Phylogeny /  /
   prevalence; new record] [Associations /  / ] [Mammalian hosts /
   Pipistrellus pipistrellus / ] [ / Pipistrellus pygmaeus / ] [England /

TI Fossil Ostracoda from the Cretaceous Mawu Formation in the Huaiji basin,
   western Guangdong.
AU Zhang, Xianqiu
   Lin, Xiaoyan
SO Acta Micropalaeontologica Sinica
VL 29
IS 1
PS 39-51
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Cretaceous ostracods has been collected from 22 samples of borehole
   and outcrop of the Mawu Formation in the Huaiji Basin,western Guangdong.
   Totally 17 ostracod species in 10 genera have been recognized, and out
   of 14 species in 8 genera are figured here, including one new species.
   The most common genera are Eucypris, Ziziypris and Darwinula, named
   Eucypris hubeiensis-Ziziphocypris simakovi-Darwinula leguminella
   assemblage. ostracod assemblage of the Mawu Formation is very similar to
   that of the Jiadian Formation in Hubei. They are roughly equivalent in
   horizon, and should be ascribed to the latest Early Cretaceous[long
   dash]early Late Cretaceous (i. e., Albian-Cenomanian) in age.

   Sanshui Guangdong 528133, China, China.

TI Middle Triassic (Ladinian) elasmobranch scales from the southwestern
   Guizhou, China.
AU Zhang, Baomin
   Chen, Xiaohong
   Cheng, Long
   Zhang, Miao
SO Acta Micropalaeontologica Sinica
VL 29
IS 1
PS 52-61
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with the Elasmobranch scales discovered from the
   Zhuganpo Formation (Middle Triassic) in the southwestern Guizhou
   Province. 4 scale genera and 6 scale species are described and
   illustrated, with 3 new species, such as Rugosicorona circacarina sp.
   nov., Fragilicorona wanlantricuspis sp. nov. and Glabri.subcorona
   triridgecorona sp. nov. Their stratigraphic distribution and
   relationship with equivalent elasmobranch scales reported from SW China
   and SE Canada are discussed briefly.

DT Article
TI RECENT OSTRACODS (FAMILY TRACHYLEBERIDIDAE) FROM THE SOUTHERN BRAZILIAN
   CONTINENTAL SHELF.
AU Ramos, Maria Ines Feijo (mramos@museu-goeldi.br) 
   Coimbra, Joao Carlos
   Bergue, Cristianini Trescastro
   Whatley, Robin Charles
SO Ameghiniana
VL 49
IS 1
PS 3-16
PD Marzo 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The present study is a further contribution to the systematic knowledge
   of the ostracods from the southern Brazilian continental shelf. Twelve
   species of Trachyleberididae are recorded, including the following six
   new taxa: Cativella ornelasae sp. nov., C. sudbrasilienis sp. nov. sp.,
   Henryhowella inflata sp. nov., Henryhowella verrucosa sp. nov.,
   Ambocythere venusta sp. nov. and Basslerites costata sp. nov. The other
   six species have been recorded in previous studies, either in shallow or
   bathyal depths in both Brazilian waters and adjacent areas. Most species
   recorded herein are distributed in the neritic zone, except three, i.e.,
   Trachyleberis aorata, Ambocythere venusta sp. nov. and C. sudbrasilienis
   sp. nov. The first two species are eurybathic, while C. sudbrasdienis
   sp. nov. is restricted to the inner shelf.

DT Article
TI REVISION OF THE GENUS TRANSPITHECUS AMEGHINO, 1901 (NOTOUNGULATA,
   INTERATHERIIDAE) FROM THE MIDDLE EOCENE OF PATAGONIA, ARGENTINA.
FT Arevision del genero Transpithecus Ameghino, 1901 (Notoungulata,
   Interatheriidae) del eoceno medio de Patagonia, Argentina.
AU Vera, Barbara (bvera@mendoza-conicet.gob.ar) 
SO Ameghiniana
VL 49
IS 1
PS 60-74
PD Marzo 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Transpithecus Ameghino is up to now known from middle Eocene
   levels of Santa Cruz and Chubut Provinces, Argentina. Only a single
   species is known, T obtentus Ameghino, which is represented by very
   scarce remains. Traditionally, this species has been placed in the
   Subfamily "Notopithecinae" (Notoungulata, Interatheriidae) together with
   Notopithecus Ameghino, Antepithecus Ameghino, and Guilielmoscottia
   Ameghino. According to recent phylogenetic analyses, this group
   constitutes a paraphyletic assemblage conformed by basal interatheriids.
   Since Ameghino's description and except for the contribution made by
   Simpson, no recent studies on Transpithecus have been performed. In this
   contribution, the associated upper and lower dentition of a same
   individual is assigned for the first time to T obtentus. This specimen
   comes from Valle Hermoso (Chubut Province, Argentina), and has led to
   the recognition of other unpublished materials as T obtentus. The
   present study allows: (1) extending the diagnosis of T obtentus; (2)
   defining an ontogenetic sequence of its dental morphology; (3) formally
   proposing Patriarchippus annectens Ameghino as synonymous to T obtentus;
   (4) establishing similarities between Transpithecus obtentus and the
   specimen MNHN CAS 69, previously assigned to Paginula parca Ameghino;
   and (5) discarding the presence of Transpithecus in the Kibenikhoria
   faunal zone (Itaboraian South American Land Mammal Age), restricting its
   biochron to the Casamayoran South American Land Mammal Age (Barrancan
   subage; middle Eocene).
C1 Vera, Barbara; CONICET, Ctr Cient Tecnol, Ave Ruiz Leal S-N, Mendoza,
   RA-5500, Argentina, Argentina.
EM bvera@mendoza-conicet.gob.ar
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Developmental Biology
SN 0002-7014; 1851-8044
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy; Skeletal
   and supporting structures; Skeleton; Dentition; Life cycle and
   development; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Transpithecus obtentus [Teeth / Dental morphology ontogeny / Taxonomic
   revision] [Development /  / ] [Argentina / Patagonia / stratigraphical
   distribution] [Eocene / Middle Eocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI THE GENUS STEINMANELLA CRICKMAY (BIVALVIA) IN THE TRANSITION BETWEEN THE
   VACA MUERTA AND MULICHINCO FORMATIONS, EARLY VALANGINIAN, NEUQUEN BASIN,
   ARGENTINA.
AU Luci, Leticia (leticialuci@gl.fcen.uba.ar) 
   Lazo, Dario Gustavo
SO Ameghiniana
VL 49
IS 1
PS 96-117
PD Marzo 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Steinmanella Crickmay is recorded in several Lower Cretaceous
   marine units of the Neuquen Basin. It is particularly abundant at the
   transition between the Vaca Muerta and Mulichinco formations. This paper
   presents a taxonomic revision of this fauna, discusses the stratigraphic
   range of each species, and describes and interprets the associated
   lithofacies based on detailed field sections, newly collected specimens
   and revision of previous fossil collections. Four sections were measured
   in northern Neuquen comprising the upper beds of the Vaca Muerta
   Formation and the lower ones of the Mulichinco Formation. The
   Steinmanella fauna was dated accurately on the basis of a precise
   ammonoid zonation. The species were found in the Neocomites wichmanni
   and Lissonia riveroi zones of early Valanginian age. Specimens were
   collected in situ from dark grey shales, alternating siltstones,
   wackestones and mudstones, and rudstones. Three species were identified:
   Steinmanella curacoensis (Weaver), S. quintucoensis (Weaver), and S.
   subquadrata sp. nov. Steinmanella curacoensis has an oval outline, poor
   demarcation of carinae, flank and corselet ribs partially intercalated
   at the median part of the valve, and oval escutcheon. Steinmanella
   quintucoensis has a furrow below the marginal carina, subrectangular
   outline, robustly tuberculated flank ribs, and lanceolate escutcheon.
   Steinmanella subquadrata sp. nov. has a subquadrate outline, well-marked
   carinae, and oval escutcheon ornamented with thin ribs and small
   elongated tubercles.
C1 Luci, Leticia; Univ Buenos Aires, Fac Ciencias Exactas & Nat, Ciudad
   Univ,Pabellon 2,C1428EGA, Buenos Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
EM leticialuci@gl.fcen.uba.ar
OI Luci, Leticia/0000-0002-7283-1079

   / ].

TI Revision of Decapoda deposited in The Museum national d'Histoire
   naturelle, Paris.
AU Schweitzer, Carrie E. (cschweit@kent.edu) 
   Feldmann, Rodney M.
SO Bulletin of the Mizunami Fossil Museum
VL 38
PS 15-27
PD Mar 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Examination of newly rediscovered types and reexamination of type
   material of Anomura, Axiidea, and Brachyura in The Museum national
   d'Histoire naturelle, Paris, resulted in two new genera, Cretacolana and
   Styracocarcinus. Protocallianassa Beurlen, 1930, and Mesostylus Bronn
   and Roemer, 1852, were determined to be distinct genera, and the
   composition of Protocallianassa thus needs to be reevaluated. Four new
   combinations resulted from the work.

TI A new Oligocene record of Szaboa (Crustacea, Decapoda, Brachyura,
   Matutidae) from northern Germany.
AU Fraaije, Rene H.B. (info@oertijdmuseum.nl) 
   van Bakel, Barry W.M.
   Jagt, John W.M.
   Polkowsky, Stefan
SO Bulletin of the Mizunami Fossil Museum
VL 38
PS 29-31
PD Mar 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new matutid crab, Szaboa deppermanni n. sp., is described on the basis
   of a single, well-preserved carapace from the so-called 'Pampauer
   Feinsandstein' ('Pampauer Gestein'), a local erratic rock of latest
   Oligocene (Neochattian C) age at Gross Pampau (Schleswig-Holstein,
   northern Germany). It represents the first record of a matutid from
   boreal northern Europe, and constitutes the third member of the genus.

DT Article
TI A review of the decapod crustaceans from the Tertiary of the Isle of
   Wight, Hampshire, U. K, with description of three new species.
AU Quayle, W.J. (crustacea1@btopenworld.com) 
   Collins, J.S.H.
SO Bulletin of the Mizunami Fossil Museum
VL 38
PS 33-51
PD Mar 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB To the known decapod crustaceans of the Tertiary deposits of the Isle of
   Wight, Hampshire, the Early Eocene species, Basinotopus lamarkii
   (Desmarest) and Dromilites bucklandi Bell are introduced from the
   mainland, as are Glyphithyreus wetherelli (Bell), Rhachiosoma bispinosum
   Woodward, Coeloma (Litoricola) dentate (Woodward), Xanthilites
   bowerbanki Bell, and Xanthopsis unispinosa (M'Coy), the stratigrahic
   range of which has been extended to the London Clay on the Island. The
   development of an anomaly concerning Zanthopsis unispinosa, also
   present, if not peculiar to the island, is well established. A carapace
   of Harpactocarcinus sp. from this horizon is the first British record
   for the genus. Late Eocene species new to the island are Goniocypoda
   quaylei Crane, Orthakrolophus depressus? (Quayle and Collins) and
   Typilobus belli Quayle and Collins. Three new genera and species are
   described from the Late Eocene Headon Hill Formation; a callianassid,
   Vecticallichirus abditus; a goneplacid, Gonioplacoides minuta, and a
   hexapodid, Headonipus tuberculosus. New, superior material of the Late
   Eocene species, Typilobus obscurus Quayle and Collins, from the type
   locality, Colwell Bay necessitates a new description. A table of all
   known Tertiary species of decapod crustaceans from the Isle of Wight is
   appended.
C1 Quayle, W.J.; 4 Argyll St, Isle Of Wight, Hants, United Kingdom, United
   Kingdom.

U1 0

AB One axiidean, one anomuran, and four brachyurans are recorded from the
   early Miocene Kumano Group of Wakayama Prefecture, central Japan. Among
   these, Trypaea mizunamiensis Karasawa, Lithodidae?, Tymolus ingens
   Takeda and Tomida, and Macrocheira sp. aff. M. kaempferi de Haan are

   Macrocheira ginzanensis Imaizumi is briefly discussed.

DT Article
TI A Pliocene asteroid from the Netherlands Antilles.
AU Donovan, Stephen K. (Steve.Donovan@ncbnaturalis.nl) 
   Schelfhorst, Rense
SO Bulletin of the Mizunami Fossil Museum
VL 38
PS 75-77
PD Mar 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Seroe Domi Formation of Curaoao has yielded the first fossil
   asteroid from the Netherlands Antilles, based on a disarticulated
   superomarginal(?) ossicle. This is only the second occurrence of
   Pliocene asteroids in the Antillean region. The ossicle is about as long
   as broad, but low, and may represent a pycinasterid sp. indet. The Seroe
   Domi Formation has hitherto yielded a moderate diversity of robust
   echinoids.
C1 Donovan, Stephen K.; Nederlands Ctr Biodiversiteit Nat, Dept Geol,
   Postbus 9517, Leiden, NL-2300 RA, Netherlands, Netherlands.

PT J

DT Article
TI A fossil tropical giant conch Strombus (Tricornis) sp. (Gastropoda:
   Strombidae) from the Miocene Yugashima Group of Izu Peninsula, central
   Japan.
AU Tomida, Susumu (tomida@chukyogakuin-u.ac.jp) 
   Kadota, Masahito
SO Bulletin of the Mizunami Fossil Museum
VL 38
PS 79-82
PD Mar 2012
PY 2012
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A fossil giant conch occurred from the limestone intercalated in the
   light green tuffaceous sandstone of the middle Miocene Sakurada
   Formation, the Yugashima Group, at Ena, Matsuzaki-cho, Kamogun, Shizuoka
   Prefecture, Japan. As a result of the study, it is confirmed that this
   species is identical with Strombus (Tricornis) sp. in having a very
   large sized shell, and a large aperture with a large and thickened
   posterior expansion present on apertural shoulder, extending onto the
   penultimate whorl. This resembles Strombus (Tricornis) maximus Martin,
   the middle to late Miocene giant conch from Java, but it is
   distinguished from S. (T.) maximus by having less pointed but round-top
   nodes on shoulder. This is the first record of a tropical giant conch
   from the Neogene of Japan. Judging from the northward drift of the Izu
   Peninsula, the present giant Strombus (Tricornis) sp. lived in the
   tropical West Pacific Ocean during the middle Miocene.
C1 Tomida, Susumu; Chukyo Gakuin Univ, Nakatsugawa City, Gifu 509-9195,
   Japan, Japan.
EM tomida@chukyogakuin-u.ac.jp
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0385-0900
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Strombidae [Japan /  / new record] [Neogene /  / ]. 
   Strombus (Tricornis) [Shell morphology /  / New record; taxonomic
   implications] [Japan / Honshu, Shizuoka / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Miocene / Middle Miocene / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Stromboidea

   Strombus (Tricornis) (Stromboidea): [Fossil; New record].

DT Article
TI Characteristics and redefining of the Cambrian Shuangmaidi Group in the
   middle part of the Baoshan block of western Yunnan Province.
AU Chen, Guang-yan (Chenguangyan1987@163.com) 
   Guan, Xiang-dong
   Zhang, Hu
   Zeng, Wen-tao
SO Dizhi Tongbao
VL 31
IS 2-3
PS 321-325
PD Mar 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB On the basis of the latest data obtained from 1:50000 regional
   geological survey of the Banqiao Sheet, the authors redefined the
   Early-Middle Cambrian Shuangmaidi Group as the Late Cambrian Hetaoping
   Formation. The lithologic association is composed of microclastic rocks
   and marbles with some basalts and andesitic basalts. The authors
   discovered for the first time the Late Cambrian trilobites Blackwelderia
   baoshanensis Luo, Blackwelderia sp., Parashengia elongata Luo, revealing
   the loss of Early and Middle Cambrian sediments. It is interesting that
   the bottom-living and planktonic trilobites lived together in mixture.
   This study will be of great significance in the study of tectonic
   property, evolution and unit subdivision in Baoshan block.
C1 Chen, Guang-yan; Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming
   650093, Yunnan, China, China.

TI Eriophyoid mites from Hainan Province, China VI: descriptions of one new
   genus and four new species of Phyllocoptini (Acari: Eriophyidae).
AU Xue, Xiao-Feng (xfxue@njau.edu.cn) 
   Cheng, Li-Sheng
   Hong, Xiao-Yue

VL 38

LA English
U1 0

AB One new genus and four new species of the tribe Phyllocoptini (Acari:
   Eriophyidae) from China's Hainan Island are described and illustrated.
   They are Xinglongarus racemoser gen. nov. and sp. nov. on Barringtonia
   racemosa (Linn.) Blume ex DC. (Lecythidaceae), Phyllocoptruta balansis
   sp. nov. on Bridelia balansae Tutcher. (Euphorbiaceae), Phyllocoptruta
   cochinchinensis sp. nov. on Cratoxylum cochinchinense (Lour.) Blume
   (Guttiferae) and Phyllocoptruta hungmaoensix sp. nov. on Phoebe
   hungmaoensis S. Lee (Lauraceae). All the new species described herein
   are vagrants on the respective host plant.

PT J
AN ZOOR14810069253
DT Article
TI Regulation of zinc and biomagnification of mercury in biota of the
   northeastern Chukchi Sea.
AU Fox, A.L.
   Hughes, E.A.
   Trocine, R.P.
   Trefry, J.H.
   McTigue, N.D.
   Lasorsa, B.K.
   Konar, B.
SO OCS Study BOEM
VL 2012-012
PS 67-90
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Mercury contamination in the atmosphere, snow and marine mammals of the
   Arctic has been a long-term environmental concern and the focus of many
   investigations. Much less is known about the distribution of Hg in
   seawater, sediments and organisms from lower trophic levels. Mercury
   values were obtained during the COMIDA Project for eight different
   species of organisms (the isopod Synidotea bicuspida, amphipod Ampelisca
   macrocephala, clam Astarte borealis, whelk Buccinum sp., whelk Neptunea
   heros, crab Chionoecetes opilio, Arctic cod Boreogadus saida, whelk
   Plicifusus kroeyeri) from the northeastern Chukchi Sea. Concentrations
   of total Hg (THg) and monomethyl Hg (MMHg) vary greatly within and among
   species. The lowest values for THg (30 ng/g dry weight) and % MMHg (32%)
   were in A. borealis; the highest average values for THg (336 ng/g dry
   weight) and % MMHg (>95%) were in P. kroeyeri. Variations in Hg
   concentrations among and within species followed a complex pattern that
   could be partly explained by concentrations of sediment Hg and total
   organic carbon, latitude, bottom water temperature and diet. Zinc, a
   well regulated metal in marine biota, was used as a reference metal
   because concentrations varied by <10% within each species over the
   entire study area. For example, average Zn concentrations of 73 [plus or
   minus] 1 [mu]g/g dry weight and 114 [plus or minus] 2 [mu]g/g dry weight
   were found for N. heros and C. opilio, respectively. The main source of
   Zn was believed to be diet, including ingestion of suspended sediments.
   Concentrations of both THg and MMHg increased with trophic level as
   determined using data for [delta]15 N. Mercury was shown to biomagnify
   following the relationship log10(THg) = 0.17([delta]15 N) - 0.43 (r 2 =
   0.83). Unlike Hg, no biomagnification of Zn was observed.
C1 Fox, A.L.; Department of Marine and Environmental Systems, Florida
   Institute of Technology, Melbourne, Florida 32901, USA, USA.
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology
BD Biochemistry; Pollution; Chemical pollution; Abiotic factors; Chemical
   factors; Marine zones
DE Ampelisca macrocephala; Astarte borealis; Boreogadus saida; Buccinum
   sp.; Chionoecetes opilio; Neptunea heros; Plicifusus kroeyeri; Synidotea
   bicuspida [Inorganic substances / Zinc regulation / ] [Pollutants /
   Mercury biomagnification / ] [Metal pollution /  / ] [Metals /  / ]
   [Arctic Ocean / USA, Alaska, Chukchi Sea / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Crustaceans; Fish; Invertebrates; Molluscs;
   Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura, Peracarida, Amphipoda, Isopoda,
   Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii, Gadiformes,
   Gadidae, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Veneroida, Astartoidea,
   Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Muricoidea
OR Chionoecetes opilio (Brachyura). 
   Ampelisca macrocephala (Amphipoda). 
   Synidotea bicuspida (Isopoda). 
   Boreogadus saida (Gadidae). 
   Astarte borealis (Astartoidea). 
   Buccinum sp. (Muricoidea). 
   Neptunea heros (Muricoidea). 
   Plicifusus kroeyeri (Muricoidea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14810069253
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14809066042
DT Article
TI An updated checklist of the robber flies of Gambia with the description
   of a new Sphagomyia Londt, 2002 (Diptera: Asilidae).
AU Londt, J.G.H. (robber4afr@telkomsa.net) 
SO African Entomology
VL 20
IS 1
PS 13-26
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A remarkable collection of 298 Gambian Asilidae collected by William F.
   Snow between 1974 and 1977 and housed in the collections of the Oxford
   University Museum of Natural History was recently reported upon (Londt
   2010). Another collection comprising 196 specimens, collected by Snow
   from 1969 to 1973, became available for study and the results are
   reported here. A new species, Sphagomyia gambia, is described and many
   new records for previously listed species supplied. Nine species are
   recorded for the first time and a complete list of Gambian Asilidae is
   provided. With 68 species, The Gambia has West Africa's richest recorded
   asilid fauna.
C1 Londt, J.G.H.; Natal Museum, Private Bag 9070, Pietermaritzburg, 3200,
   South Africa, South Africa.
EM robber4afr@telkomsa.net
SC Zoology

PT J
AN ZOOR14809066050
DT Article
TI Anacharis madagascarensis sp. n., first record of Anacharitinae from
   Madagascar (Hymenoptera: Cynipoidea: Figitidae).
AU Pujade-Villar, J. (jpujade@ub.edu) 
SO African Entomology
VL 20
IS 1
PS 119-123
PD March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Anacharis madagascarensis sp. n. is described from
   Madagascar, which represents the first record of an Anacharitinae from
   the country and the second record of this subfamily in Africa. The
   description and diagnostic characters of the new species are illustrated
   and discussed.
C1 Pujade-Villar, J.; Departament de Biologia Animal, Facultat de Biologia,
   Universitat de Barcelona, Avenida Diagonal 645, 08028-Barcelona, Spain,
   Spain.
EM jpujade@ub.edu
RI Pujade-Villar, Juli/K-9838-2014
SC Zoology
SN 1021-3589
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Anacharis [Afrotropical region /  / New record] [Madagascar /  / ]. 
   Anacharis madagascarensis [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
   Anacharitinae [Madagascar /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae
OR Anacharis (Cynipidae): [New record]. 
   Anacharis madagascarensis (Cynipidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, Host
   unknown, p. 120]. 
   Anacharitinae (Cynipidae): [New record].
